ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-41. - Purpose, scope; code adopted. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide minimum standards, provisions and requirements for safe installation of electrical wiring and electrical appliances. All such electrical wiring and apparatus installed, replaced, maintained or repaired within the corporate limits of the city shall conform to the requirements of this article and to the specifications, rules and regulations entitled "2005 National Electrical Code, Standard of the National Board of Fire Underwriters for Electric Wiring and Apparatus as Recommended by the National Fire Protection Association," 2005 Edition, as amended, which specifications, rules and regulations are hereby incorporated in this section by reference and made a part of this article as if fully set forth herein. Copies of such specifications, rules and regulations shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1966, § 10-3; Ord. No. 02-1296, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1371, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 6-42. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the "Electrical Code for Electric Wiring and Apparatus of the City of Fitzgerald" and may be cited as such. 
(Code 1966, § 10-1) 
Sec. 6-43. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Certain appliances means electric heaters, electric floor furnaces, electric central heating plants, water heaters, and boilers. 
    Certificate of approval means a document or tag issued or attached by the inspector to the inspected material, wiring, or appliance installation, filled out, together with date, address of the premises, and signed by the inspector. 
    Inspector means the building official or duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1966, § 10-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions; rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-44. - Liability. 
    This article shall not be construed as imposing upon the city any liability or responsibility for damages to any person injured by any defect in any electrical wiring or appliance mentioned in this article, or by installation thereof, nor shall the mayor and council or any official or employee thereof, be held as assuming any such liability or responsibility by reason of the inspection authorized under this article or the certificate of approval issued by the inspector. 
(Code 1966, § 10-4) 
Sec. 6-45. - Use of existing wiring and apparatus. 
    Notwithstanding any provision in this article to the contrary, electrical wiring or apparatus installed prior to June 3, 1963, may be used, if the inspector finds, upon inspection and proper tests, that such wiring or apparatus will render reasonably satisfactory service to the consumer and will not in any way endanger life or property; otherwise, such wiring or apparatus shall be altered or replaced, in whole or in part, to conform with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 10-5) 
Sec. 6-46. - Electrician's license-Required. 
    No person shall engage in or work at the installation, extension or alteration of consumers' electrical wiring or apparatus, until such person shall have secured a license as provided in this division. 
(Code 1966, § 10-6) 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxes and business regulations, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 6-47. - Same-Issuance; transferability; duration; fee. 
    The person desiring to do electrical work shall secure from the city clerk a nontransferable license which shall run until the first day of January next succeeding its issuance, unless sooner revoked. The person obtaining a license shall pay to the city clerk an annual license fee which is on file as set from time to time in the city clerk's office. Any license obtained after the first day of July of any year shall be computed at the rate of one-half of the annual fee. 
(Code 1966, § 10-7) 
Sec. 6-48. - Work done by property owner. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as prohibiting an individual from installing or repairing his own electrical apparatus or installing, extending, replacing, altering or repairing consumer's wiring on his own premises, or as requiring a license from an individual doing such work on his own premises; provided however, all such work must be done in conformity with all other provisions of this article, including those relating to permits, inspections and fees. 
(Code 1966, § 10-8) 
Sec. 6-49. - Office of inspector created; appointment, compensation. 
    To provide for the administration and enforcement of this article, the office of electrical inspector is hereby created. The inspector, and such assistants as may be necessary in the proper performance of the duties of the office shall be appointed by the mayor and council and the compensation for such office shall be determined at the time of appointment. 
(Code 1966, § 10-9) 
State Law reference- Qualified inspectors, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26.1. 
Sec. 6-50. - Inspector to enforce chapter; right of entry. 
    The inspector is authorized and directed to enforce all of the provisions of this chapter, and the inspector, upon presentation of proper credentials, may enter any building or premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making inspections or preventing violations of this chapter. 
(Code 1966, § 10-10) 
Sec. 6-51. - Disconnecting dangerous conditions. 
    The inspector is authorized to disconnect any electrical wiring, apparatus or appliance for which a certificate of approval is required but has not been issued, or which, upon inspection, shall be found defective or in such condition as to endanger life or property. In all cases where such a disconnection is made, a notice shall be attached to the wiring, apparatus or appliance disconnected by the inspector, which notice shall state that the same has been disconnected by the inspector, together with the reasons therefor, and it shall be unlawful for any person to remove such notice or reconnect such wiring, apparatus or appliance without authorization by the inspector, and the wiring or apparatus or appliance shall not be put in service or used until the inspector has attached his certificate of approval in lieu of his prior disconnection notice. 
(Code 1966, § 10-11) 
Sec. 6-52. - Inspector to confer, obtain information. 
    It shall be the duty of the inspector to confer from time to time with representatives of the local health department, the local fire department, and the water, light and bond commission of the city, and otherwise obtain from proper sources all helpful information and advice, presenting it to the city officials from time to time for their consideration. 
(Code 1966, § 10-12) 
Sec. 6-53. - Permit for certain installations. 
    No person shall install an electrical wall heater, electric floor furnace, central electrical heating plant, electrical water heater, boiler, consumer's electrical wiring or convert existing wiring to utilize electrical energy without first obtaining a permit to do such work from the city clerk. 
(Code 1966, § 10-13) 
Cross reference- Plumbing, § 6-131 et seq.; licenses, taxes and business regulations, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 6-54. - Permit for temporary use of power. 
    When only temporary use of electrical power is desired, the inspector may issue a permit for such use, for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days, provided the consumer's electrical wiring to be used is given a test equal to that required for final wiring inspection. 
(Code 1966, § 10-14) 
Sec. 6-55. - Permits not required for water, light and bond commission work. 
    The water, light and bond commission of the city shall not be required to obtain permits to set meters, or to extend, relocate, remove or repair its service lines or other facilities or for work having to do with its own electrical system. 
(Code 1966, § 10-15) 
Sec. 6-56. - Permit fees. 
(a)  Electrical permit fees shall be paid before the issuance of any permit. The schedule of such fees is on file in the city clerk's office as set from time to time. 
(b)  Any and all fees shall be paid by the person to whom the permit is issued. 
(Code 1966, § 10-16) 
Sec. 6-57. - Fee when work begun before permit obtained. 
    Where work for which an electrical permit is required is begun before the permit is obtained the permit fee shall be doubled. 
(Code 1966, § 10-17) 
Sec. 6-58. - Where and when permits issued. 
    Electrical permits may be obtained at the office of the building department between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. each day, Monday through Friday. 
(Code 1966, § 10-18) 
Sec. 6-59. - Preliminary inspection required. 
    A preliminary wiring inspection shall be made after all new wiring authorized by the electrical permit has been installed, and before any such wiring has been covered or concealed or any apparatus or appliances have been attached thereto. 
(Code 1966, § 10-19) 
Sec. 6-60. - Final inspection required. 
    A final wiring inspection shall be made after all wiring authorized by the electrical permit has been installed and, after all portions thereof which are to be concealed by plastering or otherwise have been so concealed and before any apparatus or appliances have been attached thereto. 
(Code 1966, § 10-20) 
Sec. 6-61. - Issuance of certificate of approval. 
    The inspector shall issue a certificate of approval at the completion of the work for which a permit for consumer's wiring has been issued, if after inspection it is found that such work complies with the provisions of this article. A duplicate of each certificate issued covering consumer's electrical wiring shall be delivered to the office of the water, light, and bond commission of the city and used as its authority to render electrical service. 
(Code 1966, § 10-21) 
Sec. 6-62. - Violations, penalties. 
    Any person that shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and the license of such person may be revoked, or both fine and revocation of license may be imposed. 
(Code 1966, § 10-22) 
Secs. 6-63-6-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POLES AND WIRES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 23. 

Sec. 6-76. - General regulation by water, light and bond commission. 
    All poles, posts, crossbar wires and other fixtures placed, owned or used in any of the streets, alleys or public places of the city, by any telegraph, telephone, electric light or power company shall be so placed, owned and used under the supervision and direction of the water, light and bond commission and the commission shall have the right and authority at any time to fix the size, height, painting and designation of poles and to locate and to change the location of the poles, wires, etc. 
(Code 1966, § 10-33) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 6-77. - Location regulated. 
    It shall be the duty of the water, light and bond commission to so direct the placing of poles and wires in the streets, alleys and public places of the city that the poles and wires shall cause as little obstruction as possible, either to public travel on such thoroughfares or to the private use or enjoyment of the adjacent property. 
(Code 1966, § 10-34) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 6-78. - Authority to require removal when not in use. 
    The water, light and bond commission shall have the authority to compel the removal of utility poles and wires which are no longer in use. 
(Code 1966, § 10-35) 
Sec. 6-79. - Failure to comply with notice. 
    Any person owning or using any utility poles or wires who fails or refuses after five (5) days' notice from the water, light and bond commission to remove any poles or wires deemed by it unsuitable or unsafe or improperly located or the location of which it shall require to be changed shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 10-36) 
Sec. 6-80. - Use of condemned poles. 
    The erection or use of a utility pole rejected or condemned by the water, light and bond commission shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 10-37) 
Sec. 6-81. - Interfering with wires. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, in erecting scaffolds, putting up signs, repairing or painting buildings or in any other activity, to cut or break or in any manner interfere with the arrangement of the telegraph, telephone, light, power or other wires. 
(Code 1966, § 10-38) 
Sec. 6-82. - Tampering. 
(a)  The following acts are declared to be unlawful and punishable as provided by the Charter of the city: 
(1)  Tampering with or altering any utility or any line, wire, pipe or other device or other instrumentality used in connection with the operation of the utility system of the water, light and bond commission. 
(2)  Tampering with, resetting or otherwise interfering with any metering device used in the operation of the utility system of the water, light and bond commission whether the device is owned by the commission, the customer or otherwise, so as to cause it to run backward, to register incorrectly or to fail to operate. 
(3)  Performing any act or using any means, method, device or contrivance which bypasses a metering device, metering instrument or other instrument used to measure consumption of utilities or which otherwise prevents such device from accurately recording the consumption of the utility, regardless of whether such device is owned by the water, light and bond commission, the customer or otherwise. 
(4)  Placing upon the lines, conductors, pipes or other instrumentalities conveying utilities, regardless of whether they are owned by the water, light and bond commission, the customer or otherwise, any device or instrument by means of which the utility is made available without being measured or recorded. 
(5)  Any unauthorized use of a metering device or a conducting facility so as to obtain utilities without paying for them. 
(6)  Where there is no evidence to the contrary, the person performing any of the illegal acts referred to in this section or any person who with knowledge of such violations receives the benefit of such service without proper charge as a result of such improper action shall be presumed to be responsible for such acts of tampering or diversion. 
(7)  Any customer who requests electrical current from the water, light and bond commission shall be responsible for seeing that all meters, wires and other instrumentalities used in the operation of the utility system of the commission which are located on the property owned, rented or under the control of such customer are not tampered with or altered. 
(b)  Any person who performs any of the acts set forth in this section or who conspires to do so or procures or causes to be done any of such acts or who uses or consumes any utility furnished by the water, light and bond commission with knowledge that any of such acts have been done and that such use is not being properly and accurately recorded, shall be guilty of an offense and punishable as provided in the Charter of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 10-39) 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Criminal interference with government property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; damaging, injuring, or interfering with property of public utility companies, municipalities, or political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. 
Secs. 6-83-6-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GAS 

Sec. 6-96. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the "Natural and/or Manufactured or Bottled Gas Code of the City of Fitzgerald" and may be cited as such. 
(Code 1966, § 14-1) 
Sec. 6-97. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Certain appliances means conversion burners, floor furnaces, central heating plants, vented recessed heaters, water heaters and boilers. 
    Certificate of approval means a document or tag issued or attached by the inspector to the inspected material, piping or appliance installation, filled out, together with date, address of the premises and signed by the inspector. 
    Gas company means any person distributing natural and/or manufactured or bottled gas within the corporate limits of the city, or authorized and proposing to so engage. 
    Inspector means the building official or authorized representative. 
(Code 1966, § 14-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-98. - Purpose, scope; code adopted. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide minimum standards, provisions and requirements for safe installation of consumers' gas piping and gas appliances. All such gas piping and gas appliances installed, replaced, maintained or repaired within the corporate limits of the city shall conform to the requirements of this article and to the specifications, rules, and regulations entitled Installation of Consumer's Gas Piping and Gas Appliances, International Fuel Gas Code, 2006 Edition, as amended, which specifications, rules and regulations are hereby incorporated in this section by reference and made a part of this article as if fully set forth in this section. Copies of such specifications, rules and regulations shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1966, § 14-3; Ord. No. 1140, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 02-1296, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1371, 3-12-07) 
Cross reference- Building official to enforce technical codes, § 6-1. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. 1983, Art. IX, Sec. II, Para. III(a)(12). 
Sec. 6-99. - Liability. 
    This article shall not be construed as imposing upon the city any liability or responsibility for damages to any person injured by any defect in any gas piping or appliance mentioned in this article or by installation thereof, nor shall the mayor and council or any official or employee thereof be held as assuming any such liability or responsibility by reason of the inspection authorized in this article or the certificate of approval issued by the inspector. 
(Code 1966, § 14-4) 
Sec. 6-100. - Use of existing piping. 
    Notwithstanding any provision in this article to the contrary, consumer's piping installed prior to March 7, 1960, or piping installed to supply other than natural gas may be converted to natural gas if the inspector finds upon inspection and proper tests that such piping will render reasonably satisfactory gas service to the consumer and will not in any way endanger life or property. Otherwise, such piping shall be altered or replaced in whole or in part to conform with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 14-5) 
Sec. 6-101. - Gas fitters examination, license, bond and insurance required. 
    No person shall engage in or work at the installation or alteration of consumers' gas piping or any gas appliance which uses liquefied petroleum or natural gas sold by water, light and bond commission until such person has successfully completed an examination conducted by the gas inspector of the water, light and bond commission and shall have delivered to the city a public liability and property damage insurance policy with limits of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) and shall have delivered to the city a fidelity bond for three thousand dollars ($3,000.00). Such bond and insurance must be issued by a responsible surety company and insurance company authorized to do business in the state. Such bond shall be made payable to the mayor of the city and his successor in office for the use and benefit of the city and the public, conditioned for the faithful performance of all gas fitting done by the principal within the area covered by this section and conditioned further that the principal will comply with all valid ordinances enacted by the city relating to gas fitting, and indemnifying and saving harmless the city and the general public from any damage that may result from obligor's negligence or failure to faithfully perform any work properly. Such bond and insurance shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Code 1966, § 14-6) 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxes and business regulations, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 6-102. - Issuance of license; transferability; duration; fee. 
    Upon approval of the gas fitter's fidelity bond, the person desiring to do the gas work shall secure from the city clerk a nontransferable license which shall run until the first day of January next succeeding its issuance, unless sooner revoked. The person obtaining a license shall pay an annual license fee to the city clerk the amount of which is on file in the city clerk's office as set from time to time. Any license obtained after the first day of July of any year shall be computed at the rate of one-half of the annual fee. 
(Code 1966, § 14-7) 
Sec. 6-103. - Work done by owner. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as prohibiting an individual from installing or repairing his own appliances or installing, extending, replacing, altering or repairing consumer's piping on his own premises or as requiring a license or a bond from an individual doing such work on his own premises; provided, however, all such work must be done in conformity with all other provisions of this article, including those relating to permits, inspection and fees. 
(Code 1966, § 14-8) 
Sec. 6-104. - Office of inspector created; appointment, compensation. 
    To provide for the administration and enforcement of this article, the office of gas inspector is hereby created. The inspector, and such assistants as may be necessary in the proper performance of the duties of the office, shall be appointed by the mayor and council and the compensation for such office shall be determined at the time of appointment. 
(Code 1966, § 14-9) 
Sec. 6-105. - Enforcement by inspector; right of entry. 
    The inspector is authorized and directed to enforce all of the provisions of this article. The inspector, upon presentation of proper credentials, may enter any building or premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making inspections or preventing violations of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 14-10) 
Sec. 6-106. - Disconnecting dangerous conditions. 
    The inspector is authorized to disconnect any gas piping or fixture or appliance for which a certificate of approval is required but has not been issued, or which upon inspection shall be found defective or in such condition as to endanger life or property. In all cases where such a disconnection is made, a notice shall be attached to the piping, fixture or appliance disconnected by the inspector, which notice shall state that the same has been disconnected by the inspector, together with the reasons therefor. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove the notice or reconnect the gas piping or fixture or appliance without authorization by the inspector and such gas piping or fixture or appliance shall not be put in service or used until the inspector has attached his certificate of approval in lieu of his prior disconnection notice. 
(Code 1966, § 14-11) 
Sec. 6-107. - Duty of inspector to confer, obtain information. 
    It shall be the duty of the inspector to confer from time to time with representatives of the local health department, the local fire department and the gas company and otherwise obtain from proper sources all helpful information and advice, presenting it to the city officials from time to time for their consideration. 
(Code 1966, § 14-12) 
Sec. 6-108. - Permit required. 
    No person shall install a gas conversion burner, floor furnace, central heating plant, vented recessed heater, water heater, boiler, consumer's gas piping or convert existing piping to utilize natural gas without first obtaining a permit to do such work from the city clerk. However, permits will not be required for setting or connecting other gas appliances or for the repair of leaks in house piping. 
(Code 1966, § 14-13) 
Cross reference- Plumbing, § 6-131 et seq.; licenses, taxes and business regulations, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 6-109. - Permit for temporary use. 
    When only temporary use of gas is desired, the inspector may issue a permit for such use for a period of not to exceed sixty (60) days, provided the consumer's gas piping to be used is given a test equal to that required for a final piping inspection. 
(Code 1966, § 14-14) 
Sec. 6-110. - Permits not required for gas company. 
    The gas company shall not be required to obtain permits to set meters, or to extend, relocate, remove or repair its service lines, mains or other facilities or for work having to do with its own gas system. 
(Code 1966, § 14-15) 
Sec. 6-111. - Permit fee. 
    A fee shall be charged for each gas permit, which amount is on file in the city clerk's office as set from time to time. No permit shall be issued until the fee has been paid. 
(Code 1966, § 14-16) 
Sec. 6-112. - Fee when work begun before permit issued. 
    If work for which a gas permit is required is begun before the permit is obtained, the permit fee shall be doubled. 
(Code 1966, § 14-17) 
Sec. 6-113. - Where and when permits issued. 
    Gas permits may be obtained at the office of the building department between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. each day, Monday through Friday. 
(Code 1966, § 14-18) 
Sec. 6-114. - Rough piping inspection required. 
    A rough piping inspection shall be made after all new piping authorized by the permit has been installed, and before any such piping has been covered or concealed or any fixtures or gas appliances have been attached thereto. 
(Code 1966, § 14-19) 
Sec. 6-115. - Final piping inspection required; procedure. 
    A final piping inspection shall be made after all piping authorized by the permit has been installed and after all portions thereof which are to be concealed by plastering or otherwise have been so concealed, and before any fixtures or gas appliances have been attached thereto. This inspection shall include a pressure test, at which time the piping shall stand an air pressure equal to not less than the pressure of a column of mercury twelve (12) inches in height, and the piping shall hold this air pressure for a period of at least fifteen (15) minutes without any perceptible drop. A mercury column gauge shall be used for the test. All tools, apparatus, labor and assistance necessary for the tests shall be furnished by the installer of such piping. 
(Code 1966, § 14-20) 
Sec. 6-116. - Issuance of certificates of approval. 
    The inspector shall issue a certificate of approval at the completion of the work for which a permit for consumer piping has been issued, if after inspection it is found that such work complies with the provisions of this article. A duplicate of each certificate issued covering consumer's gas piping shall be delivered to the gas company and used as its authority to render gas service. 
(Code 1966, § 14-21) 
Sec. 6-117. - Violations, penalties. 
    Any person that shall fail to comply with or violate any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and the license of such person may be revoked or both fine and revocation of license may be imposed. 
(Code 1966, § 14-22) 
Secs. 6-118-6-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING 

Sec. 6-131. - Code adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the installation of plumbing including alterations, repairs, equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and appurtenances thereto, including permits and penalties, that certain building code known as International Plumbing Code, being particularly the 2006 Edition, as amended thereof, a copy of which has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk. Such code is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length in this section and the provisions thereof shall be controlling in every plumbing installation and other related subjects therein contained within the corporate limits of the city or when connected to the city water or city sewage system. 
(Code 1966, § 22-1; Ord. No. 1140, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 02-1296, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1371, 3-12-07) 
Cross reference- Building official to enforce technical codes, § 6-1. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. 1983, Art. IX, Sec. II, Para. III(a)(12). 
Sec. 6-132. - "City" defined for purposes of code. 
    Wherever the word "city" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be held to mean the City of Fitzgerald. 
(Code 1966, § 22-2) 
Sec. 6-133. - Payment of license fee prerequisite to issuance of permit. 
    No permit as required by the code adopted in this article shall be issued until the fee prescribed in the then applicable business license ordinance of the city shall have been paid. 
(Code 1966, § 22-2.1) 
Sec. 6-134. - Permit fees. 
    The fee for issuance of a plumbing permit which shall be paid before the permit is issued shall be on file in the city clerk's office as set from time to time. 
(Code 1966, § 22-3) 
Sec. 6-135. - Permit fee when work begins before permit obtained. 
    Where work is started before a plumbing permit is obtained, the permit fee shall be doubled. 
(Code 1966, § 22-4) 
Sec. 6-136. - Reinspection fees. 
    There shall be a reinspection fee for each reinspection due to work being condemned, the amount of which is on file in the city clerk's office as set from time to time. 
(Code 1966, § 22-5) 
Sec. 6-137. - When and where permits issued. 
    Plumbing permits may be obtained at the office of the building department between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. each day, Monday through Friday. 
(Code 1966, § 22-6) 
Secs. 6-138-6-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RADIO AND TV ANTENNA[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, App. B; cable television franchise, App. C, Art. II. 

Sec. 6-151. - Scope; compliance required. 
    Any and all radio and television antenna, masts or similar appliances, including all their appurtenances, which are now or may hereafter be erected, installed, maintained or used within the corporate limits of the city shall be erected, installed, maintained and used in accordance and compliance with and in conformity to the following regulations which are hereby set up and established for the regulation and control of the installation, erection, maintenance and use thereof. 
(Code 1966, § 6-22) 
Sec. 6-152. - Permits required; application, issuance. 
    Any person desiring to erect any radio or television antenna, masts or similar appliances, including all their appurtenances shall, before such erection or installation, make written application to the building official of the city for a permit to do so. If the property upon which such installation or erection is to be made is owned by another person, such application shall be accompanied by the written consent of the owner of the property upon which such installation is to be made. Such application shall be submitted upon forms to be prescribed by the building official of the city and shall set forth detailed information regarding the location, type of installation, materials to be used and all other facts required therein. When the application shows that the proposed work and equipment conform to the regulations prescribed in this article, the building official shall issue a permit therefor. Where the application fails to show conformity to the provisions of this article, a permit shall be denied. It shall be unlawful for any person to erect a radio or television antenna, mast or similar appliance without first obtaining a permit as required in this article. 
(Code 1966, § 6-23) 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxes and business regulations, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 6-153. - Permit fee. 
    The fee of permits required by this article shall be on file in the city clerk's office as set from time to time. 
(Code 1966, § 6-24) 
Sec. 6-154. - When and where permits may be obtained. 
    Permits required by this article may be obtained at the office of the building department between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. each day, Monday through Friday. 
(Code 1966, § 6-25) 
Sec. 6-155. - Safety wire required. 
    No antenna or mast shall be located where it will be in danger of falling on any electrical distribution lines unless a separate safety wire is attached to the crossarm of the antenna and is sufficiently anchored as required in section 6-157. 
(Code 1966, § 6-26) 
Sec. 6-156. - Guy wires required. 
    The antennae or masts shall have at least three (3) guy wires of number twelve (12) or larger gauge galvanized wire or six-strand clothesline wire. 
(Code 1966, § 6-27) 
Sec. 6-157. - Anchoring of guy wires. 
    All guy wires shall be anchored securely. If the anchors are fastened to the wood structure of a building or other structure, screw type eye bolts at least five-sixteenths inch in diameter shall be embedded into the solid wood at least three (3) inches deep. All guy wires extended to the ground shall be fastened to one and one-fourth-inch iron pipe driven at least three (3) feet, six (6) inches into firm soil or clay or a four-inch by four-inch pressure treated wood driven three (3) feet, six (6) inches into firm soil or clay. A plate of iron three-eighths inch thick and with an area of at least one (1) square foot having a one-half-inch diameter road fastened thereto may be embedded three (3) feet below ground surface to provide anchorage for the guy wires. All guy wires fastened to masonry shall be by means of two (2) three-eighths-inch expansion bolts embedded at least four (4) inches into the masonry. Nails for fasteners or anchorage are prohibited. Guy wires shall be secured to anchors by served connections or served wrapped ends or with wire clamps. 
(Code 1966, § 6-28) 
Sec. 6-158. - Grounding required. 
    All antennae or masts shall be grounded by means of not less than number six (6) gauge copper wire clamped to a ground rod driven four (4) feet into the earth or to cold water piping of the building wherever the contact is made within eight (8) feet of the vertical line of antennae or masts. If conditions of the earth are such that no moisture is obtained at four (4) feet depth then a hole shall be drilled or dug at least four (4) feet deep and after placing the grounding rod therein the hole shall be filled with wet charcoal. All grounding conductors shall be run in as straight a line as practical from equipment to the grounding electrode or rod. Lightning arrestors or lead-ins are not to be considered the grounding of the antennae or masts. 
(Code 1966, § 6-29) 
Sec. 6-159. - Lightning arrestors on lead-in conductors. 
    Whenever lead-in conductors of polyethylene ribbon type are used, lightning arrestors shall be used on each lead-in conductor. Lightning arrestors shall be grounded in a similar manner to requirements for antennae or masts. 
(Code 1966, § 6-30) 
Sec. 6-160. - Fastening to chimneys, flues. 
    No antenna or mast shall be fastened to a chimney unless the antenna or mast has sufficient guy wires. Any fastening to a chimney or flue will be accepted only as a stabilizer for the base of the antennae or masts and not as a brace. Any anchorage to a chimney or flue shall be made by a steel band of sixteen (16) gauge metal one (1) inch wide or any manufactured approved chimney clamp. The ends of such band shall be fastened by means of clamps or rivets. There shall be at least one hundred fifty (150) pounds of masonry above the clamp figured on a basis of six (6) pounds per brick in place. 
(Code 1966, § 6-31) 
Sec. 6-161. - Anchorage to cornice or projection prohibited. 
    No anchorage for a guy wire shall be made to a cornice or projection of any building but shall be made to substantial framing or walls of the building. 
(Code 1966, § 6-32) 
Sec. 6-162. - Installations, attachments to property of another. 
(a)  No lessee, tenant or person other than the owner shall install or maintain any radio or television antennae, masts or similar appliances, including appurtenances thereof, upon any building or other structure nor shall any lessee, tenant or person other than the owner affix or attach any guy wires from any such antenna, masts or similar appliances to any building or structure without the written permission of the owner of any such building or structure. 
(b)  No guy wire shall be permitted to be fastened to any adjoining building or structure without written consent of the owner of the adjoining building or structure. 
(Code 1966, § 6-33) 
Sec. 6-163. - Guy wires obstructing travel. 
    No guy wires shall be permitted to be placed in the path of regular travel or to form a trap for anyone. 
(Code 1966, § 6-34) 
Sec. 6-164. - Building official to inspect, assume compliance. 
    It shall be the duty of the building official to inspect the installation of any radio or television antennae or masts or similar appliances and to require compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 6-35) 
Sec. 6-165. - Notice, correction of nonconforming conditions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or use or have in or upon his premises a radio or television antenna or mast or similar appliance unless it shall conform to the regulations set forth in this article. If any radio or television antennae, masts or similar appliances, including guy wires and all appurtenances thereto, shall be found to be in violation of any portion of this article, the building official shall give a written notice to the owner of such equipment setting out the defects and such owner shall have a period of ten (10) days from the date of the service of such written notice upon him to correct the conditions of such equipment and to conform to the regulations of this article or to remove the equipment from the premises. Upon the owner's failure to comply, he shall be served with a summons to appear in the municipal court for violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 6-36) 
Secs. 6-166-6-180. - Reserved.
