 Note c. 1 square foot = 0.093 m 2 . 
(1)  Sleeping area. The minimum occupancy area required by Table 404.5 shall not be included as sleeping area in determining minimum occupancy area for sleeping purposes. All sleeping areas shall comply with subsection (d) above. 
(2)  Combined spaces. Combined living room and dining room spaces shall comply with the requirements of Table 404.5 if the total area is equal to that required for separate rooms and if the space is located so as to function as a combination living room/dining room. 
(f)  Efficiency dwelling units. An efficiency living unit shall conform to the requirements of the code except as modified herein: 
(1)  The unit shall have a living room of not less than two hundred twenty (220) square feet (20.4 m) of floor area. An additional one hundred (100) square feet (9.3 m) of floor area shall be provided for each occupant of such unit in excess of two (2). 
(2)  The unit shall be provided with a separate closet. 
(3)  The unit shall be provided with a kitchen sink, cooking appliance and refrigeration facilities, each having a clear working space of not less than thirty (30) inches (762 mm) in front. Light and ventilation conforming to this code shall be provided. 
(4)  The unit shall be provided with a separate bathroom containing a water closet, lavatory and bathtub or shower. 
(g)  Food preparation. All spaces to be occupied for food preparation purposes shall contain suitable space and equipment to store, prepare and serve foods in a sanitary manner. There shall be adequate facilities and services for the sanitary disposal of food wastes and refuse, including facilities for temporary storage. 
(h)  Kitchen Facilities. Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen equipped with the following minimum facilities and shall comply with the provisions of section 302.6 of the Standard Housing Code 1997: 
(1)  Food preparation surfaces impervious to water and free of defects which could trap food or liquid. 
(2)  Shelving, cabinets or drawers for the storage of food and cooking and eating utensils, all of which shall be maintained in good repair. 
(3)  Freestanding or permanently installed cookstove. Portable electric cooking equipment shall not fulfill this requirement. Portable cooking equipment employing flame shall be prohibited. 
(4)  Mechanical refrigeration equipment for the storage of perishable foodstuffs. 
Exception: Nothing herein shall preclude a written agreement between an owner and tenant that the tenant will furnish mechanical refrigeration equipment and/or a cookstove as required in this section. It shall be an affirmative defense available to an owner charged with a violation of this section if such an agreement exists. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 404, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1371, 3-12-07) 
Secs. 6-305-6-320. - Reserved. 
DVISION 5. - PLUMBING FACILITIES AND FIXTURE REQUIREMENTS. 

Sec. 6-321. - General. 
(a)  Scope. The provisions of this division shall govern the minimum plumbing systems, facilities and plumbing fixtures to be provided. 
(b)  Responsibility. The owner of the occupied structure or his designated agent shall provide and maintain such plumbing facilities and plumbing fixtures in compliance with these requirements. A person shall not occupy as owner-occupant or permit another person to occupy any structure or premises which does not comply with the requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 501, 7-8-02) 
Sec. 6-322. - Required facilities. 
(a)  Sanitary facilities. Every dwelling unit shall contain not less than a kitchen sink, lavatory, tub or shower, and a water closet all in good working condition and properly connected to an approved water and sewer system. Every plumbing fixture and water and waste pipe shall be properly installed and maintained in good sanitary working condition free from defects, leaks, and obstructions. 
(1)  Location of sanitary facilities. All required plumbing fixtures shall be located within the dwelling unit and be accessible to the occupants of same. The water closet, tub or shower and lavatory shall be located in a room affording privacy to the user and such room shall have a minimum floor space of thirty (30) square feet (2.8 m 2 ) with no dimension less than four (4) feet (1,219 mm). Bathrooms shall be accessible from habitable rooms, hallways, corridors or other protected or enclosed areas. 
(b)  Rooming houses. At least one (1) water closet lavatory and bathtub or shower shall be supplied for each four (4) rooming units and shall comply with the provisions of section 308.3 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(c)  Hotels. Where private water closets, lavatories, and baths are not provided, one (1) water closet, one (1) lavatory and one (1) bathtub or shower having access from a public hallway shall be provided for each ten (10) occupants. 
(d)  Employee's facilities. A minimum of one (1) water closet, one (1) lavatory and one (1) drinking facility shall be available to employees. 
(1)  Drinking facilities. Drinking facilities shall be a drinking fountain, water cooler, bottled water cooler, or disposable cups next to a sink or water dispenser. Drinking facilities shall not be located in toilet rooms or bathrooms. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 502, 7-8-02) 
Sec. 6-323. - Toilet rooms. 
(a)  Privacy. Toilet rooms and bathrooms shall provide privacy and shall not constitute the only passageway to a hall or other space, or to the exterior and shall comply with the provisions of section 302.2 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(b)  Location. Toilet rooms and bathrooms serving hotel units, rooming units or dormitory units, shall have access by traversing not more than one (1) flight of stairs and shall have access from a common hall or passageway. 
(c)  Location of employee toilet facilities. Toilet facilities shall have access from within the employees' regular working area. The required toilet facilities shall be located not more than one (1) story above or below the employee's regular working area and the path of travel to such facilities shall not exceed a distance of five hundred (500) feet (152 m). Employee facilities shall either be separate facilities or public customer facilities and shall comply with the provisions of section 2902.5 of the International Building Code 2006. 
Exception: Facilities that are required for employees in storage structures or kiosks, and which are located in adjacent structures under the same ownership, lease or control, shall not exceed a travel distance of five hundred (500) feet (152 m) from the employee's regular working area to the facilities. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 503, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1371, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 6-324. - Plumbing fixtures. 
(a)  General. Plumbing fixtures shall be properly installed and maintained in working order, and shall be kept free from obstructions, leaks and defects and be capable of performing the function for which such plumbing fixtures are designed. Plumbing fixtures shall be maintained in a safe, sanitary and functional condition. 
(b)  Fixture clearances. Plumbing fixtures shall have adequate clearances for usage and cleaning. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 504, 7-8-02) 
Sec. 6-325. - Water system. 
(a)  General. Every sink, lavatory, bathtub or shower, drinking fountain, water closet or other plumbing fixture shall be properly connected to either a public water system or to an approved private water system. Kitchen sinks, lavatories, laundry facilities, bathtubs and showers shall be supplied with hot or tempered and cold running water, and shall comply with the provisions of section 6-282.3 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(b)  Contamination. The water supply shall be maintained free from contamination, and all water inlets for plumbing fixtures shall be located above the flood level rim of the fixture. Shampoo basin faucets, janitor sink faucets, and other hose bibs or faucets to which hoses are attached and left in place, shall be protected by an approved atmospheric-type vacuum breaker or an approved permanently attached hose connection vacuum breaker and shall comply with the provisions of sections 609.12.1 through 609.14.4.2 in the International Plumbing Code 2006. 
(c)  Supply. The water supply system shall be installed and maintained to provide a supply of water to plumbing fixtures, devices and appurtenances in sufficient volume and at pressures adequate to enable the fixtures to function properly, safely, and free from defects and leaks. 
(d)  Water heating facilities. Water heating facilities shall be properly installed, maintained and capable of providing an adequate amount of water to be drawn at every required kitchen sink, lavatory, bathtub, shower and laundry facility at a temperature of not less than one hundred twenty degrees Fahrenheit (120°F), forty-nine degrees Celsius (49°C). A gas-burning water heater shall not be located in any bathroom, toilet room, bedroom or other occupied room normally kept closed, unless adequate combustion air is provided. An approved combination temperature and pressure relief valve and relief valve discharge pipe shall be properly installed and maintained on water heaters and shall comply with the provisions of section 6-282.4 in the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 505, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1392, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 6-326. - Sanitary drainage system. 
(a)  General. Plumbing fixtures shall be properly connected to either a public sewer system or to an approved private sewage disposal system. In accordance with section 302.1 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(b)  Maintenance. Every plumbing stack, vent, waste and sewer line shall function properly and be kept free from obstructions, leaks and defects. In accordance with section 302.1 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 506, 7-8-02) 
Sec. 6-327. - Storm drainage. 
    Drainage of roofs and paved areas, yards and courts, and other open areas on the premises shall not be discharged in a way that creates a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 507, 7-8-02) 
Secs. 6-328-6-340. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - MECHANICAL AND ELECTRICAL REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 6-341. - General. 
(a)  Scope. The provisions of this division shall govern the minimum mechanical and electrical facilities and equipment to be provided. 
(b)  Responsibility. The owner or his designated agent of the structure shall provide and maintain mechanical and electrical facilities and equipment in compliance with these requirements. A person shall not occupy as owner-occupant or permit another person to occupy any premises which does not comply with the requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 601, 7-8-02) 
Sec. 6-342. - Heating facilities. 
(a)  Heating facilities. Every dwelling unit shall have heating facilities which are properly installed, are maintained in safe and good working conditions, and are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms and bathrooms and shall comply with the provisions of section 302.5.1 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(1)  Where a central heating system is not provided, each dwelling unit shall be provided with facilities whereby heating appliances may be connected, and shall comply with the provision of section 302.5.2 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(2)  Gas heaters listed for unvented use shall be permitted provided the room heaters are installed in accordance with their listing and the manufacturer's instructions. Unvented room heaters shall not have a normal input rating in excess of forty thousand (40,000) Btu per hour (11.7 kW) and shall not be installed in sleeping quarters. 
Exception: Listed unvented room heaters for installation in bedrooms shall not have normal input rating in excess of ten thousand (10,000) Btu per hour (2.9 kW). Listed unvented room heaters for installation in bathrooms shall not have normal input rating in excess of six thousand (6,000) Btu per hour (1.8 kW). 
(3)  Gas fired vented heaters installed in bedrooms or rooms generally kept closed shall be connected to an effective chimney or gas vent or equipped with a safety shutoff device. Gas fired unvented heaters installed in bedrooms, bathrooms or rooms generally kept closed shall be wall-mounted. 
(b)  [Liquid fueled unvented heating appliance.] The use of any liquid fueled unvented heating appliance shall be permitted in one-family and two-family residences only, providing such appliance is tested and listed by an approved laboratory according to requirements of UL 647 (1984) and providing the fuel is stored in containers meeting ASTM ES-8 for kerosene containers and shall comply with the provisions of section 302.5.4 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(c)  Commercial structures. Every enclosed occupied workspace shall be supplied with sufficient heat during the period from October to April to maintain a temperature of not less than sixty-five degrees Fahrenheit (65°F), eighteen degrees Celsius (18°C) during all working hours. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  Processing, storage and operation areas that require cooling or special temperature conditions. 
(2)  Areas in which persons are primarily engaged in vigorous physical activities. 
(d)  Room temperature measurements. The required room temperature shall be measured at a point three (3) feet (914 mm) above the floor and three (3) feet (914 mm) from the exterior walls. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 602, 7-8-02) 
Sec. 6-343. - Mechanical equipment. 
(a)  Mechanical equipment. Mechanical equipment, fireplaces and solid fuel-burning appliances shall be properly installed and maintained in a safe working condition, and shall be capable of performing the intended function and shall comply with the provisions of section 302.5.1 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(b)  Equipment access. Access to outdoor mechanical equipment shall be maintained under all weather conditions. 
(c)  Cooking and heating equipment. Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen equipped with the following minimum facilities: 
(1)  Food preparation surfaces impervious to water and free of defects which could trap food or liquid. 
(2)  Shelving, cabinets or drawers for the storage of food and cooking and eating utensils, all of which shall be maintained in good repair. 
(3)  Freestanding or permanently installed cookstove. Portable electric cooking equipment shall not fulfill this requirement. Portable cooking equipment employing flame shall be prohibited. 
(4)  Mechanical refrigeration equipment for the storage of perishable foodstuffs. 
Exception: Nothing herein shall preclude a written agreement between an owner and tenant that the tenant will furnish mechanical refrigeration equipment and/or a cookstove as required in this section. It shall be an affirmative defense available to an owner charged with a violation of this section if such an agreement exists. 
(d)  Flue. All fuel-burning equipment and appliances shall be connected to an approved chimney or vent. 
Exception: Fuel-burning equipment and appliances which are labeled for unvented operation. 
(e)  Clearances. All required clearances to combustible materials shall be maintained. 
(f)  Safety controls. All safety controls for fuel-burning equipment shall be maintained in effective operation. 
(g)  Combustion air. A supply of air for complete combustion of the fuel and for ventilation of the space shall be provided for the fuel burning and shall comply with the provisions of section 701.2 of the International Mechanical Code 2006. 
(h)  Energy conservation devices. Devices intended to reduce fuel consumption by attachment to a fuel-burning appliance, to the fuel supply line thereto, or to the vent outlet or vent piping therefrom, shall not be installed unless labeled for such purpose and the installation is specifically approved. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 603, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1392, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 6-344. - Electrical facilities. 
(a)  Facilities required. Every occupied building shall be provided with an electrical system in compliance with the requirements of this section and section 6-345. 
(b)  Service. The size and usage of appliances and equipment shall serve as a basis for determining the need for additional facilities in accordance with NFPA 70. Every dwelling unit shall be served by a main service that is not less than one hundred (100) amperes, three (3) wires, and shall comply with the provisions in section E3502.1 of the International Residential Code 2006. 
(c)  Electrical system hazards. Where it is found that the electrical system in a structure constitutes a hazard to the occupants or the structure by reason of inadequate service, improper fusing, insufficient outlets, improper wiring or installation, deterioration or damage, or for similar reasons, the city official shall require the defects to be corrected to eliminate the hazard. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 604, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1392, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 6-345. - Electrical equipment. 
(a)  Installation. Electrical equipment, wiring and appliances shall be properly installed and maintained in a safe and approved manner. 
(b)  Electrical lights and outlets. Where there is electrical service available to the building structure, every habitable room or space shall contain at least two (2) separate and remote receptacle outlets. Bedrooms shall have, in addition, at least one (1) wall switch-controlled lighting outlet. In kitchens, two (2) separate and remote receptacle outlets shall be provided (receptacles rendered inaccessible by appliances fastened in place or by appliances occupying dedicated space shall not be considered as these required outlets) and a wall or ceiling lighting outlet controlled by a wall switch shall be provided. Every hall, water closet compartment, bathroom, laundry room or furnace room shall contain at least one (1) ceiling-mounted or wall-mounted lighting outlet. In bathrooms, the lighting outlet shall be controlled by a wall switch. In addition to the lighting outlet in every bathroom and laundry room, there shall be provided at least one (1) receptacle outlet. Any new bathroom receptacle outlet shall have ground fault circuit interrupter protection. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 605, 7-8-02) 
Sec. 6-346. - Elevators, escalators and dumbwaiters. 
(a)  General. Elevators, dumbwaiters and escalators shall be maintained to sustain safely all imposed loads, to operate properly, and to be free from physical and fire hazards. 
(b)  Elevators. In buildings equipped with passenger elevators, at least one (1) elevator shall be maintained in operation at all times when the building is occupied. 
Exception: Buildings equipped with only one (1) elevator shall be permitted to have the elevator temporarily out of service for testing or servicing. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 606, 7-8-02) 
Secs. 6-347-6-360. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - FIRE SAFETY REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 6-361. - General. 
(a)  Scope. The provisions of this division shall govern the minimum conditions and standards for fire safety relating to structures and exterior premises, including fire safety facilities and equipment to be provided. 
(b)  Responsibility. The owner or owner's designated agent of the premises shall provide and maintain such fire safety facilities and equipment in compliance with these requirements. A person shall not occupy as owner-occupant or permit another person to occupy any premises that do not comply with the requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 701, 7-8-02) 
Sec. 6-362. - Means of egress. 
(a)  General. A safe, continuous and unobstructed means of egress shall be provided. The means of egress shall be maintained continuous and unobstructed. 
    Other standards and codes. Where the following provisions conflict with O.C.G.A., Title 8, chapter 2, article 1 and O.C.G.A. Title 25, chapter 2, the provisions of this section shall not apply. Such provisions of other codes and standards, which are found to be in conflict with the code, shall become part of this code and shall be administered and enforced by the city official. 
(b)  Exit capacity. The capacity of the exits serving a floor shall be sufficient for the occupant load thereof as determined by the city official. 
(c)  Minimum number of exits. Every floor area shall be provided with the minimum number of approved independent exits as required by Table 702.3.1 based on the occupant load, except as modified in section 1004.2.1 or 1005.2.2 of the International Fire Code 2006. For the purposes of this section, occupied roofs shall be provided with exits as required for floors. The required number of exits from any story, basement or individual space shall be maintained until arrival at grade or the public way. 
Table 702.3.1 
MINIMUM NUMBER OF EXITS FOR OCCUPANT LOAD 
OCCUPANT LOAD MINIMUM NUMBER OF EXITS 1-500 2 501-1,000 3 More than 1,000 4  
Exception: A single exit is acceptable under any one (1) of the following conditions: 
(1)  Where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system and an automatic fire detection system with smoke detectors located in all corridors, lobbies and common areas. 
(2)  Where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic fire detection system and the exit is an approved smokeproof enclosure or pressurized stairway. 
(3)  Where an existing fire escape conforming to the applicable codes and standards is provided in addition to the single exit. 
(d)  Arrangement. Exits from dwelling units, rooming units, guest rooms and dormitory units shall not lead through other such units, or through toilet rooms or bathrooms. 
(e)  Exit signs. Means of egress shall be indicated with approved "EXIT" signs where required by other codes and standards. All "EXIT" signs shall be maintained visible and all illuminated "EXIT" signs shall be illuminated at all times that the building is occupied. 
(f)  Corridor enclosure. Corridors serving an occupant load greater than thirty (30) and the openings therein shall provide an effective barrier to resist the movement of smoke. All transoms, louvers, doors and other openings shall be closed or shall be self-closing. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  Corridors in occupancies, other than high hazard occupancies, which are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system. 
(2)  Corridors in educational occupancies where each room that is occupied for instruction or assembly purposes has at least one-half of the required means of egress doors opening directly to the exterior of the building at ground level. 
(3)  Corridors that are in compliance with applicable codes and standards. 
(g  Dead-end travel distance. All corridors that serve more than one (1) exit provide direct connection to such exits. The length of a dead-end corridor shall comply with the International Fire Code 2006 where the building is not equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system. 
(h)  Aisles. Arrangements of chairs or tables and chairs shall provide for ready access by aisle access ways and aisles to each egress door. The minimum clear width of each aisle in assembly and educational occupancies shall be maintained in accordance with the requirements of applicable codes and standards. In all other occupancies, aisles shall have a minimum required clear width of forty-four (44) inches (1,118 mm) where serving an occupant load greater than fifty (50), and sixty-three (36) inches (914 mm) where serving an occupant load of fifty (50) or less. The clear width of aisles shall not be obstructed by chairs, tables or other objects and shall comply with the provisions in section 1004.3 of the International Fire Code 2006. 
(i)  Stairways, handrails and guards. Every exterior and interior flight of means of egress stairs serving any building or portion thereof and having more than four (4) risers shall have a handrail on at least one (1) side of the stair. Every open portion of a stair, landing, balcony, porch, deck, ramp or other walking surface which is more than thirty (30) inches (762 mm) above the floor or grade below shall have guards. Handrails shall not be less than thirty (30) inches (762 mm) nor more that forty-two (42) inches (1,067 mm) high, measured vertically above the nosing of the tread or above the finished floor of the landing or walking surfaces. Guards shall not be less than thirty (30) inches (762 mm) high above the floor of the landing, balcony, porch, deck, ramp or other walking surface and shall comply with the provisions in section 1033.3 of the International Fire Code 2006. 
Exception: Guards are not required at any location where guards are exempted by other codes and standards. 
(j)  Stairway identification. A sign shall be provided at each floor landing in all interior stairways more than three (3) stories above grade, designating the floor level above the floor of discharge. All elevator lobby call stations on all floor levels shall be identified by approved signs in accordance with the requirements for new buildings and shall comply with the provisions of section 1003.2.10.3 of the International Fire Code 2006. 
Exception: The emergency sign shall not be required for elevators that are part of any accessible mean of egress complying with the applicable code of standard. 
(k)  Locked doors. All means of egress doors shall be readily openable from the side from which egress is to be made without the need for keys, special knowledge or effort and shall comply with the provisions in section 1003.3.1.8 of the International Fire Code 2006. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  In problem security areas, special-purpose door alarms or locking devices shall be approved prior to installation. Manually-operated edge or surface-molded flush bolts are prohibited. 
(2)  Where the door hardware conforms to that permitted by other codes and standards. 
(l)  Emergency escape. Every sleeping room located below the third story in residential and group home occupancies shall have at least one (1) openable window or exterior door approved for emergency egress or rescue; or shall have access to not less than two (2) approved independent exits and shall comply with the provisions of section 1009.1 of the International Fire Code 2006. 
Exception: Buildings equipped throughout with an automatic fire suppression system. 
(1)  Security. Bars, grilles or screens placed over emergency escape windows shall be releasable or removable from the inside without the use of a key, tool or force greater than that which is required for normal operation of the window. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 702, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1392, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 6-363. - Accumulations and storage. 
(a)  Accumulations. Rubbish, garbage or other materials shall not be stored or allowed to accumulate in stairways, passageways, doors, windows, fire escapes or other means of egress and shall comply with the provisions of section 1011.3 of the International Fire Code 2006. 
(b)  Hazardous materials. Combustible, flammable, explosive or other hazardous materials, such as paints, volatile oils and cleaning fluids, or combustible rubbish, such as wastepaper, boxes and rags, shall not be accumulated or stored unless such storage complies with the requirements of the applicable codes and standards and shall comply with the provisions of chapter 27 of the International Fire Code 2006. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 703, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1392, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 6-364. - Fire resistance ratings. 
(a)  General. The fire resistance rating of floors, walls, ceilings, and other elements and components shall be maintained and shall comply with the provisions of section 806 in the International Fire Code 2006. 
(b)  Maintenance. All required fire doors and smoke barriers shall be maintained in good working order, including all hardware necessary for the proper operation thereof. Fire doors shall not be held open by doorstops, wedges and other unapproved hold-open devices. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 704, 7-8-02; Ord. No. 07-1392, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 6-365. - Fire protection systems. 
(a)  General. All systems, devices and equipment to detect a fire, actuate an alarm, or suppress or control a fire or any combination thereof shall be properly maintained. 
(b)  Fire suppression system. Fire suppression systems shall be in proper operating condition at all times. 
(c)  Standpipe systems. Standpipe systems shall be in proper operating condition at all times. 
(d)  Fire extinguishers. All portable fire extinguishers shall be visible, provided with ready access thereto, and maintained in an efficient and safe operating condition. Extinguishers shall be of an approved type and shall comply with the provisions of sections 906.1 and 906.2 of the International Fire Code 2006. 
(e)  Smoke detectors. (Ref. O.C.G.A. § 25-2-40). Every dwelling unit within an apartment house, and every motel, hotel and dormitory constructed prior to July 1, 1987, shall have installed approved battery-operated smoke detectors which shall be maintained in good working order. Every new dwelling unit of apartment house and every motel, hotel and dormitory constructed on or after July 1, 1987, shall be provided with approved listed smoke detector's power from the building's electrical service. On or after April 1, 1992, every dwelling unit within an apartment house and every motel, hotel and dormitory shall have approved smoke detectors installed and powered from the building's electrical service and have one and one-half (11/2) hour emergency power supply source. 
(1)  Smoke detector location. Every dwelling unit in an apartment house shall have smoke detectors mounted on the ceiling or wall at a point centrally located in the corridor or area giving access to each group of rooms used for sleeping purposes. Where the dwelling unit has more than one (1) story, detectors are required on each story including cellars and basements, but not including uninhabitable attics. In dwelling units with split levels and without an intervening door between the adjacent levels, a smoke detector is required on the upper level only provided the lower level is less than one (1) full story below the upper level. Such detectors shall provide an alarm which will be audible in all sleeping areas and shall comply with the provisions of section 302.9 of the Standard Housing Code 1997. 
(2)  [Single-station or multistation smoke detector.] Every hotel, motel and dormitory shall have single-station or multistation smoke detectors installed in accordance with applicable requirements imposed under O.C.G.A. § 25-2-13. Install smoke detectors in interior corridors in existing motels, hotels and dormitories. 
Exception: Hotels, motels and dormitories which are protected throughout by approved supervised automatic sprinkler systems installed in accordance with applicable codes. 
(3)  Tampering. Anyone tampering or interfering with the effectiveness of a smoke detector shall be in violation of this Code. 
(f)  Fire alarm systems. Fire alarm systems shall be in proper operating condition at all times. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, § 705, 7-8-02) 
Secs. 6-366-6-380. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - REFERENCED STANDARDS

    This division lists the standards that are referenced in various sections of this chapter. The standards are listed herein by the promulgating agency of the standard, the standard identification, the effective date and title, and the section or sections of this chapter that reference the standard. The application of the referenced standards shall be as specified in subsection 6-252(h).

APPENDIX A. - STANDARDS FOR DEMOLITION 

A101. - Purpose and scope. 
    The standards set forth in this appendix shall apply to the demolition of buildings or structures for which a permit is required under 256(f) of the code. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, app. A, 7-8-02) 
A102. - Definition. 
    Demolition. The act of razing, dismantling or removal of a building or structure, or portion thereof to the ground level. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, app. A, 7-8-02) 
A103. - Time limit. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of the City of Fitzgerald Administrative Procedures for the Georgia State Minimum Standard Codes, the city official may impose a time limit as an additional condition of a permit for completion of demolition work once such work shall have commenced, provided that for cause one (1) or more extensions of time, for periods not exceeding thirty (30) days each, may be allowed in writing by the city official. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, app. A, 7-8-02) 
A104. - Standards. 
(a)  Demolition work having commenced shall be pursued diligently and without unreasonable interruption with due regard to safety. It is the intent of this section to limit the existence of an unsafe condition or nuisance on the premises during the period of demolition operations. 
(b)  Any surface holes or irregularities, wells, septic tanks, basements, cellars, sidewalk vaults, or coal chutes remaining after demolition of any building or structure shall be filled with material as approved by the city official, and shall be graded in such manner that will provide effective surface drainage. 
(c)  All debris and accumulation of material resulting from demolition of any building or structure shall be removed from the premises. 
(d)  All building sewers shall be effectively plugged with concrete at the property line, or as may be required by the city official. 
(e)  Except where there is adequate space, or approval has been granted by the city official, the demolition of a multistory building by other than explosive means shall proceed with the complete removal of one (1) story at a time. In the demolition of any building other than by explosive means, story after story shall be removed and shall be properly wet to alleviate any dust. 
(f)  No wall, chimney or other construction shall be allowed to fall in mass on an upper floor. Bulky material, such as beams and columns, shall be lowered and not allowed to fall. When any building over one (1) story in height is demolished, precautions for protecting the public shall be taken as prescribed in chapter 33. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, app. A, 7-8-02) 
A105. - Inspections. 
    The city official shall make or cause to make the following inspections upon notification from the permit holder or his designated agent: 
(1)  Initial Inspection. To be made after all utility connections have been disconnected and secured in such manner that no unsafe or unsanitary conditions shall exist during or remain after demolition operations. In lieu of an inspection, the department is authorized to accept an affidavit stating that all utilities have been disconnected from said building. 
(2)  Final Inspection. To be made after all demolition work is completed. 
(Ord. No. 02-1297, app. A, 7-8-02) 
Secs. 6-396-6-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 6-401. - Violation penalty-Sanitation. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-282(a) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.1), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-402. - Same-Weeds. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-282(d) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.2), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-403. - Same-Care of premises. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-282(h) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense involving a motor vehicle shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense involving a motor vehicle shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a first offense involving an appliance shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense involving an appliance shall be one hundred forty-six dollars ($146.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.3), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-404. - Same-Protective treatment. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-283(b) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be seven hundred thirty-five dollars ($735.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be one thousand four dollars ($1,004.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.4), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-405. - Same-Structural members. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-283(d) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be seven hundred thirty-five dollars ($735.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be one thousand four dollars ($1,004.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.5), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-406. - Same-Exterior walls. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-283(f) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be seven hundred thirty-five dollars ($735.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be one thousand four dollars ($1,004.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.6), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-407. - Same-Roof and drainage. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-283(g) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be seven hundred thirty-five dollars ($735.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be one thousand four dollars ($1,004.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.7), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-408. - Same-Stairways, decks, porches and balconies. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-283(k) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be four hundred forty-nine dollars ($449.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be seven hundred thirty-five dollars ($735.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.8), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-409. - Same-Windows and doorframes. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-283(n) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be two hundred seventy-one dollars ($271.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be four hundred forty-nine dollars ($449.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.9), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-410. - Same-Doors. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-283(p) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be two hundred seventy-one dollars ($271.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be four hundred forty-nine dollars ($449.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.10), 9-13-04) 
Sec. 6-411. - Same-Sanitary facilities. 
    Each violation of subsection 6-322(a) of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be seven hundred thirty-five dollars ($735.00), plus all applicable state fees. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be one thousand four dollars ($1,004.00), plus all applicable state fees. All third offenses or higher shall require a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 04-1342, § 1(901.11), 9-13-04) 
Secs. 6-412-6-420. - Reserved. 
ARTICILE XIII. - GEORGIA STATE MINIMUM STANDARD CODES 

Sec. 6-421. - Enforcement; adoption. 
(a)  It is the intent of the city to enforce the latest edition of the following Georgia State Minimum Standard Codes, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs: 
Current Codes as Adopted by DCA - Mandatory Codes: 
 International Building Code; 
 International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings; 
 International Fire Code; 
 International Plumbing Code; 
 International Mechanical Code; 
 International Fuel Gas Code; 
 National Electrical Code; 
 International Energy Conservation Code (Georgia State Minimum Standard Energy Code). 
(b)  All appendices of said codes, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, are hereby adopted by reference as though they were copied herein fully. 
(c)  The following codes, the latest edition as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, are hereby adopted by reference as though they were copied herein fully: 
Current Codes as Adopted by DCA -Permissive Codes: 
 International Property Maintenance Code; 
 International Existing Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-1405, §§ 1-3, 5-11-09) 
Sec. 6-422. - Provisions. 
    The following provisions shall be applicable with respect to the inspection of activities regulated by any code set forth herein and with respect to the enforcement thereof, and with respect to administrative procedures, except to the extent that the same is in conflict with the express provision of any code described herein: 
(1)  The city building inspector will periodically inspect the sites of activities regulated by any such code to determine if the activities are being conducted in accordance with such code. If, through inspection, it is deemed that a person engaged in such activities has failed to comply with such code or with conditions set forth in one (1) or more permits issued by the city, a written notice to comply shall be served upon that person. The notice shall set forth the measures necessary to achieve compliance and shall state the time within which such measures must be completed. If the person engaged in such activity fails to comply within the time specified, he shall be deemed in violation of the ordinance codified in this article. 
(2)  The city building inspector shall have the power to conduct such investigations as it may reasonably deem necessary to carry out duties as prescribed the ordinance codified in this article, and for this purpose to enter at reasonable times upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of investigation and inspecting the sites of activities regulated by any such code. 
(3)  No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the city who requests entry for purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials, nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while in the process of carrying out his official duties. 
(4)  Failure to obtain required permit. If any person commences any activity requiring a permit as prescribed in any such code without first obtaining said permit, the person shall be subject to revocation of his business license, work permit or other authorization for the conduct of a business and associated work activities within the jurisdictional boundaries of the city. 
(5)  Stop-work orders. Upon notice from the city or its agent, work on any project that is being done contrary to the provisions of said code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, shall be immediately stopped. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, his authorized agent or the person or persons in charge of the activity on the property, and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. Where an emergency exists, no written notice shall be required. 
(6)  Monetary penalties. Any person violating any provisions of any such code, permitting conditions, or stop-work order shall be liable for a monetary penalty not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day, by a sentence of imprisonment not exceeding sixty (60) days in jail, or both fine and jail, or work alternative. Each day during which the violation or failure or refusal to comply continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(7)  Administrative remedies. The suspension or revocation of a permit by the city upon finding that the holder is not in compliance with any code described above; or that the holder is in violation of permit conditions; or that the holder is in violation of any ordinance; shall entitle the person holding the permit to a hearing before the mayor and council of the city within thirty (30) days after receipt by the city of written notice of appeal. 
(8)  Judicial review. Any person, aggrieved by a decision or order of the city, after exhausting his administrative remedies, shall have the right to appeal de novo to the Superior Court of Ben Hill County, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 09-1405, § 4, 5-11-09) 
Chapter 7 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2; parks and recreation, Ch. 19; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Municipalities as trustee of cemetery funds and property, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-37-4, 36-37-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - General supervision by city administrator. 
    It shall be the duty of the city administrator to exercise a special care over the cemetery and to procure the services of such persons as are necessary to improve, maintain and protect the premises. 
(Code 1966, § 7-1) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 7-2. - General duties of caretaker. 
    The caretaker shall perform all duties which are usually performed by caretakers of cemeteries. 
(Code 1966, § 7-2) 
Sec. 7-3. - Caretaker to keep watch. 
    The caretaker is required to keep constant watch on the entire cemetery grounds and shall report violators or other persons interfering with the safe keeping and preservation of any property within the cemetery. 
(Code 1966, § 7-3; Ord. No. 13-1443, § 1, 9-9-13) 
Sec. 7-4. - Hours of caretaker. 
    The caretaker shall be on duty at the cemetery from the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and on Saturday and Sunday which a funeral is being conducted. He shall be required to go on duty at any other time in case of extraordinary need. 
(Code 1966, § 7-4) 
Sec. 7-5. - Approval of expenses required. 
    No expenses shall be incurred for cemetery purposes except upon the written approval of the city administrator. 
(Code 1966, § 7-5) 
Sec. 7-6. - Signing, issuance, attestation, record of deeds to lots. 
    The mayor shall sign and issue all deeds to lots in the Evergreen Cemetery, and such deed shall be attested by the city clerk who is required to enter in a permanent manner a complete record of such deeds. 
(Code 1966, § 7-6) 
Sec. 7-7. - Deeds to be drawn with reference to map. 
    All deeds to lots in Evergreen Cemetery shall be drawn with reference to the authorized map of the cemetery. 
(Code 1966, § 7-7) 
Sec. 7-8. - Payment required before deed issued. 
    No deed to a lot in Evergreen Cemetery shall be issued unless payment in full has been made. 
(Code 1966, § 7-8) 
Sec. 7-9. - Price of lots. 
    The price to be charged for deeds to cemetery lots shall be as fixed by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1966, § 7-9) 
Sec. 7-10. - Prerequisites to admitting corpse to cemetery. 
    The caretaker shall not admit any corpse into the cemetery without first requiring and taking up the required burial permit and written evidence showing that the required deed has been issued and also a receipt showing that the prescribed price for digging a grave has been paid. 
(Code 1966, § 7-10) 
Sec. 7-11. - Prerequisites to disinterring. 
    It shall be unlawful to disinter the body of any person buried in the city cemetery without first complying with all requirements of law and giving notice thereof to the city clerk. 
(Code 1966, § 7-11) 
Sec. 7-12. - Only caretaker may disinter; disinterring without permit prohibited. 
    No body shall be disinterred and removed from the cemetery except by or under the direction of the caretaker. 
(Code 1966, § 7-12) 
Sec. 7-13. - Only caretaker to dig graves; building of vaults. 
    No person shall dig a grave of any kind except the caretaker or his assistants, but any person may build a vault in connection with any grave dug by the caretaker when such vault is built under the supervision of the caretaker or city administrator. 
(Code 1966, § 7-13) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 7-14. - Charges for digging graves. 
    The charges for digging a grave shall be as prescribed by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1966, § 7-14) 
Sec. 7-15. - Minimum depth of graves. 
    No grave shall be less than four (4) feet deep. 
(Code 1966, § 7-15) 
Sec. 7-16. - Damaging cemetery property. 
    No person shall by driving upon, treading upon or otherwise mar the beauty of the ground, graves, growths or other property of the cemetery, nor in any way damage or destroy anything of ornament or of value to the cemetery grounds. 
(Code 1966, § 7-16) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 7-17. - Installation of grave markers, monuments, etc.; license and permit; penalty for violation. 
(a)  No one shall install grave markers, monuments, boundary markers or do other similar work or improvements within the cemetery without a license from the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia, and a permit from the city designated permitting official. Such license shall be obtained annually at a charge which is on file in the Office of the City Clerk for the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia, as set from time to time. Such permit shall be obtained for all work and/or improvement prior to the commencement of such work and/or improvement; said fee shall be on file in the Office of the City Clerk for the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia, as set from time to time. 
(b)  All grave markers, monuments, boundary markers and other similar work shall be installed upon good and sufficient foundations within the property lines of each particular lot. The installer shall verify the property lines prior to the commencement of any work or improvement. All construction debris shall be removed by the installer from the cemetery. 
(c)  Any person convicted of violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction may be punished by a fine in an amount not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) and imprisonment for a period not exceeding sixty (60) days for each offense, or both. Each day of operation in violation of this code section shall be deemed a separate offense. Any person convicted of violating this section shall be subject to having any licenses obtained under this chapter revoked. Said violations shall be in the jurisdiction of the Municipal Court of the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
(Code 1966, § 7-17; Ord. No. 13-1443, § 1, 9-9-13) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; garbage, trash and weeds, Ch. 12; health and sanitation, Ch. 13. 
Sec. 7-18. - Caretaker supervision for installation, work, and/or improvement. 
    No improvements shall be made to the cemetery whether permitted or unpermitted, without the supervision of the caretaker or the caretaker's designated representative. 
(Ord. No. 13-1443, § 1, 9-9-13) 
Sec. 7-19. - Grave liner installation or vault required. 
    No burial shall occur unless vault installed or approved grave liner is installed. 
(Ord. No. 13-1443, § 1, 9-9-13) 
Secs. 7-20-7-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BURIAL OF VETERANS 

Sec. 7-31. - Area set aside. 
    All of the burial lots lying, being and situated in block number ten (10) in addition number four (4) to Evergreen Cemetery of the city are hereby set aside and reserved as a burial ground for honorably discharged deceased veterans of the armed forces of the United States in an armed conflict, subject to all provisions, limitations and restrictions contained in this chapter, and such lots are hereby dedicated to such purposes. 
(Code 1966, § 7-27) 
Sec. 7-32. - Title to area retained by city. 
    The full and complete title to and the right to the control of the lots set aside for burial of veterans is hereby retained in the city and the burial of deceased veterans therein shall be a privilege only, and no person shall acquire any vested right or title to any portion of such lots, excepting only the privilege of burying a deceased veteran therein subject to the restrictions and limitations provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1966, § 7-28) 
Sec. 7-33. - Application for permit for burial; issuance, denial. 
    When the family or next of kin of any honorably deceased veteran eligible for burial in that portion of the cemetery hereby set aside shall desire the privilege of burying such deceased veteran in such burial ground, the next of kin shall make application to the city clerk for the privilege of such burial. All such applications shall be in writing, shall give such information as may be required as to the age, birthplace, service in the armed forces of the United States and the dates of such service of such deceased veterans, the kind and character of the discharge received by such deceased veteran upon the termination of his service and any other information called for or required. When required, the next of kin shall furnish proof of such service. If the city clerk shall be satisfied that such deceased veteran is entitled to such privilege of burial, he shall thereupon issue a permit for such burial and shall designate the portion of such burial ground in which such grave shall be located, which shall be entered on such permit. If the required application, the information called for and proof of service of such deceased veteran is not made and furnished, or if the city clerk is not satisfied that such deceased veteran is entitled to the privilege of such burial, no permit shall be issued. 
(Code 1966, § 7-29) 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxes and business regulations, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 7-34. - Graves to be uniform; monuments and markers. 
    All graves located in the burial ground reserved for veterans shall be uniform and all slabs placed upon headstones placed at the head of such grave shall be of granite. Slabs placed upon such graves shall come only to the level of the ground and where no slab is used the concrete shall not protrude above the level of the ground. No monuments, markers or memorials shall be erected upon or near any grave in such burial ground excepting only that a flat headstone of the type furnished by the United States of America for the graves of deceased veterans may be placed at the head of such grave. Neither the family nor next of kin of any deceased veteran buried in such burial ground shall have the right to place any other type of slab over or erect any other type of monument or headstone at the head of or near any such grave. 
(Code 1966, § 7-30) 
Sec. 7-35. - Improvements, beautification to be approved; removal of violations. 
    All improvements, plantings and beautification by private persons in the area of the cemetery reserved for burial of veterans must be approved by the city administrator. The city administrator may remove violating improvements and plantings. 
(Code 1966, § 7-31) 
Secs. 7-36-7-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EVERGREEN CEMETERY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-1283, chs. I-XII, adopted May, 14, 2001, amended article III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article III, §§ 7-51-7-63, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 1217, Chs. I-XII, adopted Aug. 12, 1996; and Ord. No. 01-1276, § 1, adopted Feb. 12, 2001. 

Sec. 7-51. - Intent. 
    It is hereby the intent of the mayor and city council in order to promote the orderly development and maintenance of the Fitzgerald Evergreen Cemetery, of the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia, that the following rules, regulations and requirements shall be adopted and shall govern all interments within the said cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. I, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-52. - Definitions. 
    The following words, phrases, sentences, etc., when used within this article shall have the following meaning(s): 
    Bronze markers means a memorial bronze casting placed flush with ground level. 
    Burial permit means that document allowing burial in the City of Fitzgerald's cemetery. Said permit shall be obtained prior to burial from a designated city department. 
    City shall mean the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
    City cemetery means that tract of land located within the city currently utilized for the burial of the dead and designated as City of Fitzgerald Evergreen Cemetery. 
    Corner marker means a marble or granite marker buried flush with the ground at the inside corner(s) of lots or gravesites, maximum size being six (6) inches by six (6) inches. 
    Gravesite means that tract of land which will accommodate the burial of one (1) individual. 
    Ground cover means the number, in inches, of soil material to be deposited over the burial vault and/or casket at ground level. 
    Installation permit means that document allowing the installation of any monument, bronze marker, corner marker, coping or any other improvement within the city cemetery. 
    Lot means that tract of land located within the cemetery containing one (1) or more gravesites. 
    Mausoleum means an aboveground structure erected for the purpose of the internment of deceased bodies. 
    Monument means a memorial structure consisting of granite, stone, marble, or other designated manmade material marking the burial site. This does not include concrete. 
    Notification of burial means that notice requested to be given the City of Fitzgerald representative of date and time of burial, by funeral director. 
    Outer burial containers means any container designed for the placement in the grave around the casket including but not limited to such containers commonly known as "burial vaults, grave boxes and grave liners". 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. I, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-53. - Lot or gravesite. 
(a)  Purchase of lot or gravesite. Any person(s) desiring to purchase a lot, gravesite or memorial site within the City of Fitzgerald Evergreen Cemetery may do so by depositing with the city the full cost of the lot, gravesite or memorial site selected. At the time of purchase, the purchaser shall be issued a receipt upon which is noted the description of the lot, gravesite or memorial site, the purchase price and the name and address of the purchaser and any other necessary information required by the city. A cemetery deed is completed with all property description and necessary information required by the city. A cemetery deed is completed with all property description and necessary information and forwarded to the purchaser. No lot(s), gravesite(s) or memorial site(s) will be reserved under any circumstance. 
    All lots within the city cemetery have been surveyed, and the number of grave spaces per lot has been established. Lots vary in size in accordance to the section of the cemetery in which the lots are located. There shall be no more burials in any one (1) lot than already designated by the city representative. 
(b)  Purchase price. The purchase price of any grave space within the City of Fitzgerald Evergreen Cemetery, upon adoption of this article, shall be as set forth by mayor and city council in form of resolution. 
(c)  Repurchase of lot or gravesite by the city. The city shall maintain a policy of repurchase or buying back gravesites and/or cemetery lots within the City of Fitzgerald Evergreen Cemetery from record holders (or their duly appointed representatives) of any such lots/gravesites. The price to repurchase or buy back any and all such lots/gravesites shall be determined by taking the average of the original purchase price of said lot/gravesite from the city and the current price for which such lot/gravesite is being offered for purchase by the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. II, 5-14-01; Ord. No. 17-1511, § 1, 12-11-17) 
Sec. 7-54. - Gravesite opening; permit required. 
(a)  Burial permit. There shall be required by any party responsible for opening any gravesite located on any lot within the cemetery, a burial permit issued by a representative of the city. The burial permit shall be obtained a minimum or twenty-four (24) hours in advance of said site opening. Said notice may be waived by the city administrator in extenuating circumstances. 
(b)  Burial permit fee. The fee charged by the city for the issuance of a burial permit to open a grave site shall be as follows: 
(1)  City residents ..... $325.00 
(2)  Non-city residents ..... $375.00 
    Under no circumstances shall any party attempt to open a grave site prior to proper identification by the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. III, 5-14-01; Ord. No. 10-1416, § 1, 5-10-10; Ord. No. 17-1511, § 2, 12-11-17) 
Sec. 7-55. - Grave opening. 
(a)  Dimensions. All gravesites shall have an opening sufficient in size to accommodate the vault. 
(b)  Ground cover. All graves shall be dug to a depth sufficient to allow a minimum ground cover of eighteen (18) inches. 
(c)  Material disposal. All excess soil removed from a gravesite shall be deposited at a site designated by the city representative. 
(d)  Soil removal methods. In no event shall the removal of excess material result in the damage to surrounding lots, nor cause ruts to develop, nor cause damage to surrounding trees, shrubbery, flowers, monuments, etc. In the event of such damage, the person, firm or corporation responsible shall pay to the City of Fitzgerald its cost of repair of such damage. 
(e)  Soil compaction. All gravesites opened shall have the soil returned to the site compacted to prevent settling of such soil after completion of the burial. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. IV, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-56. - Monuments/lot corner markers. 
(a)  Installation. There is hereby required an installation permit for the installation of any monument, bronze marker, corner marker, coping or any other improvement within the city cemetery. Only licensed monument vendors and individual private owners will be granted an installation permit. Prior to the installation any such improvements, vendors and/or owners shall obtain an installation permit at City Hall, City of Fitzgerald, 116 North Johnston Street, for the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
    All installation permits will be presented to the cemetery supervisor prior to beginning of any work on the site. The cemetery supervisor shall review all installation rules and regulations to ensure compliance with said policies. 
    All monuments shall be installed upon good and sufficient concrete foundations, minimum six-inch thickness, within the property lines of the particular lot. 
(b)  Material disposal. The removal of all excess material resulting from the installation of a monument and/or marker base shall be the responsibility of the person making such installation. In the event all such removal is not completed within five (5) working days from date of installation, the City of Fitzgerald may remove same and charge all costs therefore to the party obtaining the installation permit. 
(c)  Damage to property. The party responsible for the installation of the monument/marker base or the monument/marker shall be responsible for the cost of any damage to property incurred within the cemetery as a result of such installation(s). 
(d)  Bronze markers. The City of Fitzgerald may in its discretion designate specific locations within the cemetery wherein only bronze plaque markers will be permitted. When so done, the owners of lots or gravesites within the designated area shall not be permitted to erect monuments/markers, etc., other than those so designated. 
(e)  Corner markers. In the event the owner and/or heirs wish to designate the location of any lot or gravesite within the city cemetery with the installation of corner markers, an installation permit shall be obtained from the City of Fitzgerald. All corner markers shall be a maximum of six (6) inches by six (6) inches in size and shall be set flush with surrounding ground level on the inside corner of the lot or gravesite so marked. No burial site located in the memorial garden shall have corner markers and/or any other monument/marker than the designated bronze markers placed flushed with ground level. Other lots or gravesites within the Segraves Addition may have head stones, slabs and corner markers placed within a particular prescribed lot. No coping is allowed in any area of Segraves Addition. 
(f)  Copings. Copings shall only be allowed in the Old Site and shall be granite or marble, minimum four (4) inches by four (4) inches, smooth polished side upwardly exposed, set upon a concrete footing, a minimum of four (4) inches thick. All copings shall be set within the established gravesite boundary markers. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. V, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-57. - Mausoleum. 
    Mausoleums are allowed in the cemetery. Only marble or granite stone shall be approved as the exposed finish. No exposed brick, block or other masonry exposed finishes shall be allowed in the construction of any mausoleums. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. VI, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-58. - Memorial garden. 
(a)  Lot description. Memorial sites are located in the Segraves Addition Phase I, Block A. Lots contain two (2) memorial sites. Size of memorial sites are ten (10) feet by four (4) feet. 
(b)  Markers. Only bronze markers are allowed in the memorial garden and the marker must be flush with ground level. No monuments, head stones, corner markers, copings, etc., are allowed. The City of Fitzgerald reserves the right to remove any monuments, head stones, etc., if so erected in the memorial garden and, a cost to do such will be the responsibility of the owner of such site(s). 
(c)  Planting. No planting of any kind is allowed in the memorial garden. The City of Fitzgerald reserves the right to remove any planting in this area. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. VII, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-59. - Plantings/ground cover. 
(a)  Plantings. The owners of lots and/or gravesites within the city's cemetery shall be restricted to planting only herbaceous, annual and perennial flowers on such areas. The City of Fitzgerald reserves the right to remove, trim and maintain such as is deemed necessary. The City of Fitzgerald reserves the right to remove all cut flowers, pot plants and artificial plants that may be objectionable. No plantings of any kind are allowed in the memorial garden. 
(b)  Ground cover. Natural grass is allowed. When properly permitted, owners desiring to remove natural grass and weeds shall conform to these installation standards. Specifically, the grave space(s) inside the coping shall be covered with a concrete underslab, minimum of two (2) inches in thickness. All grave spaces shall be scored in the concrete underslab for the purpose of future grave excavation. 
    A one (1) inch minimum finish cover of No. 7, or No. 8/9, aggregate granite gravel shall be placed upon the underslab. Individual marble, granite or concrete cover slabs for each burial site may be place upon such underslab. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. VIII, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-60. - Desecration of burial site. 
    The destruction, theft or disturbance of any monument, marker or mausoleum or their defacement in any manner shall constitute a desecration of the gravesite and shall be punishable by applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. IX, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-61. - Hours open. 
    The hours during which the city cemetery shall be open to the public are hereby established as 8.00 a.m. to sunset. Any person(s) apprehended within the confines of the cemetery at any time other than the hours herein designated without approval of the City of Fitzgerald shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. X, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-62. - Non-burial-Animals. 
    The burial of animals of any nature shall not be permitted within the city cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. XI, 5-14-01) 
Sec. 7-63. - Violation. 
    Violation of the provisions of this article shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and/or imprisonment in a city or county jail for a period not to exceed five (5) days in the discretion of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 01-1283, Ch. XII, 5-14-01) 
Chapter 8 - CIVIL DEFENSE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.; operation of governing bodies during emergencies, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-54. 

Sec. 8-1. - Defined. 
    As used in this chapter, the term "civil defense" shall include measures necessary to provide for the mobilization, organization and direction of the civilian populace and necessary support agencies to prevent or minimize the effects of fire, flood, storms, earthquakes and epidemics as well as the effects of enemy or subversive activities directed against the populace, communities, industrial plants, facilities and other installations. 
(Code 1966, § 8-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions; rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-2. - Council created. 
    The Fitzgerald Council of Defense is hereby created and shall include the following: 
Mayor. 
City administrator. 
Director of civil defense (as appointed). 
Chief of police. 
Chief of fire department. 
City health officer. 
City sanitarian. 
American Red Cross representative. 
As many others as deemed necessary by the mayor and council to be appointed by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1966, § 8-2) 
State Law reference- Local organizations for emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27; local services, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-30. 
Sec. 8-3. - Duties, powers of council. 
    It shall be the duty of the council of defense and it is hereby empowered: 
(1)  To develop a city civil defense plan. This plan shall provide for the effective mobilization of all the resources of the city, both private and public. 
(2)  To prepare and recommend for consideration by the city council ordinances necessary to implement the civil defense plan. 
(Code 1966, § 8-3) 
Sec. 8-4. - Office of director created; appointment, powers, duties. 
    There is hereby created the office of the civil defense director. Such officer shall be appointed by the mayor. The civil defense director is hereby appointed: 
(1)  To represent the mayor on all matters pertaining to civil defense. 
(2)  To require and direct cooperation of all civil defense officials of the city in the preparation and implementation of civil defense plans. 
(3)  During periods of emergency to direct the services of any city officers or employees. 
(4)  To consider and recommend to the council of defense for approval mutual aid plans and agreements. 
(Code 1966, § 8-4) 
Sec. 8-5. - Composition of civil defense corps. 
    The civil defense corps shall comprise officers and employees of the city with volunteer forces enrolled to aid them during an emergency and all groups, organizations and persons who make the agreements on operation of law. They shall be charged with duties necessary for the protection of the life and property in the city during an emergency. 
(Code 1966, § 8-5) 
State Law reference- Emergency management personnel, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-34. 
Sec. 8-6. - Divisions of corps. 
    The function and duties of the civil defense corps shall be distributed among the divisions as listed below. Each division shall be under the direction of a chief and deputy chief appointed by the council of defense. The chiefs of divisions will include public officials such as sheriffs, chiefs of police and fire departments, and head of agencies dealing with transportation, communications and other sundry services as well as private businessmen who through their profession, knowledge and experience are particularly qualified to head divisions requiring specialized knowledge and experience. The divisions are established as follows: 
Law enforcement division. 
Fire services division. 
Transportation division. 
Medical and health divisions. 
Communications division. 
Welfare division. 
Information and education divisions. 
Others as determined. 
(Code 1966, § 8-6) 
Sec. 8-7. - Volunteers to serve without compensation; immunities. 
    All persons other than officers and employees of the city volunteering in service pursuant to this chapter shall serve without compensation. While engaged in such service they shall have the same immunities as persons and employees of the city performing similar duties. 
(Code 1966, § 8-7) 
Sec. 8-8. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be a misdemeanor during an emergency: 
(a)  To wilfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the civil defense corps in any enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter or in the performance of any duty imposed upon him by the virtue of this chapter. 
(b)  To do any act forbidden by any lawful rules or regulations issued pursuant to this chapter if such act is of such a nature as to give assistance to the enemy or to imperil the life or property of any inhabitant of this city, or to prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof. 
(c)  To wear or carry or display without authority any mark or identification specified by the council of defense. 
(Code 1966, § 8-8) 
Sec. 8-9. - Radiation protection for city buildings. 
(a)  Every officer, board, department, commission or agency of the city charged with the duty of preparing specifications or awarding or entering into contracts for the design, erection or construction of buildings or other structures, including additions to existing structures, for the city, shall incorporate or cause to be incorporated in such buildings or other structures, protection from radioactive fallout, for at least its normal anticipated occupancy, which shall meet or exceed the minimum space and protection criteria recommended by the Office of Civil Defense, United States Department of Defense, unless exempted from such shelter requirements in accordance with paragraph (b). 
(b)  The mayor and council may exempt buildings or other structures from the requirements of this section where it finds that the addition of fallout protection will create, in the building or other an additional net cost in excess of one (1) percent in the construction of such building, or that other factors make it unnecessary or impractical to incorporate fallout protection in the design or construction of such building or other structure. 
(c)  It shall be the policy of the mayor and council of this city that fallout shelter protection shall be incorporated into all city buildings or structures to the fullest extent practicable, in order to provide protection against the effects of radioactive fallout for the greatest possible number of people in the event of a nuclear attack upon the United States, or an accidental nuclear explosion. 
(Code 1966, § 19-17) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. 
Chapter 9 - COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Courts, generally, O.C.G.A. § 15-1-1 et seq.; administration of courts generally, O.C.G.A. § 15-5-1 et seq.; municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq.; municipal court services, O.C.G.A. § 15-7-80 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Municipal court; creation. 
(a)  There is hereby established a court to be known as the "Municipal Court of Fitzgerald" which shall have jurisdiction and authority to try offenses against laws and ordinances of said city and to punish for a violation of the same. 
(b)  This court shall have the power: 
(1)  To enforce its judgments by the imposition of such penalties as may be provided by law; 
(2)  To punish witnesses for nonattendance, and to punish also any person who may counsel or advise, aid, encourage, or persuade another whose testimony is desired or material in any proceeding before said court, to go or move beyond the reach of the process of the court; 
(3)  To try all offenses within the territorial limits of Fitzgerald constituting traffic cases which, under the laws of Georgia, are placed within the jurisdiction of municipal courts to the extent of and in accordance with the provisions of such laws and all laws subsequently enacted amendatory thereof; 
(4)  To establish bail or recognizance to ensure the presence of those charged with violations and to prescribe the conditions of forfeiture of the same; and 
(5)  To administer oaths and to perform all other acts necessary and proper to the conduct of said court. 
(c)  The presiding officer of such court shall be known as the judge of the municipal court. 
(d)  Said court shall be convened at such times as designated by ordinance or at such times as deemed necessary by the judge to keep current the dockets thereof. 
(Code 1966, § 9-1; Ord. No. 05-1361, §§ 1, 2, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 9-2. - Same-Judge. 
(a)  No person shall be qualified or eligible to serve as judge unless he shall have attained the age of twenty-one (21) years, and shall not have been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude. 
(b)  No person shall be qualified or eligible to serve as judge unless he shall be a licensed member of the Georgia State Bar, in good standing, who is also licensed to practice law in the State of Georgia. 
(c)  Neither the mayor, any member of city council, appointed officer, nor any employee of Fitzgerald shall be qualified or eligible to serve as judge. 
(d)  The mayor shall have the responsibility of making recommendations to the city council for approval of the candidates for the position of municipal court judge. The selected candidate shall serve at the discretion of the mayor and council. The compensation of the judge shall be set by the mayor and council.
