    As soon as the health officer receives notice from any physician of the existence of a case of contagious or infectious disease, he shall file such notice and keep a record of all such reported cases, recording the name, age, school attended, disease, when attacked, when recovered, the name of the attending physician and such other information as may serve as a matter of record. 
(Code 1966, § 15-48) 
Sec. 13-64. - Premises to be placarded; damaging, taking down placard. 
    Upon notification of contagious or infectious disease it shall be the duty of the health officer to at once designate the house in which the disease is located by placing conspicuously on the house a placard with the words "Contagious Disease" printed in large letters thereon. In the case of smallpox, the card shall read smallpox, and shall be of a red color and a red flag shall be nailed on the front gate or the front of the house. Any person refusing to allow such card or flag to be placed on the house so infected or who shall remove it, destroy or deface it except by order of the health officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 15-49) 
Sec. 13-65. - Quarantine authorized; disinfecting clothing, bedding, etc. 
    Immediately upon notice that any infectious or contagious disease dangerous to the public health exists in a family, the health officer shall investigate the matter and if it is found necessary he shall enforce complete isolation of the persons and their attendants and disinfect the place and all clothing, bedding, etc., of such diseased persons before they are removed from the infected house. 
(Code 1966, § 15-50) 
Sec. 13-66. - Health officer to supervise quarantine. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer to enforce strict quarantine in cases of contagious or infectious diseases which the state board of health requires to be so quarantined, following the rules of the state board of health regarding the time and manner of the quarantine. 
(Code 1966, § 15-51) 
Sec. 13-67. - When removal to hospital required; resisting removal. 
    Whenever in the opinion of the health officer the complete isolation of any person suffering from any disease cannot be obtained by any other means, such person shall be moved as expeditiously as possible under the direction of the health officer to a hospital for treatment and any person suffering from a dangerous, infectious or contagious disease or any person having the care, charge and control of such diseased person who shall refuse to comply with the provisions of this section or shall resist the enforcement thereof by proper authority, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 15-52) 
Sec. 13-68. - Permitting school attendance by diseased children. 
    No teacher in any private school nor the superintendent of the public schools in the city shall permit any pupil in whose family smallpox, chicken pox, whooping cough, scarlet fever, measles, diphtheria, yellow fever or cholera is prevailing to attend school until the health officer shall certify that there is no danger of such pupil being infected. Any teacher refusing or neglecting to obey this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 15-53) 
Sec. 13-69. - Disposal of books of diseased children. 
    Books handled by children recovering from infectious or contagious diseases must not be brought back to school but must be turned over to the health officer to be disinfected or destroyed. 
(Code 1966, § 15-54) 
Sec. 13-70. - Letting infected premises prohibited. 
    Any person who shall let to any person any house, room or part of a house in which any person has been confined with a contagious disease without first having such house, room or part of house completely disinfected to the satisfaction of the health officer, as certified by him, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 15-55) 
Sec. 13-71. - Emergency orders, rules, regulations. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer whenever in his judgment the city is threatened with or affected by an epidemic of infectious or contagious disease to issue or cause to be issued such orders, regulations and instructions as may in his judgment be effective for the prevention or removal of such disease. Such orders, rules and regulations shall be advertised in the official paper of the city for one (1) week and shall remain in force and effect until revoked by the health officer. Such rules and regulations may be modified in such manner as, in the judgment of the health officer, shall be necessary. 
(Code 1966, § 15-56) 
Secs. 13-72-13-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Food establishments generally, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-370 et seq.; standards, labeling, and adulteration of food, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-1 et seq. 

Sec. 13-86. - Health officer to inspect. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer to visit all grocery stores, restaurants, markets and any other places where foodstuffs are stored and inspect such premises generally as to the sanitary conditions under which foodstuffs and milk are stored, kept, sold or otherwise disposed of. 
(Code 1966, § 12-1) 
Sec. 13-87. - Health officer may close premises. 
    The health officer shall have power to have any market, shop or other premises handling or dispensing food closed in the event of any violation of this article if in his discretion it should be done, and such premises shall remain closed until the proprietor or operator thereof shall comply with the rules and regulations of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 12-2) 
Sec. 13-88. - Wholesomeness generally. 
    No person shall sell or offer for sale in this city any animal or part of animal that may be sickly, diseased or unwholesome or which may have died from disease or accident; or any fish, vegetables or fruit not fresh and fit for food. Upon knowledge of violation of this section any member of the police force shall report the violation to the health officer who shall cause such nuisance to be abated and the offender punished for a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1966, § 12-3) 
Sec. 13-89. - Food screened from flies. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to expose any article of food which is intended and offered for sale in a place not thoroughly screened from flies. 
(Code 1966, § 12-4) 
Sec. 13-90. - Exposing to animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to display or offer for sale any article of food in such manner as to expose it to the attention of dogs or other animals. 
(Code 1966, § 12-5) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 13-91. - Receptacles for dispensing soft drinks. 
    All persons dispensing, selling or vending soft drinks of any kind in glasses, cups, or other receptacles, other than original bottles, shall use individual sanitary or sterilized receptacles in selling and dispensing such soft drinks. 
(Code 1966, § 12-6) 
Sec. 13-92. - Receptacles for dispensing ice cream, etc. 
    All persons dispensing, selling or vending ice cream, sherbets, sundaes and other foods of like character shall use sterilized cups, saucers or receptacles to dispense and sell the foods. Such foods may be served in cones or other sanitary receptacles. 
(Code 1966, § 12-7) 
Sec. 13-93. - Receptacles for dispensing hot drinks. 
    All persons dispensing or selling hot drinks such as chocolate, bouillon or coffee and all other hot drinks of like character shall use sanitary or sterilized receptacles in dispensing and selling the drinks. 
(Code 1966, § 12-8) 
Sec. 13-94. - Sanitation of eating utensils. 
    All eating utensils furnished with foods or drinks dispensed for consumption on the premises shall be sterilized and sanitary. 
(Code 1966, § 12-9) 
Chapter 14 - HOUSING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 11; garbage, trash and weeds, Ch. 12; health and sanitation, Ch. 14; planning and development, Ch. 20; utilities, Ch. 23; subdivisions, App. A; zoning, App. B. 
State Law reference- Buildings and housing, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; fair housing, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-200 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Housing code adopted by reference, preservation of rights, liability, etc. 
(a)  The Standard Housing Code, being particularly the 1994 edition, as amended, thereof and the whole thereof, save and except such portions as may be amended, of which not less than three (3) copies have been and are now filed in the office of the city clerk. Such code is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set forth at length in this section, and the provisions therein shall be controlling in the use, maintenance and occupancy of all dwellings, dwelling units and structures within the area of jurisdiction of the city. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect any suit or proceeding now pending in any court, or any rights acquired or liability incurred, nor any cause or causes of action accrued or existing under any act or ordinance repealed hereby. Nor shall any right or remedy of any character be lost, impaired or affected by this section. 
(Code 1966, § 16-10.1; Ord. No. 1140, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 02-1296, 7-8-02) 
State Law reference- Housing code not included in state minimum standards codes after October 1, 1991, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20. 
Sec. 14-2. - Effect of conflict with other provisions. 
    In any case where a provision of this article is found to be in conflict with any other provision of any ordinances or codes of the city, the provision which establishes the higher standards for the protection and promotion of the health and safety of the people shall prevail. 
(Code 1966, § 16-11) 
Sec. 14-3. - Violations, penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or any provision of any rule or regulation adopted by the mayor and council pursuant to authority granted by this chapter shall upon conviction be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) or more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment for not less than two (2) days nor more than thirty (30) days. Each day's failure to comply with any such provision shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Code 1966, § 16-12) 
Secs. 14-4-14-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-200 et seq. 

Sec. 14-21. - Policy. 
    It is the policy of the city that no person shall be discriminated against in the sale or rental of housing on the basis of race, sex, age or national origin. 
(Code 1966, § 16-141) 
Sec. 14-22. - Discrimination in sale or rental of housing. 
    As made applicable by this article, it shall be unlawful: 
(1)  To refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide offer or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make unavailable or deny a dwelling to, any person because of race, sex, color, religion or national origin. 
(2)  To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith because of race, color, sex, religion or national origin. 
(3)  To make, print or publish or cause to be made, printed or published any notice, statement or advertisement with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination based on race, sex, color, religion or national origin, or an intention to make any such preference, limitation or discrimination. 
(4)  To represent to any person because of race, sex, color, religion or national origin that any such dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available. 
(5)  For profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person of a particular race, sex, color, religion or national origin. 
(Code 1966, § 16-142) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-202. 
Sec. 14-23. - Discrimination in the financing of housing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any bank, building and loan association, insurance company or other corporation, association, firm or enterprise whose business consists in whole or in part in the making of commercial real estate loans, to deny a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for the purpose or purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling or to discriminate against him in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance because of the race, sex, color, religion or national origin of such person or any person associated with him in connection with such loan or other financial assistance or the purpose of such loan or other financial assistance, or of the present or prospective owners, lessees, tenants or occupants of the dwellings in relation to which such loan or other financial assistance is to be made or given. 
(Code 1966, § 16-143) 
Sec. 14-24. - Discrimination in the provision of brokerage services. 
    It shall be unlawful to deny any person access to or membership or participation in any multiple listing service, real estate brokers' organization or other service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings or to discriminate against him in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation on account of race, color, religion or national origin. 
(Code 1966, § 16-144) 
Sec. 14-25. - Administration, enforcement, appeal. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the city administrator to enforce and administer this article. 
(b)  The city administrator may delegate any of his functions in the administration of this article to the city housing inspector. 
(c)  The city administrator shall investigate any complaints arising under this article and shall present his findings within thirty (30) days to municipal court. 
(d)  Within the thirty-day period, any person accused of having violated this article may appeal the finding of the city administrator before the board of housing code appeals; provided that request for appeal is presented in writing describing the specific grounds upon which the appeal is based. 
(Code 1966, § 16-145) 
Sec. 14-26. - Exclusion of property owners. 
    Nothing in this article shall be deemed to apply to individual owners of property handling only their own rental and sale of property. 
(Code 1966, § 16-146) 
Chapter 15 - LIBRARY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- City public libraries, O.C.G.A. § 20-5-20. 

Sec. 15-1. - Failure to return borrowed items; notice, penalty. 
(a)  Any person who borrows from any public library in the city any book, newspaper, magazine, manuscript, pamphlet, publication, recording, video product, microform, computer software, film or other article or equipment necessary to its display or use belonging to or in the care of such public library under any agreement to return it, and thereafter fails to return such item shall be given written notice, mailed to his last known address or delivered in person, to return such article or equipment within fifteen (15) days after the date of such notification. Such notice shall contain a copy of this section. 
(b)  If such person shall willfully and knowingly fail to return such article or equipment within the fifteen (15) days, such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisonment for not more than sixty (60) days and shall be required to return such item or provide reimbursement for the replacement cost of such item. 
(Ord. No. 1088, § 33-1, 3-10-86) 
Sec. 15-2. - Stealing property; concealing with intent, penalty. 
    Any person who, without authority and with the intention of depriving any public library located within the city of the ownership of any property, willfully conceals a book or other public library property while still on the premises of such public library, or willfully or without authority removes any book or other property from any public library shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisonment for not more than sixty (60) days and shall be required to return such book or property or provide reimbursement for the replacement cost of such book or property; provided however, that if the replacement cost of the property is less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00), the punishment shall be a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 1088, § 33-2, 3-10-86) 
Sec. 15-3. - Concealment constitutes intent. 
    Proof of the willful concealment of any book or other public library property while still on the premises of such public library shall be prima facie evidence of intent to violate section 15-2. 
(Ord. No. 1088, § 33-2, 3-10-86) 
Chapter 16 - LICENSES, TAXES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverage license, § 4-61 et seq.; building permits, § 6-20; electrician's license required, § 6-46; gas fitter's license, § 6-101; veteran burial permit, § 7-33; plumber's business license, § 6-133; taxicab permit, § 17-51 et seq. 
State Law reference- Businesses and professions generally, O.C.G.A. § 43-1-1 et seq.; revenue and taxation generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-1-1 et seq.; specific business, and occupational taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Abandoned shopping carts. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Abandoned cart or abandoned shopping cart shall mean any cart that has been removed, without the written consent of the cart owner, from the business premises or parking area of the retail/commercial establishment of which the cart owner's business premises are located and is located on either public or private property. The cart owner's business premises may include a multi-store shopping center with shared parking areas and public access. 
(2)  Abandoned cart prevention and recovery plan shall mean a protocol submitted in writing by a cart owner as set forth hereinafter that provides for a plan for the prevention of cart removal and for the recovery of carts removed from and not located on the owner's business premises. 
(3)  Business premises shall mean the interior of a cart owner's commercial establishment, adjacent walkways, any loading area, and the parking area, as herein defined. The cart owner's business premises may include a multi-store shopping center with shared parking areas and public access. 
(4)  Cart or shopping cart shall mean those pushcarts and motorized carts of the type which are commonly provided by grocery stores, drugstores, or other merchant stores or markets for the use of the public in transporting commodities in stores and markets and incidentally from the store to a place outside the store. 
(5)  Cart owner shall mean the owner or operator of a commercial establishment which provides carts for use by its customers for the purpose of transporting goods of any kind. 
(6)  Cart retrieval company or cart retrieval service shall mean a third party service in the business of retrieving and returning shopping carts to the cart owner. 
(7)  City shall mean the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
(8)  On-site cart containment and cart recovery program shall mean one (1) or more of the following measures: 
a.  Disabling devices or other system or equipment on all shopping carts which prevent them from being removed from the business premises. 
b.  An on-site security guard to deter customers from attempting to remove carts from the business premises. 
c.  Physical barriers which restrict shopping carts to the business premises (if permitted by applicable zoning regulations and fire marshal approval). 
d.  Obtaining a security deposit from customers for the use of shopping carts. 
e.  Employment and or contracting with a cart retrieval company or cart retrieval service for recovery of abandoned carts in accordance with the recovery requirements set forth hereinafter. 
(9)  Parking area shall mean a parking lot or other property provided by a business for use by a customer for parking an automobile or other vehicle. In a multi-store complex or shopping center such area shall include the entire parking lot used by or controlled by the complex or center. 
(b)  Unlawful possession or abandonment of carts. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove a shopping cart from the business premises of a business or commercial establishment without the consent, given at the time of such removal, of the cart owner or of his or her agent, servant, or employee. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon a shopping cart upon any public street, sidewalk, way, or parking lot other than the business premises of the cart owner. 
(3)  Any persons violating a provision of this section shall be tried in the municipal court of the city and, upon conviction, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or one (1) year in jail. 
(c)  Cart owner/business requirements. 
(1)  Cart identification required. All carts must have a permanently affixed sign identifying the owner of the cart. 
(2)  Daily cart retrieval. All cart owners shall retrieve all carts daily to ensure all such carts are secure after the close of business. 
(3)  Abandoned cart prevention and recovery plan. Every cart owner of more than twenty-five (25) carts shall develop, implement and comply with the terms and conditions of an abandoned cart prevention and recovery plan. Such plan shall be submitted to the office of the city administrator in writing on a renewable annual basis and shall include the following elements: 
a.  Name and information of business/cart owner. The name of the owner and the business, the physical address of the location of the business and the name, address and telephone number where all notices and/or citations are to be sent. 
b.  Number of carts owned. 
c.  Signs. Signs shall be posted prominently and conspicuously at all entrances and exits to the cart owner's business premises, including the parking areas. Such signs shall provide notice at a minimum containing the following information: "Removal of Shopping Carts is prohibited by State Law and Local Ordinance and will subject the Violator to a maximum fine of $1,000.00 and/or One (1) year in jail." 
d.  Physical containment system and/or cart recovery agreement. Every cart owner shall provide a description of the specific measures the cart owner shall implement to prevent cart removal from the business premises which meet the requirements set forth hereinbefore and/or the proof of contract/agreement with a cart retrieval company or cart retrieval service as contemplated hereinbefore. 
(4)  Violations. Violation of any provision of this subsection is a violation of this article and the city may pursue any available remedy provided under the Code of Ordinances of the City of Fitzgerald, including, but not limited to, a fine up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) per month. 
(d)  City retrieval of carts. 
(1)  The city may retrieve an abandoned cart from public property (or private property with the consent of the property owner or tenant) in the following circumstances: 
a.  Where the location of the shopping cart will impede emergency services. 
b.  When the abandoned cart does not identify the cart owner as required by this section. 
c.  When the city has contacted the cart owner and provided notice of the abandoned cart and said cart has not been reclaimed within three (3) business days. 
(e)  Enforcement and remedies. 
(1)  Any cart owner that fails to retrieve its abandoned cart within three (3) business days after receiving notice from the city, shall pay the city's administrative costs for retrieving the cart and providing the notification to the cart owner. Any cart owner who fails to retrieve abandoned carts in accordance with this Code section in excess of three (3) times during any six-month period shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) in addition to the aforementioned costs for each occurrence thereafter. 
(2)  If a cart is not retrieved by the cart owner within thirty (30) days after notice of retrieval by the city has been sent to the cart owner, including the payment of all costs and fines, or if the cart owner cannot be determined, the cart may be sold, destroyed, or otherwise disposed of in the city's discretion. 
(Ord. No. 17-1499, § 1, 5-8-17) 
Secs. 16-2-16-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIFE INSURANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) ---

Sec. 16-16. - Insurer license fees. 
    There is hereby levied for the year 1994 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the City of Fitzgerald in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by section 16-17 which is operating on behalf of insurers within the City of Fitzgerald, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). For the purposes of this ordinance, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. section 33-3-5. 
(Ord. No. 1179, § 1, 1-10-94)

Sec. 16-17. - License fee for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations.

ARTICLE III. - POOLROOMS AND BILLIARD HALLS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Operators of billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 16-36. - Compliance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain, conduct or operate a pool or billiard room within the city, in which room pool or billiard tables are kept for the playing of pool and billiards, unless such person shall comply with the conditions of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 24-1) 
Sec. 16-37. - Application for license required, contents. 
    An application in writing shall be made to the mayor and council for a license to keep, maintain, operate and conduct a pool or billiard room. Such application must be signed by the party applying for such license and must contain the following: 
(1)  The place where the room is to be conducted or operated. 
(2)  The number of pool or billiard tables that are to be used in the pool or billiard room. 
(3)  An agreement by the applicant that he will keep a decent and orderly place and that there will be no screens, partitions or divisions of any kind by which one passing along the front of such place of business will be prevented from having a full, free and unobstructed view of the entire interior of such place and everyone therein. 
(4)  An agreement by the applicant that such place of business shall not be opened at all on Sundays and that no one will be allowed to enter the place of business or play any games therein or remain therein after the closing time. 
(Code 1966, § 24-2) 
State Law reference- City license required, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-4. 
Sec. 16-38. - Investigation of applicant. 
    When a pool and billiard room license application has been made and duly filed, and before it will be granted by the license committee, the license committee shall conduct or cause to be conducted a full investigation of the reputation and character of the person so applying. 
(Code 1966, § 24-3) 
Sec. 16-39. - Issuance of license; fee. 
    If the application for license required by this article is approved by the license committee, the city clerk is authorized to issue a license to the applicant upon the payment to him of the license fee required by the business license ordinance, authorizing and granting the right of the applicant to keep, maintain, operate and conduct a pool or billiard room. 
(Code 1966, § 24-4) 
State Law reference- Municipal license fee authorized, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-6. 
Sec. 16-40. - Acts prohibited. 
    Any person who has obtained a license by complying with all of the requirements of this article and who thereafter fails to comply with the terms of the application by: 
(1)  Failure to keep out of such place of business any and all screens, partitions, divisions or other things that prevent or attempt to prevent a full, free and unobstructed view of the entire room in which the business is carried on; or 
(2)  Opening before the time specified; or 
(3)  Failing to close such place of business at the time specified; or 
(4)  Conducting the place of business in such a way and manner as to annoy the neighbors; or 
(5)  Permitting the place of business to become disorderly; or 
(6)  Permitting minors to enter the place of business, either for the purpose of playing pool or billiards, or otherwise; 
Shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and the mayor and council shall have the right to revoke the license. 
(Code 1966, § 24-5) 
State Law reference- Authority for local regulation of billiard rooms; and limitations on local ordinances restricting hours of operation and sale of alcoholic beverages in billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-2. 
Sec. 16-41. - Guardian permitting minor in poolroom. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person having custody or control of any minor knowingly to permit such child or minor to enter or frequent any billiard hall or poolroom. 
(Code 1966, § 24-6) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 16-42. - Revocation of license for liquor in prohibited areas. 
    If any person shall be convicted in any of the courts of this state for possessing, having, controlling or selling any liquors prohibited by law in such place of business, the mayor and council shall have the right to revoke the license so issued. 
(Code 1966, § 24-8) 
Secs. 16-43-16-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PRECIOUS METALS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate and license dealers in precious metals or gems, O.C.G.A. § 43-37-5. 

Sec. 16-61. - Definition. 
    "Gold or silver buyers" shall mean, as used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires, any person engaged in the business of purchasing or otherwise dealing in gold or silver or other precious metals of any kind or description from members of the general public within the corporate limits of the city. Included in this definition are buyers of secondhand jewelry and gems. Isolated transactions between persons not engaged in the business are not covered by the terms of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 19-46) 
Sec. 16-62. - Affected with the public interest. 
    Engaging in the business of buying gold, silver, other precious metals, precious gems or jewelry within the corporate limits of the city is hereby declared to be affected with the public interest because of the opportunity it affords for the disposal of stolen property. 
(Code 1966, § 19-47) 
Sec. 16-63. - Registration required. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and an offense punishable as provided in section 1-8, to engage in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry from members of the general public within the corporate limits of the city without first complying with the registration and other provisions of this article and obtaining a license as provided in this article. Each day such offense occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1966, § 19-48) 
Sec. 16-64. - Advertising without compliance prohibited; penalty. 
    No person, partnership, corporation or other entity covered by this article shall advertise, either in the news media or on portable signs or in any other manner, the buying, selling, trading or otherwise dealing in precious metals, precious gems or jewelry until they have complied with the provisions of this article. The violation of this section shall be unlawful and an offense punishable as provided in section 1-8, and each day such violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1966, § 19-49) 
Cross reference- Advertising, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 16-65. - Registration with police chief; required information. 
(a)  All persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities engaging in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry shall register with the police chief on a form to be provided by the police chief. 
(b)  All applicants for registration under the provisions of this article shall furnish, in addition to such other information as the police chief shall require, the following information: 
(1)  Name of the applicant; 
(2)  Permanent address and local address of the applicant; 
(3)  If the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of each member of the partnership; 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of each stockholder, each officer, and each director of the corporation; 
(5)  The name and address of each employee of the applicant who is actively engaged in the performance of such services; or 
(6)  If a resident, the length of time the applicant has been a resident of the state and the city. 
(Code 1966, § 19-50) 
Sec. 16-66. - Conviction of felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
    No person shall engage in the business or activity for which the license pursuant to this article is required, or shall be a member of a partnership, or an officer, stockholder or director in a corporation engaged in such business, who shall have been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(Code 1966, § 19-51) 
Sec. 16-67. - Investigation of applicant; issuance of license; fee. 
    Within five (5) days after receipt of an application as provided for in this article, the police chief shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and his proposed operation. If upon investigation the police chief shall find that the applicant is of good moral character and has never been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, and has met all of the requirements of this article, he shall approve the issuance of a license to the applicant. The license shall be issued by the city clerk and a charge shall be paid by the licensee for such license which amount is on file in the city clerk's office as set from time to time. 
(Code 1966, § 19-52) 
Sec. 16-68. - Notice to law enforcement agencies. 
    If the license required by this article is approved, the applicant shall file a notice with all law enforcement agencies of the county and city within fifteen (15) days after approval. 
(Code 1966, § 19-53) 
Sec. 16-69. - Register to be kept; required information. 
    Every licensee under this article shall keep a register upon which the licensee shall record the name, address, social security number or driver's license number, a brief description and other identification of every person from whom the licensee purchases any precious metals, precious gems or jewelry, together with the date and time of day of such purchase, a description of each article purchased, including the name, make and serial or other identifying number or mark, and the amount paid therefor. Such entry shall be made at the time the transaction occurs. Before buying any precious metals, precious gems or jewelry, the licensee shall require positive identification from the seller, either from a driver's license or other document. 
(Code 1966, § 19-54) 
Sec. 16-70. - Daily reports; duty of police chief; penalty for violation. 
    Each licensee under this article shall file daily written reports at 10:00 a.m. with the police chief showing the name and description of the persons from whom precious metals, precious gems or jewelry were purchased by the licensee during the preceding twenty-four (24) hours, and a description in detail of the nature, type and quantity of the precious metals, precious gems or jewelry. It is hereby made the duty of the police chief to obtain such reports promptly each day. It shall be unlawful and an offense punishable as provided in section 1-8 for any licensee to fail or refuse to make such daily report in the manner described by this section and such failure shall be a ground for the revocation of the license. 
(Code 1966, § 19-55) 
Sec. 16-71. - Alteration or disposal of precious metals, gems, jewelry. 
    No articles of personal property made of gold, silver or other precious metals or precious gems or jewelry shall be sold, melted, altered or otherwise disposed of by any secondhand dealer until ten (10) days have elapsed from the time the police chief has been given a copy or transcript of the register in which such articles of personal property made of gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals or gems or jewelry are entered, and such articles shall not be transferred from within the city limits during the ten-day period. 
(Code 1966, § 19-56) 
Sec. 16-72. - License not transferable. 
    Licenses issued under this article shall not be transferred. 
(Code 1966, § 19-57) 
Sec. 16-73. - Surrender of stolen items. 
    If it is determined that any item covered by this article is the subject of any theft, embezzlement or other crime, the licensee shall surrender the item upon demand to the owner or the police chief. 
(Code 1966, § 19-58) 
Sec. 16-74. - Purchase from minors prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful and punishable as provided in section 1-8 for any person, partnership, corporation or other entity engaged in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry to purchase any of such items from a person less than eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Code 1966, § 19-59) 
Sec. 16-75. - Revocation or suspension of license. 
    Licenses issued pursuant to this article shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the city administrator upon recommendation of the police chief for the violation of or the failure to comply with any provision of this article or for the violation of any provision of law, after reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard has been given the licensee. The city administrator shall immediately notify any licensee of such suspension or revocation. 
(Code 1966, § 19-60) 
Secs. 16-76-16-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TAXATION[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; malt beverages excise tax, § 4-40. 
State Law reference- Municipal taxation generally, Ga. Const. Arts. IX, IV; revenue and taxation generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-1-1 et seq.; municipal ad valorem taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-91. - Advertising real estate for tax sale; when, where, by whom made. 
    All sales of real estate for city taxes shall be advertised for four (4) successive weeks in the official paper of the city next preceding the sale, which shall always be on the first Tuesday of the month. The advertisement shall be signed by the police chief and the sales shall be conducted by him at the front door of the city hall in the city. 
(Code 1966, § 28-1) 
Sec. 16-92. - Entry and record of fieri faci; costs and fees; execution not to issue on property for which city holds deed. 
    The police chief shall make an entry on the back of each fieri facias as soon as collected, showing the amount of tax collected and also an itemized statement of the cost, which costs shall be the same as is allowed sheriffs for like services. He shall charge the same fees for selling, making titles and an advertising fee in conformity with the successful bidder for the official paper for the advertising. He shall turn over these costs and taxes each day to the city treasurer, together with all money derived from the sale of any property for taxes, taking his receipt therefor. No execution shall be issued or levied on any property for which the city holds a tax or other deed. 
(Code 1966, § 28-2) 
Sec. 16-93. - Sale of personal property for taxes. 
    All sales of personal property for taxes shall be made at the front door of the city hall in the manner provided by law for such sales for state and county taxes, but all such sales shall be conducted by the police chief. 
(Code 1966, § 28-3) 
Sec. 16-94. - Excise tax on rooms, lodgings and accommodations. 
(a)  The city shall levy, impose and collect, pursuant to the authority set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51, an excise tax upon the activities described in such statute, other than the activities that such statute exempts from its provisions. 
(b)  The rate of such tax shall be five (5) percent of the charge to the public for furnishing of such room or rooms, lodgings or accommodations. 
(c)  In each fiscal year in which such tax is collected, the city shall make expenditures of its revenues at the levels and for the purposes required by such statute as a condition for the authority to impose such tax. 
(Ord. No. 1185, §§ 1-3, 8-22-94) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1185, adopted August 22, 1994, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification of §§ 1-3 as § 16-94 was at the discretion of the editor. 
State Law reference- Authority for local taxation of rooms, lodgings, and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 
Secs. 16-95-16-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority for municipal taxation of financial institutions, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 

Sec. 16-106. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this division "gross receipts" shall mean the total amount of revenue generated from the sources itemized in section 16-108 during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax imposed by this division is due. 
(Ord. No. 1061, § 2, 9-12-83) 
Sec. 16-107. - Business license tax. 
    Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is hereby levied for the year 1984 and for each year thereafter an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations, state building and loan associations, a business license tax at the rate of twenty-five (25) percent of the gross receipts of such institutions. Notwithstanding any other provision of this division, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institutions pursuant to this division shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year. 
(Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 9-12-83) 
Sec. 16-108. - Criteria for calculating gross receipts. 
(a)  Banks. Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to banks are as follows: 
(1)  Interest and fees on loans, less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others; 
(2)  Interest on balances with other depository financial institutions; 
(3)  Interest on federal or correspondent funds sold and securities purchased under agreements of resale; 
(4)  Interest on other bonds, notes and debentures, excluding interest on obligations in the state or its political subdivisions and obligations on the United States; 
(5)  Dividends on stocks; 
(6)  Income from direct lease financing; 
(7)  Income from fiduciary activities; 
(8)  Service charges on deposit accounts; 
(9)  Other service charges, commissions and fees; and 
(10)  Other income. 
(b)  Savings and loan associations. Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to savings and loan associations are as follows: 
(1)  Interest on mortgage loans less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold in service for others; 
(2)  Interest on mortgages, participations or mortgage-backed securities; 
(3)  Interest on real estate sold on contract; 
(4)  Discounts on mortgage loans purchased; 
(5)  Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; 
(6)  Interest and dividends on investments and deposits; 
(7)  Loan fees; 
(8)  Loan servicing fees; 
(9)  Other fees and charges; 
(10)  Gross income from real estate owned operations; 
(11)  Net income from office building operations; 
(12)  Gross income from real estate held for investment; 
(13)  Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries; 
(14)  Miscellaneous operating income; 
(15)  Profit on sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans and other assets; and 
(16)  Miscellaneous nonoperating income. 
(c)  Deductions. The following items shall be deducted from gross receipts calculated pursuant to subsection (a) or (b): 
(1)  An amount equal to the amount of interest paid on all liabilities for the period; 
(2)  An amount equal to income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 7-1-5(a); 
(3)  An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons or entities located outside of the United States, its territories or possessions; 
(4)  An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than Georgia; and 
(5)  To the extent that any deductions are made pursuant to subparagraphs (2), (3), and (4) of this subsection, any deductions taken under subparagraph (1) of this subsection shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in subparagraphs (2) through (4) of this subsection bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to subparagraphs (1) through (4) above. 
(Ord. No. 1061, § 2, 9-12-83) 
Sec. 16-109. - Due date, filing of return. 
    Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March first of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. Such returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this division shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in such return. 
(Ord. No. 1061, § 3, 9-12-83) 
Secs. 16-110-16-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OCCUPATION TAXES AND REGULATORY FEES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1222, adopted December 9, 1996, amended §§ 16-201-16-227 in their entirety to read as herein set out. Prior to such amendment, said sections contained similar provisions and derived from Ord. No. 1196, adopted December 12, 1994; Ord. No. 1209, adopted December 11, 1995; and Ord. No. 1211, § 1, adopted March 11, 1996 
State Law reference- Taxation of businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations in the municipality, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-6; taxation of businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with no location in state, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7; municipal licensing and taxation of businesses, trades, and professions licensed by state, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-18; limitations on impositions of regulatory fees by municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9; limitations on levy of employment taxes by municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-19. 

Sec. 16-201. - Occupation tax required. 
    For the year 1995 and succeeding years thereafter, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city, whether with a location in the city or, in the case of an out-of-state business, with no location in the state exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for such business, trade, profession, or occupation, which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a fixed business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no fixed business location in the city such business tax registration shall be shown to the city administrator or the officer's deputies or to any police officer of the city, upon request. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96). 
Sec. 16-202. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the term: 
    Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
    City or county means the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
    Dominant line means the type of business, within a multiple-line business, which is the major and principal source of income of such business. 
    Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual, for purposes of documenting compensation, a form I.R.S. W-2, but not a form I.R.S. 1099. 
    Gross receipts means: 
(1)  The total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including without limitation, the following: 
a.  Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; 
b.  Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets, or instruments of indebtedness; 
c.  Proceeds from commissions on the sale of property, goods, or services; 
d.  Proceeds from fees for services rendered; and 
e.  Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty, or dividend income. 
(2)  Shall not include the following: 
a.  Sales, use, or excise tax; 
b.  Sales returns, allowances, and discounts; 
c.  Interorganizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations, as defined by 26 U.S.C. section 1563 (a)(1), or between or among the units of a brother-sister controlled group of corporations, as defined by 26 U.S.C. section 1563 (a)(2), or between or among wholly owned partnerships or other wholly owned entities; 
d.  Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent; 
e.  Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions, or the interest income derived from such funds received by a nonprofit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this article, if such funds constitute eighty (80) percent or more of the organization's receipts; and 
f.  Proceeds from sales to customers outside the state. 
    Location or office means and include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. 
    Occupation tax means a tax levied by a local government on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue-raising purposes. 
    Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8) or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. 
    Person means and shall be held to include sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits, or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes all nonprofit organizations. 
    Practitioner of profession or occupation means one who, by state law, requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation as designated by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 (c), but shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-203. - Administrative and regulatory fee structure. 
(a)  A regulatory fee will be imposed as provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 on those applicable businesses. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. 
(b)  The regulatory fee schedule for persons in the following occupations and professions is set forth [as prescribed by city council:] 
(1)  Building and construction contractors, subcontractors and workers, and monument sales. 
(2)  Carnivals or circuses. 
(3)  Taxicab and limousine operators. 
(4)  Tattoo artist. 
(5)  Shooting galleries and firearm ranges. 
(6)  Scrap metal processors. 
(7)  Pawnbrokers. 
(8)  Dealers in precious metals. 
(9)  Firearms dealers. 
(10)  Peddlers (to be approved and fee set by administrator). 
(11)  Modeling agencies. 
(12)  Auto and motorcycle racing. 
(13)  Business which provides appearance bonds. 
(14)  Boxing and wrestling promoters. 
(15)  Hypnotists. 
(16)  Handwriting analysts. 
(17)  Health clubs, gyms and spas. 
(18)  Fortunetellers. 
(19)  Garbage collectors. 
(20)  Escort services. 
(21)  Burglar and fire alarm installers. 
(22)  Locksmiths. 
(23)  Flea markets. 
(24)  Nonresident dealers in new motor vehicles at temporary sites, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-2-39, for a permit to do business at such temporary site for a period not to exceed ninety-six (96) hours in any one-month period of time; provided, that no such dealer shall be entitled to purchase such a permit more than three (3) times in any calendar year. 
(25)  Every other business and practitioner of a profession or occupation included within the scope of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(a) or (b), and not specifically described above, shall pay an annual regulatory fee in an amount to be determined by the city administrator, taking into account those permissible factors referred to in such O.C.G.A. section. Should the business or practitioner object to the amount so set, it shall have the right to appeal the amount of such fee to the mayor and council of the city upon ten (10) days' notice of the date, time and place of such hearing. Such person and the administrator shall have the right to be heard on such terms as such mayor and council shall reasonably determine. The decision of the mayor and council as to the amount of such fee shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-204. - Occupation tax levied; structure. 
(a)  An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one (1) or more locations or offices in the corporate limits of the city and/or upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, based upon the number of employees of the business or practitioner engaged in substantial efforts in the state. 
(b)  Occupation tax schedule. The tax rate determined by the number of employees for each business, trade, profession, or occupation is as [prescribed by the city council] and will be developed and updated from time to time by the city administrator. 
(c)  No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one (1) occupation tax for each of its locations. No occupation tax shall be required from those real estate brokers, real estate agents, or real estate companies whose offices are located outside the city and who sell property inside the city. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-205. - Businesses with no in-state location; exemption. 
(a)  Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business's largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the city and the business or practitioner: 
(1)  Has one (1) or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(b)  Any business or practitioner of a profession with no location or office in the state shall be exempt from assessment of an occupation tax under this article if such business or practitioner submits proof of payment of a local business or occupation tax in another state on the business's or practitioner's sales or services in the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-206. - Identification of dominant lines of business. 
    The business registration of each business operated in the city shall identify the dominant line of business that the business conducts. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-207. - Businesses at more than one location considered separate. 
    Where a person conducts business at more than one (1) fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of an occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-208. - Professionals classified in O.C.G.A. section 48-13-9(c). 
(a)  Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 (c)(1) through (18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one (1) of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on the number of employees as set forth in section 16-204 of this article. 
(2)  A fee schedule per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service from the following schedule, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner paying according to this paragraph shall not be required to provide information to the city relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. 
(b)  This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by February 15 of each year. 
(c)  A business through which one (1) or more practitioners of professions practice their profession, either directly or indirectly through a partnership, professional corporation or association, or other similar entity, shall not be liable for a separate occupation tax or fee, if all such professionals pay the tax imposed by this section. 
(d)  The professions that are governed by this section include: 
(1)  Lawyers. 
(2)  Physicians licensed under O.C.G.A., title 43, chapter 34. 
(3)  Osteopaths licensed under O.C.G.A., title 43, chapter 34. 
(4)  Chiropractors. 
(5)  Podiatrists. 
(6)  Dentists. 
(7)  Optometrists. 
(8)  Psychologists. 
(9)  Veterinarians. 
(10)  Landscape architects. 
(11)  Land surveyors. 
(12)  Practitioners of physiotherapy. 
(13)  Public accountants. 
(14)  Embalmers. 
(15)  Funeral directors. 
(16)  Civil, mechanical, hydraulic, or electrical engineers. 
(17)  Architects. 
(18)  Marriage and family therapists, social workers, and professional counselors. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-209. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for government. 
    Any practitioner whose office is maintained by, and who is employed in practice exclusively by, the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-210. - Purpose and scope of tax. 
    The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 through 48-13-28. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-211. - Payment; delinquency. 
(a)  Each and every person required to pay an occupation tax or regulator fee by this article shall complete and file with the city clerk on or before November 15 of each year, an occupation tax/regulatory fee registration on forms furnished by the city clerk for such purpose. 
(b)  Each such occupation tax and regulatory fee shall be for the calendar year 1995 and succeeding calendar years thereafter unless otherwise specifically provided. Such regulatory fee and occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by February 15 of each year, be subject to penalties for delinquency as prescribed in this article. On any new profession, trade, or calling begun in the city in 1995 or succeeding years thereafter, the registration and tax or regulatory fee shall be delinquent if not obtained immediately upon beginning business and a ten (10) percent penalty imposed. The tax or fee registration herein provided for shall be issued by the city administrator; and if any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after such registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the city, any of the kind of profession, trade, or calling subject to this article without having first obtained such registration, such offender shall, upon conviction by the mayor's court for the city, be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), or imprisonment not to exceed five (5) days, either or both in the discretion of the judge of such court. 
(c)  In the case of a business subject to occupation tax for a calendar year, which was not conducted for any period of time in the corporate limits of the city in the preceding year, the owner, proprietor, manager, or executive officer of the business liable for occupation tax shall estimate the number of employees from commencing date to the end of the calendar year. The occupation tax for any business registering and opening for business after July 1 shall be fifty (50) percent of the tax that would be otherwise applicable for that year only. 
(d)  In addition to the above remedies, the chief of police of the city may proceed to collect such tax in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-212. - Nonprofit organization. 
    Any nonprofit organization shall be exempt from the levy of occupation tax under this article. 
Sec. 16-213. - Evidence of state registration. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the secretary of state pursuant to O.C.G.A., Title 43 shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city registration may be issued. 
(b)  Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-214. - Evidence of qualification. 
    Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory requirement shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-215. - Inspectors with subpoena and arrest powers. 
    The city administrator and its duly designated officer and inspectors or its successors shall be classified as deputy marshal-business inspectors with full subpoena and arrest powers in conjunction with any violation pertaining to the business tax ordinance for 1995 (this law) and succeeding years. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-216. - Businesses not covered by article. 
    The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by local law: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission. 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under Chapter 3 of Title 46 of O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355 (businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls). 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-217. - Multiple locations or lines. 
    Where a business is operated at more than one (1) place or where the business includes more than one (1) line, such business will pay an occupation tax in accordance with the prevailing taxing method and tax rate for the dominant line at each location. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-218. - Inspections of books and records. 
    In any case, the city administrator, through its officers, agents, employees, or representatives, may inspect the books of the business for which the returns are made. The city administrator shall have the right to inspect the books or records for the business of which the return was made in the city; and, upon demand of the city administrator, such books or records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within thirty (30) days. Failure of submission of such books or records within thirty (30) days shall be grounds for revocation of the tax registration currently existing to do business in the city. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the city administrator at that officer's discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of underreporting, a penalty of one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the prime interest rate times the amount deficient will be assessed for the period delinquent. For purposes of this section, the prime interest rate shall be that which is published by The Wall Street Journal on the first business day of the year in which the underreporting is identified. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-219. - Revocation of tax registration for failure to pay. 
    Upon the failure of any business to pay such occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of such returns within the time required herein, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as above provided, any business tax registration granted by the city under this article permitting the owner of such business to do business for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax registration shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax herein provided for is at that time unpaid, or to an individual, form, or corporation who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the city administrator in accordance with provisions found in section 16-218. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-220. - Lien taken for delinquent tax. 
    In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, the city administrator, upon any tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of such tax against the persons, partnership, or corporation liable for such tax, which such execution shall bear interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover the property (in the city) of the person, partnership, or corporation liable for such tax, all as provided by the ordinances and charter of such city and the laws of the state. The lien of such occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the chief of police of the city upon the property of the defendant located in such jurisdiction, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of such execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as is provided by the ordinances and charter of the city and the laws of the state, and the defendant in such execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the city administrator against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full, together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due him or her as though he or she had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-221. - Registration required; liability of officers and agents; penalties for failure to obtain. 
    All persons subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this article shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for such business as described in this article, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. Every person intending to commence business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration herein provided for before commencing the same; and any person transacting or offering to transact in the city any of the kinds of business, trade, profession, or occupation that require registration without first having so obtained such registration shall be subject to penalties provided therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-222. - Amendment or repeal. 
    This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the mayor and council of the city to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Such amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the jurisdiction of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-223. - Applications to prior ordinance. 
    This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. Any and all parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed that provide for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that impose fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in such ordinance or ordinances, or for failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-224. - Enforcement. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the city administrator and police department to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the court. It is hereby made the further duty of the city administrator to inspect all registrations issued by the city, as often as, in its judgment, it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-225. - Full force and effect. 
    This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the mayor and council of the city. All provisions hereto relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-226. - Public hearing before tax increase. 
    After January 1, 1996, the mayor and council of the city shall conduct at least one (1) public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-227. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in occupation tax. 
    The mayor and council of the city may, by subsequent ordinance or resolution, provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one (1) or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the mayor and council of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 16-228. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
    Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-96) 
Secs. 16-229-16-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-1486, §§ 1-8, adopted September 12, 2016, amended article VII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article VII, §§ 16-251-16-254, pertained to similar material, and derived from Ord. No. 01-1279, adopted December 12, 2001. 
State Law reference- Regulation of peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; Georgia Charitable Solicitations Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq. 

Sec. 16-251. - Definitions 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include words in the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    City means the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
    County means the unincorporated area of Ben Hill County, Georgia. 
    Licensed solicitor means and includes any person who has obtained a valid permit as provided for in this article and such person is in compliance with all requirements as set forth in this article. 
    Police department means the police department for the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
    Residence means and includes every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one (1) or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. 
    Soliciting means and includes any one (1) or more of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, and/or services, of any kind, character or description whatsoever, for any form of consideration whatsoever; 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any kind, type or publication; or 
(3)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers, and/or publications of any form whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 16-1486, § 1, 9-12-16) 
Sec. 16-252. - Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business or action of soliciting, selling, canvassing, survey-making or any other business, occupation or vocation which by its nature requires such person to call on residences door-to-door or house-to-house without first having obtained a permit in accordance with the provisions contained in this article. 
(b)  The requirement of subsection (a) hereinbefore is meant to apply to door-to-door solicitations for commercial transactions for profit only. 
(1)  This article is not meant to regulate solicitation for charitable, political, or other non-profit purposes provided that all sales proceeds of any sales by a non-profit organization are the sole property of the non-profit organization and for the sole use of said non-profit organization. 
(2)  This article shall not apply to officers or employees of the city, county, State of Georgia, or United States of America, or any subdivisions thereof, when on official business. 
(Ord. No. 16-1486, § 2, 9-12-16) 
Sec. 16-253. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Application for a permit shall be made upon a form provided by the city and such application shall be available upon request. The application shall be verified and made under oath stating in full all information requested in such application. 
(b)  The applicant shall submit to fingerprinting and criminal background investigation by the Ben Hill County Sheriff's Department as part of such application process. 
(c)  The applicant shall be required to pay a non-refundable application fee which shall include the costs of such required criminal background investigation. 
(Ord. No. 16-1486, § 3, 9-12-16) 
Sec. 16-254. - Issuance or denial of permit. 
(a)  Upon satisfactory review of the application and background investigation by the clerk of the city such applicant shall be eligible for issuance of a permit. Upon the approval of such applicant, the applicant shall obtain a business license and pay the required license fee. Such license and fee must be acquired and paid prior to the issuance of such permit. All permits shall be issued for the term of three (3) months from the date of issue. Permits are non-transferrable. 
(b)  The issuance or denial of a permit under this chapter shall be based upon consideration of the public welfare, peace, safety, health, good order and convenience of the city and the citizens of the city. 
(c)  No permit shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of a misdemeanor involving violence, a felony, or crime of moral turpitude within five (5) years of the date of the application; nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter; nor to any person whose permit issued hereunder has previously been revoked as provided for herein.
