For purposes of this section, the term "convicted" shall include verdicts or pleas of guilty or nolo contendre, entered by a court of this state, any other state, or any federal court. 
(d)  In any case in which the issuance of a permit is denied, the city shall so inform the applicant. Upon delivery of the applicant's written request to the city administrator for the city within five (5) days of such notification, the city shall furnish the applicant with a reasonably detailed written statement of the reasons for such denial. 
(e)  The permit of any solicitor being charged with a felony or misdemeanor involving violence or moral turpitude shall be deemed suspended from the time of lawful arrest, formal accusation or indictment, whichever shall first occur; such suspension shall remain in place until such solicitor is convicted or acquitted, or until the charge is dismissed, dead docketed, no billed, or until the expiration of such permit. 
(f)  The permit of any solicitor who is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving violence or moral turpitude shall stand revoked from the time of such conviction. 
(g)  The permit of any solicitor convicted of having violated any provision of this article after issuance of such permit shall be deemed revoked from the time of such conviction. 
(h)  Any permit issued pursuant to this article shall be revoked if the holder of such permit has made any false material statement in the application for such permit. 
(i)  Any suspension or revocation pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be effective as an operation of law. 
(j)  It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a solicitor after such solicitor's permit has been suspended, revoked or stands expired. 
(k)  Any person denied a permit or person who has had his permit suspended or revoked shall have the right to appeal such denial, suspension, or revocation to the mayor and council of the City of Fitzgerald or other designated hearing officer by giving notice to the city administrator no later than ten (10) days following the receipt of such denial or the effective date of such suspension or revocation. Any appeal shall be scheduled to be heard not later than thirty (30) days from the date of delivery of such notice of appeal to the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 16-1486, § 4, 9-12-16) 
Sec. 16-255. - Display of permit and identification badge. 
(a)  Any person engaged in the act of soliciting shall at all times carry upon his person the permit issued. Such permit shall be made available at the time such person is requested to exhibit such permit by any police officer, city marshal, or person being solicited. 
(b)  Each permit issued shall include and contain, at minimum, the name of the solicitor; the name and address of the person, firm, corporation, or association by whom the solicitor is employed, under contract to, or represents; a photograph of the solicitor; and a physical description of such person. Such photograph shall be provided by the solicitor and subject to the approval of the city. 
(c)  The permit shall state the expiration date of such permit. 
(d)  The permitee shall be issued an identification badge that shall include, at minimum, the permitee's name, a photograph of said permitee, permitee's organization or employer, and the date range such permitee's permit is valid. Such identification badge shall be visibly and conspicuously worn by any person engaged in the act of solicitation at all times. 
(Ord. No. 16-1486, § 5, 9-12-16) 
Sec. 16-256. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  Hours of operation. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the act of soliciting or any conduct for which a permit is required under this article outside of the hours between 10:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., local time. 
(b)  Number of persons soliciting. It shall be unlawful for more than two (2) individuals to engage in the act of soliciting upon any premises at the same time for the same goods or services. Each individual member of a group engaged in such act of soliciting shall be in violation of this provision and subject to punishment for such violation. 
(c)  Frequency of soliciting of premises. It shall be unlawful for any person, or such person's agents, employees, or representatives, to make more than one (1) uninvited solicitation call at the same premises for identical goods or services within any consecutive two-week period. 
(d)  Soliciting to take place at main entrance. It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit or attempt to solicit at a place of residence at any entrance or part of the dwelling other than the main entrance to such dwelling. 
(e)  Identification and announcement of purpose of call. It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the act of soliciting to fail to first inform the occupant of such location at which such solicitation or attempted solicitation occurs of the purpose of such call, the company and product line represented, and the name of such solicitor. 
(f)  Selling or renting permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to lend, rent, or sell a solicitor's permit card to another. 
(Ord. No. 16-1486, § 6, 9-12-16) 
Sec. 16-257. - Posting of signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the act of soliciting upon any private property or premises when the owner thereof has posted or caused to be posted, in a conspicuous place, a notice stating "No Soliciting," or similar language upon the premises. 
(Ord. No. 16-1486, § 7, 9-12-16) 
Sec. 16-258. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 16-1486, § 8, 9-12-16) 
Secs. 16-259-16-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - GAME ROOMS 

Sec. 16-281. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Game rooms means commercial establishments offering video games, arcade games, pool billiards and similar games for pleasure only, which involve some skill and experience rather than pure chance. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 1, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-282. - Scope. 
    Game rooms shall be subject to the regulations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 2, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-283. - Hours and times of operation. 
    Game rooms may be operated from Monday through Saturday from 9:00 a.m. local time until 12:00 midnight local time, and Sundays, from 2:00 p.m. local time to 10:00 p.m. local time. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 3, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-284. - Underage persons. 
    No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be allowed inside the game room after 9:00 p.m. local time. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 4, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-285. - Telephone required. 
    All game rooms must have a functioning telephone that is listed in the current local telephone directory. Failure of an establishment to maintain an operating listed telephone shall be grounds for revocation of its business license. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 5, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-286. - Affidavit; qualifications of affiant. 
    Every person or other entity desiring to operate a game room in the City of Fitzgerald shall make an affidavit that such person (or proposed manager if a corporation or other impersonal entity) is a citizen of the United States of America, is twenty-one (21) years of age or older, and has never been convicted of an offense involving moral turpitude; that affiant will not permit vagrants or intoxicated persons to play or remain in the place of business; that affiant will not have personal responsibility for the management of such business and will not permit gambling or swearing in or about the place of business. Before a permit and occupational tax certificate are issued, the mayor and council of the City of Fitzgerald may, for themselves, inquire into the character and reputation of the affiant, and after such investigation, it shall be discretionary with the mayor and council whether they permit affiant to operate a game room in the City of Fitzgerald, accept payment of the occupational tax and issue an occupational tax certificate. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 6, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-287. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    If an alcoholic beverage license is held by a game room, on-premises consumption of the licensed beverage will be allowed in the game room. Otherwise, no alcoholic beverages shall be consumed inside a game room or on the premises on which it is located and no alcoholic beverages shall be sold, served or otherwise provided therein, and only nonalcoholic beverages and prepackaged food products shall be sold in the business. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 7, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-288. - Operation on ground floor. 
    Such business shall be conducted only on the ground floor of a building. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 8, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-289. - Loitering. 
    Loitering shall not be allowed in the business, and persons doing so shall be immediately reported to the police department. The business shall prosecute a person loitering on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 9, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-290. - Additional restrictions. 
    Game rooms shall be subject to all other premises regulations set forth for billiard parlors under all other ordinances in effect in the City of Fitzgerald. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 10, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-291. - Penalties. 
    A violation of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 11, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-292. - Effective date. 
    This article shall become effective immediately upon its final approval. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 12, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 16-293. - Severability. 
    In the event any provision or portion of this article shall be unconstitutional or invalid, the remaining portion shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 05-1349, § 13, 4-11-05) 
Chapter 17 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Railroads, Ch. 21; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles and traffic generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; authority for municipal regulation of motor vehicles and traffic, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Rules of the Road adopted. 
    O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, and O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1 through 40-6-395, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited in this section. 
(Code 1966, § 18-1) 
State Law reference- Uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; authority for municipalities to adopt uniform rules of the road by reference, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372. 
Sec. 17-2. - Applicability to public employees. 
    Unless otherwise provided, the provisions of this chapter applicable to the drivers of vehicles upon the streets shall apply to the drivers of all vehicles owned or operated by the United States, any state or any county, city, town, district or any other political subdivision of the state. 
(Code 1966, § 18-2) 
Sec. 17-3. - Chapter not to interfere with rights of property owners. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the owner of real property used by the public for purposes of vehicular travel by permission of the owner, and not as matter of right, from prohibiting such use or from requiring other or different or additional conditions than those specified in this chapter or otherwise regulating such use as may seem best to such owner. 
(Code 1966, § 18-3) 
Sec. 17-4. - Disobeying traffic-control devices. 
    The disregard or disobeying of the instructions of any official traffic-control device or signal, placed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, by the driver of a vehicle, shall be deemed as prima facie evidence of a violation of this chapter, without requiring proof of who and by what authority such sign or device has been erected. 
(Code 1966, § 18-4) 
Sec. 17-5. - Dangerous or unsightly material on streets. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit upon any street any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans, rubbish, garbage, trash or other dangerous or unsightly material which is likely to injure any person, animal or vehicle upon such street. 
(b)  Any person who drops or permits to be dropped or thrown upon any street any destructive or injurious material shall immediately remove it or cause it to be removed. 
(c)  Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the street from such vehicle. 
(Code 1966, § 18-5) 
Cross reference- Garbage, trash and weeds, Ch. 12; placing wastes on streets, § 12-7; health and sanitation, Ch. 13; creating unsanitary conditions on streets, § 13-31. 
Sec. 17-6. - Vehicle equipment generally. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle on the streets of the city which does not comply in all respects with state law, relating to equipment of vehicles. 
(Code 1966, § 18-6) 
Sec. 17-7. - Mufflers; prevention of noise, smoke. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle shall at all times be equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying smoke. No person shall use a muffler cut-out, bypass or similar device upon a motor vehicle on a street, except that this section shall not apply to tractors. 
(b)  The engine and power mechanism of every motor vehicle shall be so equipped and adjusted as to prevent the escape of excessive fumes or smoke. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any muffler which causes excessive or unusual noise or annoying smoke, or any muffler cut-out, bypass or similar device for use on a motor vehicle, or to sell or offer for sale any motor vehicle equipped with any such muffler, muffler cut-out, bypass or similar device. 
(Code 1966, § 18-7) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 13. 
Sec. 17-8. - Using closed streets and sidewalks prohibited. 
    Whenever any street, alley or sidewalk, or any portion thereof is closed by order of the mayor, street department or police department, whether the closing thereof is for repairs, improvements, protection against danger or for any other purpose, it shall be unlawful for any person to enter, cross or travel upon the portion so closed except by permission of the authorities closing such area. 
(Code 1966, § 18-8) 
Sec. 17-9. - Temporary regulations authorized. 
    In cases where the traffic upon the streets of the city may become congested, or upon occasions of parades, or at theaters, churches or schools, or any public gathering or assemblage at any park, building or public place, the police may make temporary rules regulating the traffic and any person who violates such regulations, after having been warned of such temporary traffic regulations, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 18-9) 
Sec. 17-10. - Speed limits on specific streets. 
    The mayor and council may from time to time designate specific streets or portions of streets on which the speed limit is greater or less than that prescribed in the Uniform Rules of the Road. When appropriate signs or markings are installed giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful to exceed the speed limits so designated. 
(Code 1966, § 18-10) 
State Law reference- Speed restrictions generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-186 et seq.; authority for local alteration of speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-9, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371. 
Sec. 17-11. - U-turns. 
    It shall be unlawful to turn a vehicle on a street so as to proceed in the opposite direction, commonly known as making a U-turn, at any intersection at which a traffic-control signal is in place or at any other intersection or place where signs have been erected by the police department prohibiting U-turns. 
(Code 1966, § 18-11) 
Sec. 17-12. - Left turns prohibited. 
    The police chief may place or erect signs prohibiting left turns at intersections and it shall be unlawful to violate any such sign. 
(Code 1966, § 18-12) 
Sec. 17-13. - Designation of "yield" intersections. 
    The mayor and council may from time to time designate intersections where traffic on one (1) street shall be required to yield the right-of-way to traffic on another street. Appropriate signs shall be installed and maintained giving notice of such designation and the drivers of vehicles approaching such intersections shall comply with such signs. 
(Code 1966, § 18-13) 
Sec. 17-14. - Designation of through streets and stop intersections. 
    The mayor and council may designate through streets and erect stop signs at specified entrances thereto or may designate any intersection as a stop intersection and erect like signs at one (1) or more entrances to such intersection. 
(Code 1966, § 18-14) 
Sec. 17-15. - Installation, obedience to traffic-control signals, pedestrian signals. 
    The mayor and council may provide for the procuring, erection and maintenance of the traffic-control signals exhibiting the words "Go," "Caution" or "Stop" or exhibiting different colored lights successively at a time, or with arrows, or directing pedestrians to "Walk," "Don't Walk" or "Wait" or exhibiting flashing red, yellow or amber lights, and it shall be unlawful to fail to comply with any such signal. 
(Code 1966, § 18-15) 
Sec. 17-16. - Parking, standing in alleys. 
    No vehicle shall be parked or standing in any of the alleys of the city for a longer time than is necessary to load or unload. 
(Code 1966, § 18-16) 
Sec. 17-17. - Parking, standing regulations at specific locations. 
    The mayor and council may from time to time regulate, restrict or prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles on specified streets or parts of streets or in specified areas. Signs or markings shall be installed and maintained giving notice of such regulations, restrictions and prohibitions and it shall be unlawful to violate or fail to comply with any such sign or marking. 
(Code 1966, § 18-17) 
Sec. 17-18. - Using streets, sidewalks to repair or store vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating and maintaining a garage in the city for the purpose of repairing or storing motor vehicles to use any of the streets, alleys or sidewalks for the purpose of parking cars or for the purpose of washing, painting or repairing such motor vehicles. 
(Code 1966, § 18-18) 
Sec. 17-19. - Abandoned motor vehicles, nuisances, abatement. 
(a)  Nuisance declared. Motor vehicles which are abandoned upon through streets within the corporate limits of the city are hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance. The police chief is hereby authorized and directed to abate the nuisance as provided in this section. 
(b)  Constitutes abandonment. For the purposes of this section, a motor vehicle shall be deemed to be abandoned if it is parked upon a through street continuously for a period of more than forty-eight (48) hours, where such street is located within or adjacent to districts which are zoned for professional, business or industrial uses, or for a period of seven (7) days where such street is located within districts zoned for residential uses. 
(c)  Unlawful. In any case it shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or leave unattended for a period in excess of ten (10) days any motor vehicle upon any street, road, alley or other public way within the city. 
(d)  Abatement, sale, disposition of proceeds. The police chief shall authorize and direct the removal of each abandoned motor vehicle to the city barn, where the motor vehicle shall be temporarily stored for a period of fifteen (15) days. If at the end of the fifteen (15) days the owner of such vehicle has not appeared and paid all fines and costs incurred in the removal and storage of such vehicle and retaken possession of it, the mayor and council shall thereafter declare the vehicle to have been abandoned and to constitute a public nuisance, and shall direct that such vehicle be sold a public auction. The proceeds of the sale shall be applied first in satisfaction of all fines and costs of removal and storage assessed against the vehicle. The balance, if any, of the proceeds shall be held in escrow for a period of six (6) months, during which time such balance may be claimed by the owner of such vehicle, upon satisfactory proof of ownership. If the balance has not been claimed at the end of the six-month period, the balance shall be deemed to be forfeited to the city and shall be deposited into the general treasury of the city. 
(e)  Notice to owner. The police chief shall proceed to ascertain the record owner of the abandoned vehicle and, upon obtaining the name and address of the record owner, shall cause to be mailed to the owner a notice advising him of the circumstances under which such vehicle is being temporarily stored by the city, and further advising the owner of the manner in which such vehicle will be disposed of unless claimed by the owner upon the payment of all applicable fines and costs. 
(f)  Publication of notice. The police chief shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county a notice which shall describe each and every abandoned vehicle which has been removed to the city barn under the provision of this section and unless claimed by the owner upon the payment of all fines and costs. Such notice shall be published once a week for the two (2) weeks next preceding the date on which such vehicle shall otherwise be disposed of. 
(g)  Fine. A fine in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be assessed against each abandoned vehicle and the owner for each day or portion thereof during which such vehicle remains abandoned upon a through street of the city. If the owner does not appear and pay the fine prior to the sale of such vehicle by the city, the fine shall be assessed against the vehicle itself, as provided in this section. 
(Code 1966, § 18-19; Ord. No. 1098, § 1, 8-10-87) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 13; junk, § 18-1; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22; obstructing public ways, § 22-2. 
State Law reference- Abandoned motor vehicles generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. 
Sec. 17-20. - Commercial trucks. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Truck is any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property including raw materials and having more than six (6) wheels. 
(2)  State road or state route means those roads which are defined under of O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1(1). 
(3)  Federal road or federal route means those public roads comprised of the Dwight D. Eisenhower System of Interstate and Defense Highways and the National Highway System, as those terms are defined in Section 103 of Title 23 of the United States Code. 
(4)  City is the City of Fitzgerald. 
(5)  County is the unincorporated area of Ben Hill County. 
(6)  Deviating truck is a truck which leaves and departs from a state road/route, federal road/route, or truck route while traveling within the city. 
(b)  Except as set forth in subparagraph (c) hereinafter, it shall be unlawful for any person, business or company to operate a truck on any roadway, street or thoroughfare within the city other than a state road/route, federal road/route, or a roadway designated as a truck route as set forth in article IV of this chapter. 
(c)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Operation on street for loading and unloading. The operation of trucks upon any street or road where necessary for loading or unloading at a destination point, provided that streets or roads designated as a truck route, state road/route, or federal road/route are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point and provided that any deviating truck shall return to such truck route, state road/route, or federal road/route by the shortest, most direct way. 
(2)  Emergency vehicles. The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street or public road in the city. 
(3)  Public utilities and government vehicles. The operation of any vehicle owned or operated by the city, Ben Hill County, public utility, or contractor or materialman while engaged in repair, maintenance, construction of streets, street improvements, or utilities within the city or Ben Hill County. 
(4)  Detoured trucks. The operation of a deviating truck upon any officially established detour. 
(5)  Local delivery. The operation of a deviating truck within the city, originating in the city or county for the sole purpose of local delivery within the city or county. 
(d)  Any persons violating a provision of this section shall be tried in the Municipal Court of the City of Fitzgerald and, upon conviction, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 16-1482, § 1, 6-13-16) 
Secs. 17-21-17-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ACCIDENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Accidents generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-270 et seq. 

Sec. 17-31. - Duties of driver when death or injury results. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of such accident or as close thereto as possible but shall then forthwith return to and in every event shall remain at the scene of the accident until he has fulfilled the requirements of section 17-33. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. 
(b)  Any person knowingly failing to stop or comply with this section shall upon conviction by guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 18-30) 
Sec. 17-32. - Duties of driver when damage to attended vehicle results. 
    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting only in damage to a vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of such accident or as close thereto as possible but shall forthwith return to and in every event shall remain at the scene of such accident until he has fulfilled the requirements of section 17-33. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. Any person knowingly failing to stop or comply with this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 18-31) 
Sec. 17-33. - Duty to give information, render aid. 
    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or damage to any vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall give his name, address and the registration number of the vehicle he is driving and shall upon request and if available exhibit his operator's or chauffeur's license to the person struck or the driver or occupant of or person attending any vehicle collided with and shall render to any person injured in such accident reasonable assistance, including the carrying or the making of arrangements for the carrying of such person to a physician, surgeon or hospital for medical or surgical treatment if it is apparent that such treatment is necessary or if such carrying is requested by the injured person. 
(Code 1966, § 18-32) 
Sec. 17-34. - Duty upon striking unattended vehicle. 
    The driver of any vehicle which collides with any vehicle which is unattended shall immediately stop and shall then and there either locate and notify the operator or owner of such vehicle of the name and address of the driver and owner of the vehicle striking the unattended vehicle or shall leave in a conspicuous place in the vehicle struck a written notice giving the name and address of the driver and the owner of the vehicle doing the striking. 
(Code 1966, § 18-33) 
Sec. 17-35. - Duty when striking fixtures on streets. 
    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting only in damage to fixtures legally upon or adjacent to a street shall take reasonable steps to locate and notify the owner or person in charge of such property of such fact and of his name and address and of the registration number of the vehicle he is driving and shall upon request and if available exhibit his operator's or chauffeur's license. 
(Code 1966, § 18-34) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 17-36. - Immediate report required. 
    The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or property damage to an apparent extent of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or more shall immediately by the quickest means of communication give notice of such accident to the police department. 
(Code 1966, § 18-35) 
Secs. 17-37-17-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxes and business regulations, Ch. 16. 
State Law reference- Authority for local regulations of taxicabs and other vehicles for hire, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-25, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-6-9; certificates of public necessity may be required by local governments, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-25. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 17-51-17-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TAXICABS 

Sec. 17-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Driver means the person who actually drives a taxicab either for himself or an operator as defined in this division. 
    Operator means every person owning, controlling, operating or managing any one (1) or more taxicabs used in the transporting of persons for hire on the public streets of the city. 
    Permit means the written authority granted by the license committee of the city under this division to engage in the taxicab business in the city. 
    Street means any of the streets, boulevards, avenues, drives or alleys of the city. 
    Taxicab means any motor-driven vehicle for transportation for hire of passengers which operates within the city, except motor vehicles engaged solely in transporting schoolchildren and teachers to and from public schools, and motor vehicles operating under the authority of state public service commission and the Interstate Commerce Commission. 
(Code 1966, § 29-11) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-62. - Compliance with division. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating taxicabs on the streets of the city until the provisions of this division shall have been complied with. 
(Code 1966, § 29-12) 
Sec. 17-63. - Application for permit required; contents. 
    Any person desiring to engage in the business of operating taxicabs as an operator within the city shall first make written application to the license committee of the city for a permit to operate taxicabs on the highways of the city. Such application shall be in writing, addressed to the city and shall be filed with the city clerk. The written application shall contain the full name and address of the person and the principal location from which the business is to be operated. If a corporation, the application shall set forth the names of the officers of the corporation. The application shall also state the number of taxicabs to be operated under such permit if granted, and such other information as may be required by the license committee. The city clerk shall furnish without cost forms for this purpose. 
(Code 1966, § 29-13) 
Sec. 17-64. - Investigation, hearing. 
    Upon the filing of an application for a permit pursuant to this division, the license committee shall make or cause to be made such investigation thereon as it may deem advisable and may in its discretion fix a time and place for the holding of a public hearing upon such application. Such application may be acted upon either at a regular or special meeting of the license committee. 
(Code 1966, § 29-14) 
Sec. 17-65. - Transferability of permits; substitutions of vehicles. 
    Permits issued pursuant to this division shall not be transferable, provided, however, that holders of permits may make replacements and substitutions of taxicabs so long as the number of taxicabs operated does not exceed the number provided for in the permit already issued to such holder. 
(Code 1966, § 29-15) 
Sec. 17-66. - Insurance or bond required; city officials' approval. 
(a)  No permit required by this division shall be issued or continued in effect unless the operator shall have and maintain liability and property damage insurance with a public liability insurance company authorized to do business in the state in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for personal injuries to any one (1) person; fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for personal injuries arising out of one (1) accident; and five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for property damage. An operator may file in lieu of such insurance a bond, with adequate security, which bond must substantially conform to all of the provisions in this division relating to insurance. 
(b)  The mayor, city clerk and city attorney shall approve each bond and policy of insurance offered by an operator and no personal surety shall be adequate or acceptable. Such bond or policy of insurance may be in the form of a separate bond or policy for each taxicab or may be in the form of a fleet bond or policy covering all taxicabs operated by such owner. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16) 
Sec. 17-67. - Maintenance, inspection of vehicles. 
    Each taxicab must be maintained in good mechanical condition at all times. Once each month the operator shall present each taxicab to the police chief for inspection by him. If the police chief finds that the taxicab is not in good mechanical condition, and if it is not equipped in accordance with the laws of the state the police chief shall have authority to take possession of the permit as to such taxicab until the taxicab is placed in good mechanical condition. 
(Code 1966, § 29-17) 
Sec. 17-68. - Requirements for drivers; suspension of right to drive. 
    The driver of a taxicab shall be in good health and free from all communicable diseases and must have a license to operate a taxicab as required by the laws of the state. Any person who has been convicted twice for violating any of the traffic ordinances of the city shall not be permitted to operate a taxicab in the city. Upon any single conviction, the court in its discretion may suspend the right and license of any person to drive a taxicab in the city for a period of thirty (30) days. 
(Code 1966, § 29-18) 
Sec. 17-69. - Vehicles to be marked. 
    Every vehicle used in the city as a taxicab shall be permanently marked in letters at least three (3) inches high and one-quarter inch thick on two (2) sides and the back of every such vehicle or, in lieu thereof, a raised sign may be installed on the top of such vehicle with lettering of the same size as set out above displaying the word, "Taxicab" on the front and back of such raised sign. 
(Code 1966, § 29-19) 
Sec. 17-70. - Card showing insurance or bond and copy of permit required. 
    Every person engaged in the business of operating taxicabs within the city shall display on the right hand side of the windshield, so as to be plainly visible to any passenger occupying the rear seat of the taxicab; a card showing current liability insurance or bond in force for such taxicab and also the copy of the city permit issued for the operation of such taxicab. 
(Code 1966, § 29-20) 
Sec. 17-71. - Offenses related to prohibited beverages. 
(a)  Defined. The term "prohibited liquors and beverages," as used in this section, shall include alcohol, alcoholic liquors, spirituous liquors, mixed liquors any part of which are spirituous, spirits, absinthe, whiskey, brandy, rum, gin, vinous liquors and vinous beverages. 
(b)  Transporting. It shall be unlawful for any taxicab driver or operator to transport any prohibited liquors and beverages. 
(c)  Possessing. It shall be unlawful for any taxicab operator or driver to have within his custody or control while he is within, entering or getting out of any taxicab any prohibited liquors and beverages. 
(d)  Storing. It shall be unlawful for any taxicab operator or driver to permit any prohibited liquors and beverages to be contained in any taxicab owned or operated by such operator or driver. 
(e)  Permit revocation, appeal. The permit issued to any person in compliance with this division may be suspended, cancelled or revoked by the license committee if the holder thereof or any of his agents, servants or employees violates any of the provisions of this section. Upon such suspension, cancellation or revocation of such permit, and such person shall have the right to appeal to the mayor and council, such appeal to be filed with the city clerk in writing within five (5) days following such suspension, cancellation or revocation. The matter shall be heard and passed upon by the mayor and council at any regular or special meeting thereafter. The decision of the mayor and council shall be final. 
(Code 1966, § 29-21) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 17-72. - Violations. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this division or drives a taxicab after his right to do so has been suspended or operates a taxicab either as owner or driver without insurance as required in this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 29-22) 
Secs. 17-73-17-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRUCK ROUTES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1103, adopted Aug. 8, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-5 as Art. IV, §§ 17-101-17-105, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 17-101. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    City is the City of Fitzgerald. 
    County is the unincorporated area of Ben Hill County. 
    Deviating truck is a truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling within the city, as permitted herein. 
    Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Truck is any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property including raw materials and having more than six (6) wheels. 
    Truck route means any street or road, or any portion thereof, within the city, now or hereafter designated as a truck route by resolution of the mayor and council of the city. 
    Vehicle, for the purposes of determination of weight or number of axles, includes any tractor-trailer, which together shall comprise one (1) vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1113, § 1, 8-8-88) 
Sec. 17-102. - Purpose. 
    It is hereby declared to be the purpose of this article to protect the public safety and the use of the streets and roads of the city; to facilitate and expedite traffic within the city; and to protect the streets and roads of the city from unusual wear and damage. 
(Ord. No. 1113, § 5, 8-8-88) 
Sec. 17-103. - Application of regulations. 
(a)  Generally. Except as specifically set out herein, no truck shall be operated over any public street or road in the city other than a truck route. 
(b)  Exceptions: 
(1)  Any truck may deviate from a truck route and operate over a prohibited street or road where necessary to reach a destination point in the county or the city for the conduct of business, provided truck routes and state or federal highways and Merrimac, Monitor, Sultana and Roanoke Drives are used until reaching the intersection of the prohibited street or road nearest such destination. 
(2)  Any truck may be operated over a prohibited street or road where necessary to leave a point of origin within the county or the city for the conduct of business, provided it leaves such prohibited street or road at the nearest intersection of a truck route, state or federal highway, or drive, to such point of origin. 
(3)  Any truck may be operated over a prohibited street or road if owned or operated by the city or county, or if operated by any public utility, contractor or materialman while engaged in repair, maintenance, construction of streets, street improvements, or utilities within the county or city. 
(Ord. No. 1113, § 2, 8-8-88) 
Sec. 17-104. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city clerk shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck routes; the map shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available to the public. 
(b)  The chief of police of the city shall cause those roads upon which truck traffic is prohibited to be clearly signed and posted to give notice that this article is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 1113, § 3, 8-8-88) 
Sec. 17-105. - Violations. 
    Any persons violating a provision of this article shall be tried in the mayor's court of the city and, upon conviction, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 1113, § 4, 8-8-88) 
Secs. 17-106-17-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ON-STREET OPERATION OR PARKING IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-1282, § 1, adopted April 9, 2001, set out provisions intended for use as a new Art. V, §§ 17-110-17-112. To preserve the style of this Code and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included herein as Art. V, §§ 17-126-17-128. 

Sec. 17-126. - On-street operation or parking of certain vehicles and trailers prohibited. 
    On-street operation or parking of any vehicle having ten (10) or more wheels or of any trailer having four (4) or more wheels on any public street or road in any part of the city that is zoned residential is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 01-1282, § 1, 4-9-01) 
Sec. 17-127. - Exception for delivery vehicles. 
    This article shall not apply to vehicles including trailers attached thereto that are being operated or parked on any such street for the purpose of making deliveries at such location. However, this exception shall only apply for the minimum time necessary to make any such delivery. 
(Ord. No. 01-1282, § 1, 4-9-01) 
Sec. 17-128. - Punishment for violations. 
    Any violation of this article shall be unlawful and punished as for a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 01-1282, § 1, 4-9-01) 
Chapter 18 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 4; animals, Ch. 5; court, Ch. 9; garbage, trash and weeds, Ch. 12; health and sanitation, Ch. 13. 
State Law reference- Crimes generally, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.; limitation on local ordinances defining a criminal defense that is also a crime under state law, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Junk. 
(a)  Defined. "Junk" is hereby defined as old iron, steel, brass, copper, tin, lead, or other base materials; old cordage, ropes, rags, bricks, or fabrics; old rubber; old bottles or other glass; bones; wastepaper and other waste or discarded material which might be prepared to be used again in some form; and motor vehicles which are discarded, abandoned, inoperative, dismantled, wrecked, scrapped or ruined, or parts thereof. 
(b)  Unlawful. It shall be unlawful to permit junk to be left on private property or on streets or alleys within the city. 
(c)  On private premises; notice. The city administrator or his delegate shall notify in writing the owner or occupant of any premises upon which junk is located in violation of the provisions of this section that such material must be removed within ten (10) days from the date of such notice. Such notice shall be delivered in person or by United States certified or registered mail addressed to the owner or occupant of such premises as shown on the tax records of the city. 
(d)  On public ways; notice. The city administrator or his delegate shall notify in writing the owner of any junk left on the public streets and alleys of the city that such material must be removed within ten (10) days from the date of such notice. Such notice shall be delivered in person or by United States certified or registered mail addressed to the owner, if known. If the owner is unknown, the notice shall be posted on the junk. 
(e)  Failure to comply; removal. Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or occupant notified to remove such junk within the designated time period, the city administrator or his delegate is authorized and empowered to arrange for the removal of such material by the city or by a private individual or firm through contract with the city. 
(f)  Cumulative remedies. This section is cumulative and provides additional remedy to any other remedies now existing for the removal of junk from private property. 
(Ord. No. 1097, §§ 1-6, 8-10-87; Ord. No. 01-1284, §§ 1-4, 5-14-01) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 17; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 18-2. - Assault and battery. 
    It shall be unlawful to attempt to commit or commit a violent injury to the person of another. 
(Code 1966, § 19-1) 
State Law reference- Assault and battery, O.C.G.A. § 16-5-20 et seq. 
Sec. 18-3. - Disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct himself in a tumultuous or riotous manner or to commit any act against good order, temperance, public safety, morality or common decency in the city. 
(Code 1966, § 19-2) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39. 
Sec. 18-4. - Drunkenness. 
    It shall be unlawful to be drunk or intoxicated upon any street, alley or other public place of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 19-4) 
State Law reference- Public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. 
Sec. 18-5. - Gambling and gambling places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person either by himself or his agent to keep or maintain within the city any gaming house or room occupied or controlled by him whether directly or indirectly or to permit persons to come together and play for money or other valuable things at any game of chance by whatever name called or to carry on or to permit to be carried on at any place within the city any device or practices for the purpose of gambling. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to play or bet for money or anything of value at any game of cards or other game of chance. 
(Code 1966, § 19-7) 
State Law reference- Gambling and related offenses, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20. 
Sec. 18-6. - Houses of ill fame. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or remain as an inmate in a house of prostitution, ill fame or assignation or other place or resort for the purpose of fornication or adultery. 
(Code 1966, § 19-8) 
State Law reference- Keeping a place of prostitution, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-10; disorderly house, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-44. 
Sec. 18-7. - Loitering. 
(a)  "Loitering" shall mean remaining idle in essentially one (1) location and shall include the concepts of spending time idly, loafing, walking about aimlessly, or sitting on cars, trucks, or other vehicles, and shall include the colloquial expression "hanging around." It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter within the city public property or private property used by the public in such a manner as to: 
(1)  Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace; 
(2)  Create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person; 
(3)  Obstruct the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles; 
(4)  Obstruct, molest, or interfere with any person lawfully in any public place; 
(5)  Be at a place, at a time, or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances which would warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property within the vicinity; 
(6)  Near business establishments. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to congregate or loiter on any private property which is adjacent to or used by any business or commercial establishment in the city for the use of said business establishment or its customers for parking of vehicles or other uses incidental to the operation of said business; or 
(7)  Congregating on sidewalks or streets. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to obstruct the sidewalks or streets of the city, or sidewalks or drives within private property which is open to the public, by standing, sitting, or laying in crowds. 
(b)  Relocating from one (1) position to another and regrouping or generally "hanging around" shall be prima facie evidence of intent to continue an unlawful act under this section and shall constitute a new offense after having been dispersed or cited for an offense under these provisions. 
(c)  A person commits the offense of loitering if said person refuses to leave the premises or place after being asked to leave by the owner of the premises, the authorized agent of the owner, or a law enforcement officer. 
(d)  Among the circumstances, which may be considered in determining, whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify him or herself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impractical, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself or herself and explain his or her presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(Code 1966, § 19-10; Ord. No. 05-1362, § 2, 12-12-05) 
State Law reference- Loitering or prowling, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-36. 
Sec. 18-8. - Obscene, abusive, profane language. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use vulgar, obscene, abusive or profane language to or of another in any public place, street or alley. 
(Code 1966, § 19-11) 
Sec. 18-9. - Quarrelling, fighting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to quarrel or fight in any public place, street or alley. 
(Code 1966, § 19-12) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39; affray, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-32. 
Sec. 18-10. - Police officers; resisting; obstructing; following; impersonating. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to resist any police officer, any member of the police department, or any other person duly empowered with police authority, while in the discharge or apparent discharge of his duty, or in any way interfere with, obstruct or hinder him in the discharge of this duty. 
(b)  No person shall follow any police officer, while in charge of any prisoner, after such person has been commanded to desist such following, or after any crowd has been commanded to disperse. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to wear or carry the uniform, apparel, badge, identification card or any other insignia of office, like or similar to, or a colorable imitation of that adopted and worn or carried by the official police officers of the city, unless such person is an official officer of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 19-13; Ord. No. 05-1362, § 3, 12-12-05) 
State Law reference- Impersonating police officers, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-23; obstruction of police officer, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-24. 
Sec. 18-11. - Sewers; damaging, interfering with. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or damage any sewer or fixture or appurtenances of sewers or deposit any garbage, offal or refuse material of any kind in any catch basin, manhole or other fixture of a public sewer or to remove any manhole cover without first obtaining the permission of the superintendent of the water, light and bond commission. 
(Code 1966, § 19-14) 
Cross reference- Sewage, § 23-16 et seq. 
State Law reference- Damaging, injuring, or interfering with property of public utility companies or municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. 
Sec. 18-12. - Trespassing, squatting, camping on city property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to squat, trespass and camp upon any public park, public square, vacant lot, street or alley owned by the city without first having obtained the permission and consent of the city administrator or the police chief. 
(Code 1966, § 19-15) 
State Law reference- Criminal trespass, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-21 et seq. 
Sec. 18-13. - Weapons. 
(a)  Discharging firearms. It shall be unlawful to fire or discharge any firearms in the city without first obtaining the permission of the police chief, provided that this subsection shall not apply to duly authorized law enforcement officers acting in pursuit of their duties. 
(b)  Sale regulated. No person shall sell to anyone a pistol or any other firearm capable of being concealed on the person, or any dirk, sword cane, brass knucks or bowie knife or any other kind of knives manufactured or sold for the purpose of offense and defense, within the corporate limits of the city, unless such person selling any of such articles shall make a report to the police chief before 10:00 a.m. of the following day (except Sunday when transactions for Saturday shall be made the following Monday) of the sale of any of the articles listed in this subsection. Such report shall verify the articles sold giving a full description thereof such as number, mark and any other details as will make identification of such articles clear and positive and shall given the name of the person to whom sold with his age and address set forth therein. 
(Code 1966, §§ 19-16, 19-17) 
State Law reference- Georgia Firearms and Weapons Act, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-120 et seq.; state preemption of firearm regulations, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-173; discharge of firearms on or near public highway, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-103; discharge of firearms on property of another, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-104; authority for local ordinances regarding discharge of firearms, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-173. 
Sec. 18-14. - Adult book stores, movie houses. 
(a)  Any adult book store or adult movie house in the city is hereby prohibited from operating within two hundred (200) yards of any church, church book store, public park, public housing project, hospital, public or private school, college, recreational center or private residence. 
(b)  The term "adult book store" shall mean any commercial establishment in which is offered for sale any book or publication, film or other medium which depicts nudity or sexual conduct. 
(c)  The term "adult movie house" shall mean any movie theater which on a regular, continuing basis shows films rated X by the Motion Picture Coding Association of America, or any movie theater which presents for public viewing on a regular, continuing basis so-called "adult films" depicting sexual conduct. 
(d)  The definition of the term "sexual conduct and nudity" as set forth in act of the 1971 General Assembly of the State of Georgia, set forth in 1971 Georgia Laws, pages 888 and 889 are hereby adopted by reference thereto and are hereby made a part of this section. 
(e)  Any person violating this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-8. 
(f)  Any person convicted of violating this section shall be subject to having its city business license revoked. 
(Code 1966, § 19-19) 
Sec. 18-15. - Truancy. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, "public place" means any street, highway, alley or right-of-way, to include sidewalks, any park, playground, shopping center or other place or building open to the public; any cemetery, school yard, body of water or watercourse; any privately or publicly owned place of amusement, entertainment or public accommodation, including parking lots and other areas adjacent thereto; and any vacant lot or land, whether publicly or privately owned. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any minor between the ages of seven (7) and sixteen (16) years to loiter, wander, stroll, or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots, or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. on any school day; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  When a minor is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian, or other adult person twenty-one (21) years of age or older having the legal care or custody of the minor; 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by the minor's parent, guardian, or other adult person having the legal care or custody of the minor; 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly from [to] home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above-referenced places during the prescribed period of time; 
(4)  When the minor is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal interstate or intrastate travel through the city; 
(5)  When the minor is enrolled in a valid home study program, as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690; 
(6)  When the minor has completed all course study requirements for high school graduation; 
(7)  When the minor is married in accordance with applicable law; 
(8)  When the minor has written proof from school authorities that the minor is excused from school attendance at that particular time; 
(9)  When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; or 
(10)  When the minor serves as a page of the general assembly, as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 20-2-692. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having legal custody or control of any minor to allow such minor to be in or upon any public place within the city between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. on any school day, except in the circumstances set out in subsection (b)(1) through (9) above. An adult person who is in violation of this subsection shall be subject to such punishment as the municipal court of the city may impose, subject to all limitations contained in the charter of the city. Each violation of this subsection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  It shall be an affirmative defense to an offense charged under subsection (c) above that the parent or legal guardian of the minor has initiated the jurisdiction of the juvenile court against the minor prior to the time that the minor was found in violation of subsection (b) above. Any minor who violates subsection (b) above is subject to the jurisdiction of the juvenile court. 
(e)  Any police officer who takes into custody a minor in violation of subsection (b) above shall comply with the requirements of O.C.G.A. §§ 20-2-699 and 20-2-700. 
(f)  If a minor is suspended or expelled from school, that minor's parent or legal guardian, for the duration of the suspension or expulsion, shall prohibit the minor from being in any public place at the time that the minor would have been required to be in attendance at school had the minor not been suspended or expelled, unless; 
(1)  The minor is accompanied by the minor's parent or legal guardian or a responsible adult, twenty-one (21) years of age or older, selected by the parent or legal guardian to supervise the minor; or 
(2)  The minor is employed pursuant to an age or schooling certificate during the actual working hours or traveling directly to or from the job site. 
(g)  A person who is in violation of subsection (f) above shall be subject to such punishment as the municipal court of the city shall impose, subject to all limitations contained in the charter of the city. Each violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(h)  Any minor who violates subsection (b) above while under suspension or expulsion shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the juvenile court. 
(i)  It shall be an affirmative defense to an offense charged under subsection (f) above that the parent or legal guardian has invoked the jurisdiction of the juvenile court against the minor prior to the time that the minor violated subsection (f) above. 
(Ord. No. 1215, § I, 5-13-96) 
Sec. 18-16. - Yard sales. 
(1)  Subject to the provisions of subsection (9) of this section, it shall be permitted within any residential district to have and advertise a sale of personal property. It shall not be the intention of these regulations to prohibit the occasional sale of personal belongings, nor shall the restrictions against signs in residential districts apply to the advertising of yard sales, garage sales, or estate sales. The application of this regulation shall take precedence over the sign regulations with regard to yard sales, estate sales, garage sales, or any sale of like nature. 
(2)  All sales of personal property occasionally sold in the yard, garage, carport, or house, commonly called carport sales, yard sales, garage sales, family sales, moving sales, or estate sales, shall be known as yard sales for the purpose of this regulation. 
(3)  All yard sales in the City of Fitzgerald shall require a permit to be obtained for a fee of five dollars ($5.00) a minimum of three (3) business days prior to the date of said sale, which permit shall be obtained from the Office of the Community Development Department of the City of Fitzgerald by personal application. This permit shall contain the name and address of the applicant, and the three (3) consecutive day period for which the applicant wishes to sell property and the permit number. No more than two (2) such permits shall be issued in any calendar year for the same street address unless such street address has been designated by the city as an aggregate yard sale area. 
(4)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property where the sale is to be conducted to obtain the permit and to post said permit in full view of the public at the place of the yard sale. 
(5)  It shall be a violation of this regulation to sell merchandise in a yard sale or offer merchandise for sale by sign or to display merchandise in any yard, carport, garage, or house without a yard sale permit. 
(6)  It shall be permitted to advertise a lawful yard sale by the use of signs which direct the public to the location of the yard sale. The yard sale signs shall be of any color and no larger than two (2) feet by three (3) feet. The yard sale signs shall not be attached to any utility pole, government sign, or placed on any public property or right-of-way. It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to remove said signs within twenty-four (24) hours after the expiration of said permit. No sign may interfere with, be an obstruction to, or impede vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(7)  The section shall not regulate the private sale of major possessions such as homes and automobiles. 
(8)  Religious and charitable organizations exempt from Federal taxation pursuant to section 501(c)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code may conduct yard sales on the property of the organization or at other locations within the city with the expressed written consent of the owner of the premises where the yard sale is being conducted. 
(9)  Yard sales may be held on a lot or parcel of land upon which there is situated a house, apartment or other structure which is utilized primarily for residential purposes. Yard sales (other than those permitted under subsection (8) of this section and those permitted in an area designated as an aggregate yard sale area under subsection (3) of this section) are prohibited upon vacant lots and upon lots upon which there is situated a structure that is utilized primarily for any use other than residential purposes. 
(10)  Each day of noncompliance with this section shall constitute an additional violation of this section. Violators of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 09-1403, §§ 1-10, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 18-17. - Pawnshops. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include words in the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(2)  Pawnbroker is any person or entity engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers as a part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this Code section. 
(3)  Pledged goods are items of tangible personal property other than choses in action, securities, notes or other evidences of indebtedness, which said property is purchased by, deposited or left with, or otherwise actually delivered into the possession of a pawnbroker in the course of his business. 
(4)  Police department refers to the police department of the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
(b)  Duration of purchase transactions. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to resell any item purchased in the pawn business until at least ten (10) days have elapsed following the date of the purchase of such item. 
(c)  Duration of pawn transactions. 
(1)  All pawn transactions shall be for thirty (30) day periods, but may be extended or continued for additional thirty (30) day periods. In no event shall a pawn transaction be for less than thirty (30) days. 
(d)  Minors. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker and/or agent or employee of such pawnbroker to receive in pawn, trade, or to purchase from a minor goods or items of any kind. 
(e)  Inspection of inventory. 
(1)  The inventory of any pawnbroker shall be available for inspection by officers of the police department during ordinary business hours and/or any other reasonable time acceptable to the pawnbroker and the officer(s) of the police department. 
(f)  Record keeping. 
(1)  Each pawnbroker shall maintain a permanent record in which shall be entered at the time of each transaction the following information: 
a.  Date of transaction; 
b.  Type of transaction; 
c.  Name of pawnbroker/employee conducting the transaction; 
d.  The name, age, and address of the customer, general description of the customer's appearance, and customer's driver's license number or identification card number; 
e.  Identification and description of the pledged or purchased goods. Such description shall include, when available, the serial number, model number, or such other number of such good or item and any other identifying marks thereon; 
f.  The receipt number/pawn ticket number regarding such transaction; 
g.  The price paid or amount loaned in such transaction; 
h.  The maturity date of the transaction; and 
i.  The signature of the customer. 
(2)  Said permanent record shall be kept by each pawnbroker in a typed or legible handwritten format; otherwise such record may be kept electronically in a medium compatible with the police department's computer system and shall be able to be transferred via disk or other portable memory device. 
(3)  Said permanent record of each transaction shall be maintained by the pawnbroker for a period of not less than four (4) years from the date thereof. 
(4)  The permanent record shall be available for inspection by a member of the police department during the ordinary hours of business and/or any other reasonable time acceptable to the pawnbroker and the officer(s) of the police department. 
(g)  Reports to the police department. 
(1)  Each pawnbroker shall be required to deliver to the police department a legible report once each week every week said pawnbroker is open for business. Such weekly report shall contain all entries into the permanent record for such week as contemplated in subsection (f)(1) hereinbefore. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for a pawnbroker or any agent or employee thereof to make any false entry in any report. Any person making any willfully false or misleading statements in the report shall be punished as provided hereinafter. 
(h)  Penalties. 
(1)  Any violation of any portion of this section shall be construed as an offense against the City of Fitzgerald and shall be a misdemeanor and punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Any business who shall be convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be subject to suspension or revocation of its business license or permit. 
(Ord. No. 16-1478, § 1, 1-11-16) 
Secs. 18-18-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DRUG PARAPHERNALIA[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Transactions in drug related objects prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 16-13-32. 

Sec. 18-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Apothecary means a licensed pharmacist as defined by the laws of this state. 
    Dentist means a person authorized by law to practice dentistry in this state. 
    Hospital means an institution for the care and treatment of the sick and injured. 
    Physician means a person authorized to practice medicine in this state and any other person authorized by law to treat sick and injured human beings in this state and to use narcotic drugs in connection with such treatment. 
    Veterinarian means a person authorized by law to practice veterinary medicine in this state. 
(Code 1966, § 19-30) 
Cross reference- Definitions; rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-32. - Use of drug apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any apparatus, device or instrument for the unauthorized use of drugs. Use shall not be unauthorized if authorized by a physician, dentist, veterinarian or authorized nurse, attendant or intern of a hospital, sanatorium or institution in which persons are treated for disability or disease. 
(Code 1966, § 19-31) 
Sec. 18-33. - Destruction of hypodermic syringes and needles. 
    All hypodermic syringes and hypodermic needles must be destroyed when no longer in use for medical purposes, and it shall be unlawful not to destroy them. Hypodermic needles shall be broken off from the hub, glass hypodermic syringes shall be broken and disposable hypodermic syringes shall be incinerated. 
(Code 1966, § 19-32) 
Sec. 18-34. - Possession of hypodermic syringes or needles restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except a dealer in surgical instruments, physician, apothecary, dentist, veterinarian or nurse, attendant or intern of a hospital, sanatorium or institution in which persons are treated for disability or disease, at any time to have, possess or buy a hypodermic needle or hypodermic syringe unless such possession or purchase is authorized by the prescription or the certificate of a physician, dentist or veterinarian. 
(Code 1966, § 19-33) 
Sec. 18-35. - Penalty for violation. 
    The penalty for violation of the provisions of this article shall be according to section 1-8. 
(Code 1966, § 19-34) 
Secs. 18-36-18-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 18-61. - Public parks; hours of operation. 
(a)  The mayor and/or council may establish closing times for any recreation facility or area owned or maintained by the city. These closing times shall be posted in conspicuous places in or around the facility or area regulated. 
(b)  There shall be no use of the facility or area affected after the posted closing time, unless the facilities have been rented for a community function. No one shall be allowed on the subject property and there shall be no parking or congregating on the public streets or parking areas around the property. 
(Ord. No. 05-1362, § 1, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 18-62. - Destruction of, damage to property-Public; generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage, break, mutilate, alter, deface or in any other manner destroy or injure public property, either real or personal, belonging to or used by the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-1362, § 1, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 18-63. - Malicious mischief as to public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to paint, mark, print or in any manner to deface or to paste advertising matter of any kind on any of the signs or public property within the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-1362, § 1, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 18-64. - Defacing private signs or buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, glue or fix in any manner any cardboard or paper advertisement on, or to mark with paint, crayon or otherwise, any private sign or building within the city without permission of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 05-1362, § 1, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 18-65. - Defrauding innkeeper or food establishment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without contracting for credit, to board or lodge at a hotel or a motor court or similar establishment, or eat at an eating house or similar establishment and then refuse to pay for the service. 
(Ord. No. 05-1362, § 1, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 18-66. - Sound systems disturbing neighbors prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any phonograph, television set, music box, radio, or other sound-receiving or transmitting system in such a manner as to disturb the neighbors. 
(Ord. No. 05-1362, § 1, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 18-67. - Curfew. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any minor under seventeen (17) years of age to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 12:00 midnight on any day and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  When a minor is accompanied by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his or her parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor; 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity or dance; 
(4)  When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above-referenced places during the prescribed period of time; and 
(5)  When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any child under sixteen (16) years of age to permit, or by insufficient control, to allow, such child to be in or upon the public streets or any other places between the hours of 12:00 midnight on any day and 6:00 a.m. the following day, except in circumstances set out in subsections (a)(1) through (a)(5) of this section. Upon conviction of a violation of this section for the first time, a person shall be given a warning citation. Upon further convictions, a person shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and costs, or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than sixty (60) days, or work on the city streets or work on the public works of the city for not more than sixty (60) days, or be subject to any one (1) or more of the within punishments. Each violation of this shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 05-1362, § 1, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 18-68. - Carrying pistol without license. 
    A person commits the crime of carrying a pistol without a license when he has or carries on or about his person, outside of his home, motor vehicle or place of business, any pistol or revolver without having on his person a valid license issued by the judge of the probate court of the county in which he resides; provided that no permit shall be required for persons with a valid hunting or fishing license on their person or for persons not required by law to have hunting licenses who are engaged in legal hunting, fishing or sport shooting, when the persons have the permission of the owner of the land on which the activities are being conducted. A pistol or revolver, whenever loaded, shall be carried only in an open and fully exposed manner. Upon conviction of the crime of carrying a pistol without a license, the person committing the violation shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  For the first offense, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished by imprisonment of not more than three (3) months and may be fined in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(2)  For the second offense, and for any subsequent offense, he shall be guilty of a felony, and shall be bound over to the superior court for disposition. 
(Ord. No. 05-1362, § 1, 12-12-05) 
State Law reference- Georgia Firearms and Weapons Act, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-120 et seq.; state preemption of firearm regulation, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-173. 
Sec. 18-69. - Carrying concealed weapon. 
    A person commits the crime of carrying a concealed weapon when he has or carries about his person outside of his home or place of business, unless in an open manner and fully exposed to view, any bludgeon, metal knuckles, firearm, knife designed for offense and defense, or any other dangerous or deadly weapon or instrument of like character, except as permitted under O.C.G.A. § 16-11-130. 
(Ord. No. 05-1362, § 1, 12-12-05) 
State Law reference- Georgia Firearms and Weapons Act, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-120 et seq.; state preemption of firearm regulation, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-173. 
Sec. 18-70. - Knives, razors and ice picks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have, possess or carry upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks or in any public place in the city any of the following implements unless same are securely wrapped so as not to be readily available for harmful use: 
(1)  Any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring, or other device in the handle, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two (2) inches.
