(c)  Any property owner or interested party shall provide notice, in writing, of any petition or filing made in the municipal court to the city manager at least ten (10) days prior to any hearing before the municipal court. 
(d)  No designation or increased rate of taxation shall be lifted before an order of the municipal court is issued. 
(Ord. No. 18-1514, § 7, 4-9-18) 
Sec. 18-126. - Decreased rate of taxation for remediated property. 
(a)  Real property which has had its designation as maintained in a blighted condition removed as provided in this article shall be eligible for a decrease in the rate of city ad valorem taxation. Said decreased rate of taxation shall be determined by applying a factor of 0.50 to the normal city millage rate applied to the subject property so that such property shall be taxed at a lower millage rate than the millage rate generally applied in the city. 
(b)  Such decreased rate of taxation shall be applied and reflected in the first tax bill rendered following the entering of an order of the municipal court removing the designation of the subject property as blighted, and shall continue to apply for two (2) years thereafter, totaling three (3) years of taxation at the decreased rate. 
(Ord. No. 18-1514, § 8, 4-9-18) 
Chapter 19 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; department of leisure services, § 2-106 et seq.; animals, Ch. 5; cemeteries, Ch. 7; garbage, trash and weeds, Ch. 12; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 17; planning and development, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facility, Ga. Const., art. IX, § II, ¶ III, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; parks, historic areas, memorials, and recreation, O.C.G.A. § 12-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 19-1. - Damaging, misusing facilities or property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, damage, deface, destroy or otherwise impair any of the buildings, structures, improvements, fences, light poles, wiring, trees, flowers, shrubs or other portions of any of the public parks or recreational or athletic fields belonging to the city or to use any of such parks and recreational or athletic fields for the purpose of private profit and gain, except only when used for athletic contests under the permission and authority of the department of leisure services and after payment of compensation for such use. 
(Code 1966, § 20-6) 
Sec. 19-2. - Riding, driving in parks; walking on grass, flowers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive any vehicle or cattle, hogs or other animals of any kind or description on or across the parks of the city or to walk upon the grass or flowers in any park in this city, except that seats or benches in the parks may be occupied and used by the public. 
(Code 1966, § 20-7) 
Sec. 19-3. - Hitching animals in parks. 
    It shall be unlawful to tie or fasten any animal or team to any tree in any city park. 
(Code 1966, § 20-8) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 5.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 20-1-20-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Georgia Historic Preservation Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-20 et seq.; regulation of fire hazards associated with historic buildings, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-13 et seq.; history preservation grant program, O.C.G.A. § 12-3-58 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-16. - Purpose. 
    This article is designed to: 
(1)  Support and further the mayor and council's determination that the historical, cultural and aesthetic heritage of the city is among its most valued and important assets and that the preservation of this heritage is essential to the promotion of the health, prosperity and general welfare of the citizens of the city; 
(2)  Stimulate revitalization of the city's central business district and its historic neighborhoods and promote and enhance local historical and aesthetic attractions to tourists and thereby promote and stimulate business; 
(3)  Enhance the opportunities for federal or state tax benefits under relevant provisions of federal or state law; 
(4)  Provide for the designation, protection, preservation and rehabilitation of historic properties and historical districts and participate in federal and state programs to do the same; 
(5)  Establish a uniform procedure for use in providing for the protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use of places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, objects, landscape features and works of art having a special historic, cultural or aesthetic interest or value in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 1, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-17. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Certificate of appropriateness means a document evidencing approval by the historic preservation commission of an application to make a material change in the appearance of a designated historic property or of a property located within a designated historic district. 
    Commission means the Fitzgerald Historic Preservation Commission. 
    Exterior architectural features means the color, architectural style, general design and general arrangement of all or any part of the exterior of a building or other structure, including but not limited to the color, kind or texture of the building material and the color, type and style of all walls and other exterior surfaces, windows, doors, signs and other appertainments, architectural fixtures, features, details or elements relative to the foregoing. 
    Exterior and environmental features means all those aspects of the landscape or the development of a site which affect the historic character of the property. 
    Historic district means a geographically defined area designated by the city by mayor and council as a historic district pursuant to the criteria established in this article. 
    Historic property means an individual building, structure, site, object or work of art including the adjacent area necessary for the property appreciation thereof designated by mayor and council as a historic property pursuant to the criteria established in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 2, 10-13-86; Ord. No. 05-1355, § 1, 8-22-05) 
Cross reference- Definitions; rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 20-18. - Relationship to existing zoning and zoning districts. 
    The provisions of this article and in particular the designation of any area as a historic district or any structure as a historic property are intended to preserve and protect the historic quality or architecture for the buildings, structures, sites, monuments or works of art of the historic area. In all zoning districts lying within the boundaries of any designated historic district, the regulations of both the zoning district and the historic district shall apply. Whenever a conflict between the regulations of the zoning district and the regulations of the historic district conflict, the more restrictive shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 3, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-19. - Requirements for adopting designations. 
(a)  Application. Application for designation of historic districts or properties may be proposed by the city council or the commission itself, or: 
(1)  For historic districts, a historic society, neighborhood associations or groups of property owners may apply to the commission for designation; 
(2)  For historic properties, a historic society, neighborhood associations or property owners may apply to the commission for designation. 
(b)  Components. Any ordinance designating any property or district as historic shall: 
(1)  List each property in a proposed historic district or describe the proposed individual historic property; 
(2)  Set forth the names of the owners of the designated properties; 
(3)  Require that a certificate of appropriateness be obtained from the commission prior to any material change in appearance of the designated property; and 
(4)  Require that the property or district be shown on the official zoning map of the city. 
(c)  Report. No less than thirty (30) days prior to making a recommendation on any ordinance designating a property or district as historic, the commission must submit a report as required by law to the historic preservation section of the department of natural resources. 
(d)  Hearings, published notice. The commission and the city shall hold a public hearing on any proposed ordinance for the designation of any historic district or property. Notice of a hearing shall be published in at least three (3) consecutive issues in the principal newspaper of local circulation, and written notice of the hearing shall be mailed by the commission to all owners and occupants of such properties. All such notices shall be published or mailed no less than ten (10) days nor more than twenty (20) days prior to the date set for a public hearing. A notice sent by the United States mail to the last known owner of the property shown on the city and county tax rolls and a notice sent through United States mail to the address of the property to the attention of the occupant shall constitute legal notification to the owner and occupant under this article. 
(e)  Recommendation. A recommendation to affirm, modify or withdraw the proposed ordinance for designation shall be made by the commission within fifteen (15) days following the public hearing and shall be in the form of a resolution to the mayor and council. 
(f)  Action on recommendation. Following the receipt of the commission's recommendation, the mayor and council may adopt the ordinance as proposed, may adopt the ordinance with any amendments it deems necessary, or reject the ordinance. 
(g)  Notice of adoption. Within thirty (30) days following adoption of the ordinance for designation by the mayor and council, the owners and occupants of each structure, site or work of art located within the designated historic district shall be given written notification of such designation by the mayor and council which notice shall apply to such owners and occupants of the necessity of obtaining a certificate of appropriateness prior to undertaking any material change in appearance of historic property designated or within the historic district designated. A notice sent through the United States mail to the last known owner of the property shown on the city or county tax roll or a notice sent through United States mail to the address of the property to the attention of the occupant shall constitute legal notice to the owners and occupants under this article. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 4D, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-20. - Designation of property. 
(a)  Criteria. A historic property is a building, structure, site, work of art, including the adjacent area necessary for the proper appreciation or use thereof deemed worthy of preservation by reason of value to the city, state or the local region or for one (1) of the following reasons: 
(1)  It is an outstanding example of structural representation of its era; 
(2)  It is one (1) of the few remaining examples of past architectural style; 
(3)  It is a place or structure associated with an event or persons of historic or cultural significance to the city, state or the region; or 
(4)  It is the site of natural or aesthetic interest that is continuing to contribute to the cultural or historic development and heritage of the city, county, state or the region. 
(b)  Boundaries. Boundaries shall be included in separate ordinances designating such properties and shall be shown on the official zoning map of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 4C, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-21. - Designation of district. 
(a)  Criteria. A historic district is a geographically definable area which contains buildings, structures, sites, objects, landscape features and works of art or a combination thereof which: 
(1)  Have special character or special historic or aesthetic value or interest; 
(2)  Represent one (1) or more periods, styles or types of architecture, types of one (1) or more eras in the history of the municipality, county, state or the general geographic region; and 
(3)  Cause such areas, by reason of such factors, to constitute a visually perceptive section of the municipality. 
(b)  Boundaries. Boundaries of a historic district shall be included in the separate ordinances designating such districts and shall be shown on the official zoning map of the city. 
(c)  Evaluation of properties. Individual properties within historic districts shall be classified as historic or nonhistoric: 
(1)  Historic. 
a.  Exceptional. Those structures having special character and contributing to the district because of their particular historical character. 
b.  Notable. Structures which represent one (1) or more architectural styles typical of one (1) or more eras in city history and are one (1) of the few remaining examples of such architectural style; 
c.  Valuable. Structures that are of value as part of the area and contribute to the cultural or historical development and heritage of the designated area. 
(2)  Nonhistoric. Those structures not classified as exceptional, notable or valuable. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 4B, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-22. - Research of historic resources; recommendation, report. 
(a)  The commission shall: 
(1)  Compile and collect information and conduct surveys of historic resources within the city; 
(2)  Present to the mayor and council recommendations for historic districts and properties. 
(b)  Prior to the commission's recommendation of a historic district or historic property to the mayor and council for designation, the commission shall prepare a report consisting of: 
(1)  A physical description of the property or district; 
(2)  A statement of the historical, cultural, architectural and/or aesthetic significance of the property or district; 
(3)  A map showing district boundaries and classifications of individual properties therein, or showing boundaries of individual historic properties; 
(4)  A statement justifying district or individual property boundaries; and 
(5)  Representative photographs of the district or properties. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 4A, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-23. - Use of certain buildings prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any storefront building located within the historic district of the City of Fitzgerald to use any such building that is accessible only from exterior entrances solely for the storage of junk that is unrelated to the use of said property or any adjacent property owned or occupied by such person, for a continuous term of more than ninety (90) days. Each day that said property is used in such an unlawful manner shall be a separate offense. Violations of this section shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. "Junk" is defined for the purposes of this section as old iron, steel, brass, copper, tin, lead, or other base materials; old cordage, ropes, rags, bricks, or fabrics; old rubber; old bottles or other glass; bones; inactive files and business records; wastepaper and other waste or discarded material which might be prepared to be used again in some form; motor vehicles which are discarded, abandoned, inoperative, dismantled, wrecked, scrapped or ruined, or parts thereof; used furniture, clothing, household items, yard items, appliances, auto parts, toys, fixtures, and other similar items not readily available for purchase at retail on the premises. Rotating stock and inventory, files and records shall not be included within such definition, provided it is screened from public view in keeping with the historic nature of the district. 
(Ord. No. 04-1332, § 1, 2-9-04) 
Secs. 20-24-20-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 20-46. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Fitzgerald Historic Preservation Commission. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 3, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-47. - Jurisdiction. 
    The commission shall be part of the planning function of the city and the commission's jurisdiction shall be limited to the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 3, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-48. - Members. 
(a)  The commission shall consist of six (6) members appointed by mayor and council: 
(1)  Who shall be residents of the city, or who shall be residents of Ben Hill County, Georgia, who own property located within the historic district; and 
(2)  Who have demonstrated special interest, experience or education in history, architecture, or the preservation of historic resources. 
(b)  The term of office for each commission member shall be two (2) years. As there are six (6) commission members currently serving, the transition to the new terms shall be as follows: the two numbers whose terms would expire December, 1990, shall be extended to December, 1991. The two (2) members whose terms would expire December, 1992, shall remain unchanged. The two (2) members whose terms would expire December, 1993, shall expire Dec., 1992. Two (2) new commission members shall have terms that will expire December, 1991. All appointments thereafter shall be for a term of two (2) years. In the event of a vacancy, the appointment shall be for the unexpired term in the same manner as the initial appointment. 
(c)  Compensation. Members of the commission shall serve without compensation, although they may be reimbursed for expenses incurred. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 3, 10-13-86; Ord. No. 1130, § 1, 3-12-90; Ord. No. 00-1274, § 1, 10-9-00) 
Sec. 20-49. - Powers. 
    The commission shall be authorized to: 
(1)  Prepare and maintain an inventory of all property within the city having the potential for designation as historic property; 
(2)  Recommend to the mayor and council specific places, districts, buildings, structures, objects or works of art to be designated by ordinance as historic properties or historic districts; 
(3)  Review applications for certificates of appropriateness and grant or deny them in accordance with the provisions of this article; 
(4)  Recommend to the mayor and council that the designation of any place, district, site, building, structure, objects or works of art as a historic property or as a historic district or as part of a historic district be revoked or removed; 
(5)  Promote the acquisition by the city of facade easements and conservation easements in accordance with the provisions of the Facade and Conservation Easement Act of 1976; 
(6)  Conduct educational programs on historical properties located within the city and on general historic preservation activities; 
(7)  Make such investigations and studies on matters relating to historic preservation, including the consultation with historic preservation experts as the mayor and council, or the commission itself may deem necessary from time to time or appropriate for the purposes of preserving historic resources; 
(8)  Seek out local, state, federal and private funds for historic preservation and make recommendations to the mayor and council concerning the most appropriate uses of any funds acquired; 
(9)  Submit to the historic preservation section of the department of natural resources a list of historic properties or historic districts designated; 
(10)  Perform historic preservation activities as the official agency of city historic preservation programs; 
(11)  Review and make comments to the historic preservation section of the department of natural resources concerning the nomination of properties within its jurisdiction to the national registrar of historic properties; and 
(12)  Participate in private, state and federal historic preservation programs and with the consent of the mayor and council enter into agreements to do the same. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 3, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-50. - Adopting rules and standards, quorum. 
    The commission shall adopt rules and standards for the transaction of its business and for consideration of application for designations and certificates of appropriateness such as bylaws, removal of membership, provisions and designated guidelines and criteria. The commission shall have the authority to adopt rules and standards without amendment to this article. The commission shall also provide for the time and place of its regular meetings and a method for calling of special meetings. The commission shall elect such officers as it deems appropriate from among its members. A quorum of the commission shall consist of a majority of the members. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 3, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-51. - Conflict of interest. 
    At any time the commission reviews a project or application in which a member of the commission has ownership or other vested interest or that member is employed by a financial institution that may be considering financing of the project or application, that particular member shall be prohibited from voting on the particular project or application. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 3, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-52. - Meetings public, record. 
    All meetings of the commission shall be public meetings and a public record shall be kept of the commission's resolutions, proceedings and actions. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 3, 10-13-86) 
Secs. 20-53-20-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS 

Sec. 20-66. - Required. 
    A certificate of appropriateness issued by the planning director after approval by the historic preservation commission shall be required before a permit is issued for any of the following within any designated historic district or on any designated historic property: 
(1)  Demolition of a historic building; 
(2)  Moving of a historic building; 
(3)  Any material change in the exterior appearance of an existing building classified as historic by additions, reconstructions or alterations of such building or by the painting or other application of colored materials (whether or not such represents a change in the existing color) of any exterior architectural feature thereof; 
(4)  The erection or display on any lot, in any designated historic district or on any designated historic property, of any building, structure, any sign, light or other fixture. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 5, 10-13-86; Ord. No. 05-1355, § 2, 8-22-05) 
Sec. 20-67. - Application; contents. 
    Application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be made to the historic preservation commission accompanied by such sketches, drawings, photographs, descriptions or other information showing any proposed exterior alterations, additions, changes or new construction on the property in question and any additional information as is reasonably required by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 6, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-68. - Action on application. 
    The planning director shall transmit the application for a certificate of appropriateness, together with the supporting information and documents, to the commission for approval. The commission shall act upon the application within forty-five (45) days after the filing thereof. Otherwise the application shall be deemed to be approved and a certificate of appropriateness shall be issued. Nothing in this section however shall prohibit an extension of time where mutually agreed between the parties. If the commission approves the application, a certificate of appropriateness shall be issued. If the certificate of appropriateness is issued, the application shall be processed in the same manner as applications for buildings or demolition permits. If the commission denies the application, a certificate of appropriateness shall not be issued. The commission shall state its reasons for denial in writing and the city building official shall advise the applicant of the denial and the reasons therefor. Under no circumstances shall any permit for alteration, demolition or construction be issued after a certificate of appropriateness has been denied. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 7, 10-13-86; Ord. No. 1111, § 1, 7-18-88) 
Sec. 20-69. - Guidelines and criteria. 
(a)  Where considering applications for certificates of appropriateness to existing buildings, the secretary of the interior's "Standards for Historic Preservation Projects" including the secretary's "Standards for Rehabilitation" shall be used as a guideline along with any other criteria adopted and established by the commission. 
(b)  The commission will to the best of its ability make the review of certificates of appropriateness a process of negotiating with and providing guidance to property owners in designated districts and sites. The commission will attempt to negotiate certificates of appropriateness which are satisfactory to the applicant, while at the same time preserving the historic, aesthetic integrity of the property and the designated district and site of which it is a part. The goal of the commission in this review process is to preserve the city's historic, aesthetic resources, not to dictate how property owners will develop their property. 
(c)  In reviewing applications for certificates of appropriateness, the commission may consider a number of pertinent factors including historic and aesthetic significance, architectural style, general design, arrangement, texture and material of the architectural and environmental features involved and the relationship the property immediately affected and the designated district and site of which it is a part. 
(d)  The commission may make approval of a certificate of appropriateness conditional upon compliance to certain stipulations which may be listed on the certificate. Such stipulations are to be used only to diminish the adverse impact of the changes in material appearance proposed in the application for a certificate of appropriateness. Such changes may be included only if they are mutually agreed on by the commission and the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 8, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-70. - Public hearings, notice. 
    At least seven (7) days prior to the review of certificate of appropriateness, the commission shall take such action as may reasonably be required to inform the owners of any property likely to be affected by reason of the application and shall give the applicant and such owners an opportunity to be heard. All meetings of the commission to consider certificates of appropriateness shall be public hearings and shall be open to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 9, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-71. - Interior alterations. 
    In the review of applications for certificates of appropriateness, the commission shall not consider interior arrangements or alterations or use having no effect on the exterior architectural feature of the building in question. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 10, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-72. - Conformance with certificate. 
(a)  All work performed pursuant to an issued certificate of appropriateness shall conform to requirements of such certificate. If work is performed not in accordance with such certificate, the commission shall issue a cease and desist order and all work shall cease immediately. 
(b)  The mayor and council or the commission shall be authorized to institute any appropriate action or proceeding in a court of competent jurisdiction to prevent any material change in appearance of a designated historic property or historic district, except those changes made in compliance with the provisions of this article or to prevent any illegal act or conduct with respect to such historic property or historic district. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 11, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-73. - Development standards. 
    For all buildings in a designated historic area or designated historic properties rated exceptional, notable or valuable, the commission shall approve the application and issue a certificate of appropriateness if it finds that the proposed material change in appearance will not have a substantial adverse effect on the aesthetic, historic or architectural significance and value of the historic property or the historic district. In making this determination, the commission shall, in addition to all other pertinent factors, consider: 
(1)  The historic and architectural value and significance; 
(2)  Architectural style; 
(3)  General design, arrangement, texture and material of the architectural features involved; and 
(4)  The relationship thereof to the exterior architectural style and pertinent features of other structures in the immediate neighborhood. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 12, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-74. - Relocation of historic buildings. 
    Historic buildings shall not be relocated on another site unless it is shown to the satisfaction of the commission that the preservation of its existing site is impractical and creates an undue burden on the owners. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 13, 10-13-86) 
Secs. 20-75, 20-76. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1102, adopted Oct. 12, 1987, deleted § 14 of Ord. No. 1093, adopted Oct. 13, 1986, from which former §§ 20-75 and 20-76 were derived. Such former sections pertained to nonhistoric buildings within designated historic areas. 
Sec. 20-77. - Undue hardship. 
    Where, by reason of unusual circumstances, the strict application of any provision of this article would result in the exceptional practical difficulty or undue hardship upon any owner of a specific property, the commission, in passing upon applications, may vary or modify strict adherence to such provisions or may interpret the meaning of such provisions so as to relieve such difficulty or hardship; provided such variances, modifications or interpretations shall remain in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this article and so that the architectural or historical integrity or character of the property shall be conserved and substantial justice done. In granting variances, the commission may impose such reasonable and additional stipulations and conditions as will, in its judgment, best fulfill the purpose of this article. An undue hardship shall be a situation not of the person's own making pertaining to their financial means or the fitness of the property for preservation. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 15, 10-13-86) 
Sec. 20-78. - Appeal of commission decisions. 
(a)  Any person adversely affected by any determination made by the commission relative to the issuance or denial of a certificate of appropriateness may appeal such determination to the mayor and council. The mayor and council may approve, modify or reject the decision of the commission if the mayor and council finds that the commission abused its discretion in reaching its decision. 
(b)  The application for such an appeal shall be filed with the city administrator within thirty (30) days of the decision of the commission stating the findings of the commission, and the applicant's reasons for disagreement with such findings. 
(Ord. No. 1093, § 16, 10-13-86) 
Secs. 20-79-20-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY-COUNTY PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 20-96. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Planning commission means the Fitzgerald-Ben Hill County Planning Commission. 
Cross reference- Definitions; rules of construction generally, § 1-2; administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 20-97. - Membership; terms; filling vacancies; removal; compensation. 
    The planning commission shall consist of ten (10) members, all such members shall be residents of Ben Hill County, Georgia. Five (5) of the members shall be appointed by the mayor and council, and five (5) of the members of the commission shall be appointed by the board of commissioners of the county. The terms of members shall be for five (5) years, excepting that in the appointment of the first planning commission under the terms of this article two (2) of the county-appointed members shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years, two (2) county-appointed members shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years, and one (1) county-appointed member shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years; and one (1) of the city-appointed members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, and two (2) members of the city-appointed members shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years, and two (2) members of the city-appointed members shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and council, which shall have the authority to remove any city-appointed member for cause, on written charges, after public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(Code 1966, § 21-1; Ord. No. 18-1517, § 1, 5-14-18) 
Sec. 20-98. - Election of chairman. 
    The planning commission shall elect its chairman from its members. 
(Code 1966, § 21-2) 
Sec. 20-99. - Term of chairman. 
    The term of the chairman of the planning commission shall be one (1) year with eligibility for reelection, and he shall serve until his successor has been duly elected and qualified. 
(Code 1966, § 21-3) 
Sec. 20-100. - Secretary. 
    The planning commission may appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the city or county. 
(Code 1966, § 21-4) 
Sec. 20-101. - Rules of procedure; time of meetings. 
    The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. 
(Code 1966, § 21-5) 
Sec. 20-102. - Meetings, records to be public. 
    All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the commission shall be a public record. However, after a public hearing, the commission is authorized to formulate and make its decisions in executive session after which its findings shall be made public and shall be a public record. 
(Code 1966, § 21-6) 
Sec. 20-103. - Staff; purchases. 
    The planning commission may appoint such employees, consultants, legal counsel and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with municipal planners and other planning and zoning consultants for such services as it may require, and may purchase such supplies and equipment as are necessary. 
(Code 1966, § 21-7) 
Sec. 20-104. - Limitation on expenditures. 
    The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated by the governing bodies of the city and the county. 
(Code 1966, § 21-8) 
Sec. 20-105. - Powers, duties. 
    The planning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the General Enabling Act of 1957 as amended, being Georgia Acts 1957 and 1958, Chapter 69-12 of the 1933 Code of Georgia, authorizing planning commissions. 
(Code 1966, § 21-9) 
Secs. 20-106-20-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SOUTH GEORGIA AREA PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 

Sec. 20-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commission means the South Georgia Area Planning and Development Commission. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2; administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 20-122. - Purpose; created. 
    In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the municipality and the southeast Georgia area which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the South Georgia Area Planning and Development Commission is hereby created and established as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 69-2101, as amended, and the commission shall be organized and empowered as provided in this article. 
(Code 1966, § 21-20) 
Sec. 20-123. - Membership. 
    The commission shall consist of two (2) members from each of the counties participating in the commission. Of the two (2) members from each county, one (1) shall be appointed by the governing authority of the municipality wherein the county seat is located, and the other member shall be appointed by the governing authority of such county. 
(Code 1966, § 21-21) 
Sec. 20-124. - Term of office. 
    The term of office for all members of the commission shall be five (5) years, and the initial appointment by the mayor and council of the city shall be for a term of five (5) years. 
(Code 1966, § 21-22) 
Sec. 20-125. - Filling vacancies. 
    Any vacancy in the membership of the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term by the governing authority making the appointment which has become vacant. 
(Code 1966, § 21-23) 
Sec. 20-126. - Removal of members. 
    The appointing authority of a commission position shall also have the power to remove any member of the commission it may appoint for cause, on written charges, after public hearing. 
(Code 1966, § 21-24) 
Sec. 20-127. - Compensation. 
    All members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1966, § 21-25) 
Sec. 20-128. - Election of chairman, vice-chairman. 
    The commission shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman from among its appointive members. 
(Code 1966, § 21-26) 
Sec. 20-129. - Term of office of chairman, vice-chairman. 
    The term of office of the chairman and vice-chairman of the commission shall be for one (1) year or until reelected or their successors are elected. 
(Code 1966, § 21-27) 
Sec. 20-130. - Secretary. 
    The commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an employee of the commission. 
(Code 1966, § 21-28) 
Sec. 20-131. - Meetings, rules of procedure, public records. 
    The commission shall meet at least once each month at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the chairman or board may determine, shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a public record. 
(Code 1966, § 21-29) 
Sec. 20-132. - Employees, staff. 
    The commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work. 
(Code 1966, § 21-30) 
Sec. 20-133. - Cooperative agreements. 
    In the performance of its duties, the commission may cooperate with, contract with or accept funds from federal, state or local public or semipublic agencies or private individuals or corporations, may spend such funds, and may carry out such cooperative undertakings and contracts. 
(Code 1966, § 21-31) 
Sec. 20-134. - Purchases authorized. 
    The commission may make expenditures for the purchase of required equipment and supplies. 
(Code 1966, § 21-32) 
Sec. 20-135. - Limitation on expenditures. 
    The expenditures of the commission, exclusive of gifts to the commission and contract receipts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the participating governing authorities. 
(Code 1966, § 21-33) 
Sec. 20-136. - Powers and duties. 
    It shall be the function and duty of the commission to make such careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future developments and to prepare such plans for physical, social and economic growth as will best promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, prosperity or the general welfare as well as efficiency and economy in the development of the entire Southeast Georgia area and each political subdivision therein. In general, the commission shall have such powers and duties and responsibilities as set forth in the General Planning Enabling Act of 1957, as amended, being Chapter 69-12 of the Code of Georgia. 
(Code 1966, § 21-34) 
Chapter 21 - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Railroad companies, O.C.G.A. Title 46, Ch. 8. 

Sec. 21-1. - Speed of trains. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or allow the operation of any train or part thereof at a speed in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour on or across any street or public place in the city. 
(Code 1966, § 26-1) 
Sec. 21-2. - Rolling loose cars at crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful to cause or allow a train or part thereof to uncouple or become detached and thereby allow such part to run on by its own momentum on or across any street or public place in the city without being attached to an engine under charge of a competent engineer and equipped with adequate brakes. 
(Code 1966, § 26-2) 
Sec. 21-3. - Obstructing crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful to cause or allow any part of a train to be detached and left standing alone upon any tracks in the city, or to allow any such part or piece of equipment to project over or obstruct any street or sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1966, § 26-3) 
Cross reference- Obstructing public ways, § 27-2. 
Sec. 21-4. - Crossing warning signs required. 
    Whenever the tracks or line of any railroad cross a street or highway signs of such size and dimensions as may be prescribed by the mayor and council shall be installed on posts to be erected on the right side of such street at the curbline on each side of such crossing and not less than ten (10) feet from the nearest rail, on which signs shall be painted in black letters upon a white background the words "Stop-City Ordinance-R. R. Crossing." 
(Code 1966, § 26-4) 
Sec. 21-5. - Precautions required when backing over crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful to back any railroad train, locomotive, cars or other equipment across a street crossing unless there is at such crossing a flagman, or unless the crossing is protected by electrical warning devices of a type approved by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1966, § 26-6) 
Sec. 21-6. - Duty to construct, maintain street crossings. 
    All railroads having tracks within the city are required to construct and maintain street crossings in accordance with the specifications of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1966, § 26-7) 
Sec. 21-7. - Notice to construct street crossings. 
    The police chief, under the instructions of the city administrator, shall serve notice in writing upon the railroads having lines in the city directing the railroads to put in the crossings as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1966, § 26-8) 
Sec. 21-8. - Jumping, trespassing on trains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than an employee of the railroad to jump on or off any train while in motion or to otherwise trespass upon a train within the city. 
(Code 1966, § 26-10) 
Sec. 21-9. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Train means and includes a railroad engine or propelling unit with or without cars attached, and shall include two (2) or more railroad cars when attached together, whether or not there shall be an engine or propelling unit attached thereto. 
    Vehicular traffic means all motorized traffic upon the streets of the City of Fitzgerald, not including trains or railroad cars. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 1, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-10. - Blocking streets. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or to operate the same so that it shall stop in an intersection with a public street with in the City of Fitzgerald longer than ten (10) minutes including the time such train is in motion and the time such train is stopped. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 2, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-11. - Same-Leaving crossing gates down. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for any railroad company or corporation to allow crossing gates maintained or operated by such company or corporation at any intersection of its tracks with any public street in the City of Fitzgerald to remain down so as to control traffic upon such street for an uninterrupted period of time longer than ten (10) minutes, regardless or whether or not a train or railroad car is, or has been, within the area of such intersection within such period of time. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 3, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-12. - Same-Leaving warning device activated. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for any railroad company or corporation to allow any warning device maintained or operated by such company or corporation and installed to control vehicular traffic at any intersection of its tracks with any public street in the City of Fitzgerald to remain active so as to control vehicular traffic upon any such street for an uninterrupted period of time longer than ten (10) minutes, regardless of whether or not a train or trains, or railroad car or cars are, or have been, within the area of such intersection within such period of time. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 4, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-13. - Same-Switching or other intracity transit. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or to operate the same while engaged in local switching or any other intracity transit in such a manner as to prevent the use of any street within the City of Fitzgerald for purposes of travel for a period of longer than five (5) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 5, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-14. - Same-Clearing in case of fire alarm. 
    In case of fire alarms, railroad crossings shall be immediately cleared. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 6, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-15. - Flagman or brakeman during switching, etc. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for any railroad officer or employee in charge of any train passing through the City of Fitzgerald to allow such train to be "switched," "made up," or "drilled," within the City of Fitzgerald, without having a flagman or brakeman placed in front of the engine or train of cars, the term "front" as used herein to mean the foremost unit, whether powered or not, in the direction of travel of such train. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 7, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-16. - Kicking cars or flying switch. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for any employee or officer of a railroad company or corporation to "kick" cars, or perform what is known in railroad parlance as "the flying switch" on any main line or side track or railroad yard in the City of Fitzgerald. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 8, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-17. - Crossings to be kept in repair. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of all railroad companies or corporations running or operating a line of a railroad in and through the City of Fitzgerald to place and keep in good repair all of its railroad track public street crossings by placing plank, other timbers or approved materials on each side of the rails of the roads and the rails of each side track so as to raise the entire space of the crossings between the rails to the level of the rails and fill in between the tracks of the roads or side tracks with gravel, asphalt or other approved material, for the whole space of the streets and sidewalks across which such tracks may run or operate so as to render the same of safe and easy passage to pedestrians and vehicles of all kinds. 
(b)  Should any railroad company or corporation owning or operating a line of railroad through the said city fail or refuse to place or keep in good repair any public street crossing on its line of road within the said city, it shall be the duty of the chief of police of said city to give the agent of the railroad company or corporation, so defaulting, notice in writing or otherwise, that within ten (10) days, the city will proceed to have such work executed at the expense of the railroad company or corporation. 
(c)  The person opening or repairing such crossings shall, as soon as the work is completed, render to the city clerk an itemized, sworn statement of the cost of such work, whereupon the clerk shall immediately issue an execution for said amount against the defaulting company or corporation, which shall be levied by the chief of police against property of said company or corporation and the property sold by him under the same rules and regulations as govern judicial sales. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 9, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-18. - Persons permitted to get on or off trains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to get on or off any train within the City of Fitzgerald while said train is in motion or otherwise, except on business. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 10, 4-11-05) 
Sec. 21-19. - Excused acts. 
    No act which is caused by breakdown of equipment or other mishap, nor any act done to prevent personal injuries or property damage, shall be a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 05-1348, § 11, 4-11-05) 
Chapter 22 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; garbage, trash and weeds, Ch. 12; housing, Ch. 14; planning and development, Ch. 20; utilities, Ch. 23; subdivisions, App. A. 
State Law reference- Municipal street systems generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Town plats adopted. 
(a)  In the year 1895, there was filed in the office of the clerk of the Superior Court of Irwin County, Georgia, by the American Tribune Soldiers Colony Company a plot or plan of a town site platted by such company and situate, lying and being in land lots one hundred twenty (120) and one hundred twenty-one (121) of the third land district, and land lots three hundred (300) and three hundred and one (301) of the fourth land districts in such county, which platted town site was designated by the company as "City of Fitzgerald," and on the plot or plan of the town site the company designated and named various avenues, streets and alleys and dedicated their use to the public as public streets, avenues and alleys for which purpose they have ever since been used, and such town site is now embraced within the corporate limits of the City of Fitzgerald. 
(b)  In the year 1896, the Colony Company further filed in the clerk's office a plot or plan of land surveyed by the company now situate, lying and being within the corporate limits of the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia, and outside of the town site plat, referred to in subsection (a), which lands were surveyed and divided into tracts of five (5) acres each, and such plot or plans of five-acre tracts as filed contain various streets and alleys as shown on plats which streets and alleys have always been used by the public as public streets since the filing of the plat. 
(c)  Each and every one of the avenues, streets and alleys as shown by the town site plat and the five-acre tract plat now within the corporate limits of the city and such avenues and streets shall be officially known and designated by the names given them by the Colony Company and designated on the plats. 
(Code 1966, § 27-1) 
Sec. 22-2. - Obstructing public ways. 
    Except as otherwise provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to place, erect or maintain any obstruction in or on any street, sidewalk or public way in the city so as to impede travel or passage over said streets, sidewalks or public ways. 
(Code 1966, § 27-2) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 22-3. - Temporary obstructions. 
(a)  Any person desiring to obstruct a street, sidewalk or public way temporarily, such as during the course of building operations or while loading or unloading merchandise, may do so upon obtaining special permission. If the obstruction is incidental for or arises out of building operations, the permission will be granted by the building official, if for some other reason, it will be granted by the police chief. The building official or police chief may impose such regulations as he deems appropriate in granting such permission, such as but not limited to: 
(1)  The extent or size of the obstruction. 
(2)  The maximum duration of the obstruction. 
(3)  The type of obstruction. 
(4)  Required safety precautions such as barricades, lights, warning devices, etc. 
(b)  The violation of any such regulation shall be a misdemeanor, and furthermore shall be grounds for revocation of the permission. 
(Code 1966, § 27-3) 
Sec. 22-4. - Obstructing drainage. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the flow of water in any gutter, street or alley of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 27-4) 
Cross reference- Obstructing drains, § 15-27. 
Sec. 22-5. - Outdoor dining. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, outdoor dining areas shall be permitted on a public sidewalk area provided that said outdoor dining area: 
(1)  Shall be immediately adjacent to and directly abutting a restaurant located in a building; 
(2)  Shall be arranged so as to provide, at all times, least a five-foot wide contiguous pedestrian pathway free from obstructions in the sidewalk and no portion of such outdoor dining area shall be placed in any portion of the sidewalk that lies within the five-foot wide area measured perpendicular from the edge of the sidewalk closest to the street or roadway: 
a.  In the event a permanent obstruction including but not limited to a utility pole, tree well or fire hydrant is located within the five-foot wide pedestrian pathway, a five-foot wide pedestrian pathway free from obstruction shall be maintained measured perpendicular from the edge of such obstruction farthest from the street or roadway. 
(3)  No outdoor dining areas are permitted in any section of the sidewalk that is less than five (5) feet wide. 
(b)  All tables, chairs, umbrellas, and other similar items used in an outdoor dining area shall be stored in the interior of the restaurant or in a similar enclosed area so that the entire sidewalk is unobstructed when the outdoor dining area is not in use. 
(c)  Outdoor dining areas may only be open during the business hours of the adjacent restaurant. 
(Ord. No. 14-1447, § 1, 3-10-14) 
Sec. 22-6. - Enforcement. 
    Any person or entity violating or failing to comply with any of the terms of this article shall be subject to fine in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each and every day such person or entity shall be in violation of this article. Said violations shall be in the jurisdiction of the Municipal Court of the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 14-1447, § 1, 3-10-14) 
Sec. 22-7. - Mailboxes-General requirements. 
(a)  All mailboxes, whether installed on public or private streets, shall comply with the United States Postal Services standards for the construction of mailboxes. 
(b)  Non-yielding and non-breakaway mailbox structures will not be allowed within the clear zone. The use of concrete filled metal pipe for any mailboxes, or the use of horizontally mounted wooden members to support multiple mailboxes is expressly prohibited. 
(c)  The property owner shall be responsible for the maintenance and repair of the curbside mailbox. 
(d)  Lateral placement of the mailbox shall be no more than six (6) inches from the face of the curb or edge of pavement (if no curb and gutter is present) as defined by USPS installation requirements. 
(e)  In no case shall the face of the mailbox extend out over the face of the curb or edge of the pavement (if no curb is present). 
(f)  Mailboxes shall not be constructed in any location that may block or in any way impair or obstruct visibility. 
(g)  The location and installation of cluster box units shall be approved by the city building inspector prior to installing the units. 
(Ord. No. 15-1468, § 1, 9-14-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-1468, § 1, adopted September 14, 2015, set out provisions intended for use as § 22-5. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 22-7. 
Secs. 22-8-22-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 

Sec. 22-21. - Material. 
    All sidewalks shall be constructed of such material as the mayor and council may designate. 
(Code 1966, § 27-20) 
Sec. 22-22. - Notice requiring construction. 
    Whenever the mayor and council pass resolutions authorizing the construction of sidewalks along any of the streets of the city, the city clerk shall and is hereby authorized and directed to serve written notice upon the owner, agent or occupant of the lots abutting upon the sidewalk to be constructed, by mailing the notice in a properly addressed envelope, notifying such owner to immediately proceed with construction of the sidewalks, at an elevation level with the center of the streets next adjacent to such sidewalks. 
(Code 1966, § 27-21) 
Sec. 22-23. - Duty of property owner or occupant to construct; construction by city. 
    When notice has been served on the owner or occupant of the property adjacent to the sidewalks such owner shall have the right to construct within thirty (30) days the sidewalk according to the specifications provided. If the owner or occupant fails to comply with the notice, it shall be the duty of the street commissioner to use the street force or city prisoners in the construction of the sidewalk in accordance with the plans provided and make a written report of the cost to the mayor and council. 
(Code 1966, § 27-22) 
Sec. 22-24. - Apportionment of costs when city constructs. 
    When a report of the cost of city constructed sidewalks has been filed with the mayor and council by the street commissioner, it shall be the duty of the finance committee to apportion and assess one-third of the cost of the work to the city and two-thirds to the abutting property owner along such sidewalks where such improvements may have been made as provided in this article. 
(Code 1966, § 27-23) 
Sec. 22-25. - Assessment, collection of construction costs. 
    When assessments have been made of the cost of sidewalk improvements against property owners and prorated by the finance committee and assessed by the mayor and council, the city clerk shall prepare a list of the property owners whose property abuts on portions of the sidewalk improved and shall mail to each of such property owners or holders a written notice of the list in a properly stamped and addressed envelope, together with the amount of cost assessed against each, which amount shall be paid within thirty (30) days after such notice. If any property holder shall fail to pay to the city clerk his pro rata share of the cost in accordance with the city's assessment, then the city clerk shall issue an execution against such delinquent property holder for the amount due and unpaid, together with all costs therein. Such execution shall bind and be a lien upon the abutting property of the delinquent and shall be a superior lien to all other liens except taxes upon the property. The police chief shall proceed to levy and advertise the property of the delinquent property holder as provided for tax sales. The lien in favor of the city shall be a lien against the property abutting upon the portions of the sidewalks improved pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1966, § 27-24) 
Sec. 22-26. - Repairs; notice. 
    Whenever any sidewalk or portion thereof shall need repairing the street commissioner shall at once notify the owner of the abutting property, provided the owner is a resident of the city, to repair the sidewalk at once. If the repairs are not made according to the specifications of the mayor and council and the order of the street commissioner within twenty-four (24) hours after the service of the notice, the street commissioner shall proceed to make the repairs, reporting the cost thereof to the city clerk who shall tax the cost against the abutting property. 
(Code 1966, § 27-25) 
Sec. 22-27. - Discrete accounts. 
    The city treasurer shall keep separate and apart from all other accounts of the city the account showing the cost of constructing or repairing sidewalks as provided in this article. 
(Code 1966, § 27-26) 
Sec. 22-28. - Contest of assessments. 
    Whenever executions have been issued on assessments for sidewalk construction or repair, the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit denying that the whole or any part of the amount for which the execution issued is due and stating what amount he admits to be due. Such amount admitted to be due with all costs shall be paid and collected before the affidavit is received by the police chief and the affidavit shall be received for the balance unpaid. Such affidavit so received shall be returned to the superior court of the county and there tried and the issue determined as in cases of illegality subject to all of the penalties provided in cases of illegality for delay. 
(Code 1966, § 27-27) 
Secs. 22-29-22-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NUMBERING BUILDINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. 

Sec. 22-46. - Philadelphia system adopted. 
    The system known as the "Philadelphia System" shall be used and adopted by the city in numbering buildings in the city. 
(Code 1966, § 27-38) 
Sec. 22-47. - Base lines established. 
    For the purpose of numbering buildings the city is divided into four (4) sections by Main Street running north and south, and Central Avenue running east and west, beginning at the intersection of such streets. 
(Code 1966, § 27-39) 
Sec. 22-48. - Numbering of lots on right and left hand sides of first and second squares. 
    The lots on the right hand side of the first square shall be numbered 101, 103, 105, etc., the lots on the second square being numbered 201, 203, 205, etc., each lot being numbered. The lots on the left hand side for the first square shall be 102, 104, 106, etc., and on the second square 202, 204, 206, etc., the squares on the north, south, east and west being respectively designated by numerals, 1, 2, 3, 4, etc. 
(Code 1966, § 27-40) 
Sec. 22-49. - Numbering of lots in remainder of city. 
    All lots outside of the four (4) drives shall be numbered in accordance with the "centerline method." The building inspector of the city shall assign all property with street numbers in accordance with this system and shall notify each property owner as to the street numbers assigned to all property fronting on public roads outside of and beyond the four (4) drives. 
(Ord. No. 1145, § 9-9-91) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1145, adopted Sept. 9, 1991, repealed § 22-49 and enacted a new § 22-49 relative to similar subject matter in lieu thereof. The repealed provisions derived from Code 1966, § 27-41. 
Sec. 22-50. - Marking of buildings on rear of lots. 
    All buildings upon the rear of city lots upon being numbered shall be marked "R" in addition to the number upon the front of such lot. 
(Code 1966, § 27-42) 
Sec. 22-51. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1145, adopted Sept. 9, 1991, repealed former § 22-51, which pertained to size and location of numbers and to the requirement of building numbers, and derived from Code 1966, § 27-43. 
Sec. 22-52. - Approval of numbers. 
    For the purpose of securing uniformity in numbering buildings in the city, no person shall be permitted to number his buildings unless the numbering is done by permit of the city administrator, or by someone authorized by the city administrator to number buildings. 
(Code 1966, § 27-44) 
Sec. 22-53. - All improvements of land in city to have street number. 
    All improvements of land within the city limits shall have a street number. Those within the four (4) drives of the city shall use the Philadelphia System and those outside the four (4) drives of the city shall use the centerline method. The building inspector of the city shall have the primary responsibility for the enforcement of this article and the determination of each number to be used for each lot or parcel of land. Should anyone object to the decision of the building inspector in this connection, an appeal is hereby permitted to the mayor and council of the city, who shall make a final determination in this regard. The owners of all properties within the city limits shall post the number or numbers assigned by the building inspector so that such numbers are clearly visible from the public road which the property abuts. The numbers shall be four (4) inches high and shall have contrasting background. 
(Ord. No. 1145, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 22-54. - Enforcement. 
    Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the terms of this article shall be subject to fine in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each and every day such person shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1145, 9-9-91) 
Secs. 22-55-22-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CHANGING THE NAME OF EXISTING STREETS 

Sec. 22-60. - Title and purpose. 
    This article shall be known as the "changing the name of existing streets" article and may be referred to by that title. The City of Fitzgerald recognizes that, from time to time, a certain individual, business, or organization may make historical, cultural, or other important contributions to the City of Fitzgerald, State of Georgia or the United States that merit recognition in the form of renaming a street within the city in such individuals honor. This article prescribes the protocol and procedure by which existing streets or public places within the City of Fitzgerald may be renamed in honor of the aforementioned deserving individuals, businesses, or organizations, while at the same time, preserving the integrity of those existing streets and public places that have already been historically named or dedicated. 
(Ord. No. 13-1439, § 1, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 22-61. - Authority. 
    The mayor and council shall have the sole power and authority to change the name of existing streets and dedications of existing public places located within the incorporated limits of the city where such streets are owned by the City of Fitzgerald. 
(Ord. No. 13-1439, § 1, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 22-62. - Procedures. 
    With respect to the changing of the name of an existing street or dedication of a public place owned by the city and located within the corporate limits of the City of Fitzgerald, the mayor and council shall be required to follow the following procedures with respect to the changing of the name of an existing street: 
(1)  By application of a citizen or group of citizens. 
a.  A citizen or group of city citizens may submit an application to change the name of an existing street hereunder. Such application shall be on forms prescribed by the city clerk. Such application shall not be considered unless at least seventy-five (75) percent of the persons owning real property abutting such existing street submit a written application to the city clerk requesting that the name of such existing street be changed. 
b.  Such application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), which is intended to cover administrative and other costs which are anticipated to be incurred by the city in connection with its consideration of the application. Such application fee shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
c.  The mayor and council of the city shall consider such application and act thereon in accord with this division no later than one hundred eighty (180) calendar days after the date of submission of such application to the city clerk. 
d.  Upon receipt of the application by the city clerk, the city clerk shall proceed to validate the application. The city clerk shall validate the application by verifying that the proper number of signatures is contained on the application and that the persons signing the application are owners of real property abutting said street as required by this division. In the event that the city clerk determines that the application is invalid for any reason, or that the application does not contain sufficient signatures, the application shall be returned to the person or persons submitting such application, and it shall not be subject to further consideration by the mayor and council until such time as a new application is submitted and the city clerk validates the new application. 
e.  In determining the required percentage of the persons signing such application in connection with the validation thereof, where property abutting such street is owned by more than one (1) person, the signature of only one (1) such owner shall be counted in calculating such seventy-five (75) percent. In addition, persons who rent or lease real property abutting such street may sign such application, but their signatures shall not be counted toward the seventy-five (75) percent threshold for submission of the application to the mayor and council. Signatures on any such application signed more than ninety (90) calendar days prior to the date of submission of the application to the city clerk shall be invalid and shall not be counted toward the seventy-five (75) percent threshold. In the event that more than one (1) application for changing the name of an existing street is presented to the city clerk, the city clerk shall validate such applications in the order received. The first application validated by the city clerk shall be presented to the mayor and council first, and only if the resolution to approve the application is denied shall the city clerk present the second or subsequent validated application to the mayor and council. 
f.  The application shall be in such form as established by the city clerk. At a minimum, the application shall indicate thereon the location of the street, the proposed new name of the street, the printed name, street address, and signature of each property owner signing such application, and the date that each property owner signed the application. In addition, each such application shall include therewith a written statement which provides, in succinct detail, the reasons for the proposed street name change in honor of a particular person or business listed in the application. In providing such written statement, the criteria to be considered by the mayor and council regarding the changing of the name of such street as more particularly established in this division shall be specifically addressed by the application in such written statement accompanying the street name changing application. In addition, the application shall also list any public announcement or public recognition request that should accompany any official street name changing ceremony undertaken by the city in connection with the changing of the name of such street. 
g.  In the event that the city clerk determines that the application is valid, then prior to the submission of the application to the mayor and council, the city clerk shall undertake the following: 
1.  Provide notification of the application to and compile for review by the mayor and council responses to the application from the following: 
i.  All city agencies and departments, including, but not limited to city police, city fire, EMS, code enforcement, water, light and bond, and any other city agencies or departments that the clerk deems appropriate; 
ii.  All other local, state, or national agencies which the city clerk determines may be affected by the changing of the name of the street; 
iii.  The Ben Hill County Board of Education; 
iv.  Any other persons or entities the city clerk deems, in his or her sole discretion, should receive notice of the proposed changing of the street's name. 
v.  Said notified agencies and departments shall respond to said notice within fourteen days of receipt of said notice. Said response shall include said agency or department's position regarding name change and support for said position. 
2.  Review existing public records for the purpose of establishing that the proposed name does not duplicate any existing street name and is not confusingly similar to any existing street name in the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia or Ben Hill County, Georgia. 
h.  Upon the completion of the foregoing, the city clerk shall be required to place consideration of the application on the agenda for a city council meeting within ninety (90) days from the date the application was finally validated. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the tabling of such proposal by the mayor and council, but in no event shall consideration of such proposal by the city council be delayed beyond one hundred eighty (180) calendar days after the validated application was filed with the city clerk. 
i.  Prior to the mayor and council considering or voting upon such application, the mayor and council shall hold a public hearing regarding such application. Notice of such public hearing shall be published once in the city's legal organ no later than the day prior to the date of the public hearing. Not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the date set for the public hearing signage displaying public notice hereinafter described shall be erected on along the street of the proposed renaming. Such sign shall be erected within ten (10) feet of said street in such a manner as may be readily seen by the public. Such public notice shall advise the public regarding the application, the proposed new street name, and the time and place of the scheduled public hearing before the mayor and council. Such public hearing shall be conducted with the same formality as that required of public hearings in connection with zoning and rezoning matters before the mayor and council. Upon conclusion of the public hearing, the mayor and council shall be authorized to vote on the application. 
j.  In the event that the application is approved by an appropriate resolution of the mayor and council, the new name of the street shall take effect at such time as is determined by the mayor and council in such resolution. 
k.  Upon adoption of the resolution by the mayor and council, the city clerk shall undertake the following: 
1.  Provide written notice to each property owner owning property abutting the street of the official name of the street as approved by the mayor and council; 
2.  Provide written notice of the new name of the street to the United States Postal Service; 
3.  Provide written notice of the new name of the street to the emergency 911 system in effect for the geographical area including the City of Fitzgerald. 
l.  Within ninety (90) calendar days of the effective date of the resolution adopting the new street name, the city public works director shall have fabricated and installed appropriate signage regarding the new name of the street at such locations as deemed appropriate by the public works director. 
1.  All costs, including the cost of signage, will be the responsibility of the petitioners and supporting property owners. 
(Ord. No. 13-1439, § 1, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 22-63. - Determination of renaming. 
(a)  Any application for the renaming of any street within the original bounds of the City of Fitzgerald, as shown by that certain plat of survey made by or for the American Tribune Soldiers Colony Company of file in the Office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Irwin County, Georgia, more specifically the original sixteen city blocks therein and all streets passing through and contained within the bounds of Merrimac Drive, Sultana Drive, Monitor Drive, and Roanoke Drive, shall not be considered. 
(b)  In making a determination as to changing the name of an existing street, if the street is proposed to be renamed after a natural person, the mayor and council shall take into consideration the following: 
(1)  Whether such person has resided for a long period of time on such street; 
(2)  Whether such person has made significant and long-lasting contributions to the city and its citizens; 
(3)  Whether such person is a nationally or internationally prominent figure who has or may have a direct or indirect connection to the city and its citizens; 
(4)  Whether such person has provided charitable or philanthropic contributions to the city and its citizens; 
(5)  Whether such person has brought honor, prestige, or recognition in a positive manner to the city and its citizens; 
(6)  Whether such person is a leader in local governmental, civic, educational, or public affairs; or 
(7)  Whether such person is a distinguished and accomplished scholar, scientist, educational leader, business leader, government leader, or civic leader. 
(8)  In order to be considered for having an existing street renamed named after a person, such person may be either living or deceased at the time that the street name is changed. With respect to a deceased individual, the application shall not be submitted until at least one (1) year after the date of death of such person. With respect to a living person, such person must have reached the age of seventy-five (75) years at the time of the submission of the application, unless such age limitation is affirmatively waived by the mayor and council of the city within thirty (30) calendar days after the filing of the application. 
(c)  In the event that consideration is given to changing the name of an existing street so as to name such existing street after a business, an organization, or a nonprofit entity, the mayor and council of the city shall consider the following: 
(1)  Whether such entity is located upon such street; 
(2)  The length of time that such entity has been located on such street; 
(3)  The length of time that such entity has been located within the city; 
(4)  The civic, community, and educational contributions of the business to the city and its citizens; or 
(5)  The length of time that such entity is expected to remain in business under the same name on such street; 
(6)  No street shall be named after any ongoing business, organization, or nonprofit entity which is not located upon the street to be renamed in honor of such entity. 
(d)  In addition to the foregoing factors to be considered by the mayor and council in changing the name of an existing street, the mayor and council shall also be authorized to consider any and all other relevant factors that the mayor and council deems appropriate in making a street naming decision. 
(e)  No applications proposing to change the name of only a portion of a street shall be accepted by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 13-1439, § 1, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 22-64 - Prohibitions. 
    Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit or interfere with the right of the State of Georgia or the Georgia Department of Transportation to name or dedicate roads or streets under their respective ownership or jurisdiction in such manner as they may be authorized to do in accord with Georgia law or regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 13-1439, § 1, 4-22-13) 
Secs. 22-65-22-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SALES AND DISPLAYS OF GOODS AND/OR MERCHANDISE IN OR ON PUBLIC SIDEWALKS AND PROPERTY 

Sec. 22-70. - Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, business or company to offer merchandise or goods for sale, display merchandise or goods, or conduct general vending of merchandise or goods upon public property without a permit.
