    In the maintenance and operation of its television transmission and distribution system in the streets, alleys, and other public places, and in the course of any new construction or addition to its facilities, the company shall proceed so as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the general public; any opening or obstruction in the streets or other public places made by the company in the course of its operations shall be made only after having obtained the prior written permission from the City of Fitzgerald to do so, and shall be guarded and protected at all times by the placement of adequate barriers, fences, or boardings, the bounds of which, during periods of dusk and darkness shall be clearly designated by appropriate warning lights. All work in any way necessitated by the business of the company which may involve the opening, breaking up or tearing up a portion of a street, sidewalk or other part of any city owned or city controlled property, shall be done and repaired in a manner approved by the City of Fitzgerald, and may be done by the city at the expense of the cable operator, if mutually agreed upon by the City of Fitzgerald and the company. The company shall maintain said repairs in a condition approved by the city for a period of one (1) year thereafter. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-5) 
Sec. 6. - Installations. 
    Installation shall be maintained so as not to interfere with TV reception already in existence. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-6) 
Sec. 7. - Time for compliance. 
    The company shall provide a television cable system capable of carrying a minimum of twelve (12) viewing channels to every subscriber within twelve (12) months after the effective date hereof. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-7) 
Sec. 8. - Rates and charges. 
    All rates and charges enacted by the company shall be subject to approval by the City of Fitzgerald, and shall be fair, reasonable, just and be uniform; provided, however, that the foregoing shall not be construed to prohibit the company from having different rates for designated classifications of subscribers so long as all subscribers of such classification shall qualify for such rates. The installation or reconnection fee shall not exceed ten dollars ($10.00) per outlet. For as long as the current five-channel service is provided, the monthly service rate charged to a subscriber shall not exceed five dollars and ninety-five cents ($5.95) for a single outlet residential installation or one dollar ($1.00) for each additional outlet. Upon the full performance by the company of all of the following, the monthly service rate charge to a subscriber shall be permitted to increase to seven dollars [and] fifty cents ($7.50) for a single outlet residential installation and one dollar ($1.00) for each additional outlet: 
(a)  The rebuilding of the existing cable system by replacing all cable where necessary to meet broadband (twelve-channel) specifications; 
(b)  The replacement of all existing low band tube-type amplifiers with broadband (twelve-channel minimum capacity) transistor amplifiers; 
(c)  The furnishing and installation of all required associated equipment to operate the transistor amplifiers, such as a thirty-volt power supply unit, power combiners, etc.; 
(d)  The furnishing and installation of auxiliary power at the tower location to accommodate all control equipment and the first main line amplifier from the tower; 
(e)  The furnishing and installation of receiving antennas and all associated channel processing equipment to add off air reception of Channel 41, WCWB (NBC) Macon, and Channel 3, WRBL (CBS-NBC) Columbus, Georgia; 
(f)  The furnishing and installation of a local video-weather machine which will operate twenty-four (24) hours a day and carry continuous information, such as time, barometric pressure, wind direction, wind velocity, etc., and which will carry FM music from a reliable source; 
(g)  The building of a new cable system extension to serve all desiring residents of the city located within the corporate limits thereof as now and hereafter existing; 
(h)  Furnishing and installation of microwave equipment and channel processing equipment and the addition of the following Atlanta channels, namely: Channel 2, WSB (NBC), Channel 5, WAGA (CBS), Channel 11, WXIA (ABC), and Channel 17, WTCG (independent); provided, however, that such microwave and processing equipment shall be required to provide, at any given time, not more than three (3) of the said Atlanta channels. 
    No change in the above rates charged to subscribers shall be made except as authorized by the City of Fitzgerald after an appropriate public proceeding affording due process of law. The company shall notify the city in writing of any proposed rate change. The city will then arrange a meeting with the company to discuss the rate change. The merits and demerits of the proposed rate change shall be discussed in the public proceeding and the city will then determine whether or not the increase in rates shall be authorized. The company shall make no charges to its subscribers except as authorized by this chapter as it now exists or as it may be amended. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-8) 
Sec. 9. - Reception. 
    Installation and maintenance of all cable and equipment shall be such that it is fully capable of receiving and delivering to any subscriber's set both color and black and white signals as they may be transmitted from the television station. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-9) 
Sec. 10. - Failure of company to perform to specifications. 
    The distribution system of the company as it currently exists or is hereafter improved shall not be abandoned, transferred or assigned either in whole or in part without the consent of the city council of the City of Fitzgerald, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. In the event of the failure of the company to commence construction of those improvements of the currently existing system described in section 8 hereof within thirty (30) days after the enactment of this article and pole attachment agreements from the General Telephone Company of the Southeast and from the Fitzgerald water, light and bond commission and in the event the company shall within a reasonable time fail to apply for all necessary permits, certificates, and approvals from the Federal Communications Commission, or in the event of the failure of the company to complete said improvements as contemplated and provided for by this article within a period of one (1) year from the date all of said pole attachment agreements and all necessary permits, certificates, and approvals from the Federal Communications Commission shall have been received, the city council shall have the right, on reasonable notice to the company and the determination that said failure was not beyond the reasonable control of the company, to declare this chapter and the rights and franchise granted thereunder forfeited. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-10) 
Sec. 11. - Sale of system. 
    If the company does not seek a franchise upon the termination of this franchise period, or if the franchise is forfeited due to the failure of the company to fully comply with all terms and conditions of this agreement, or upon transfer or assignment of the franchise, all assets of the company located in Ben Hill County, Georgia, shall be placed up for sale at current market value and the City of Fitzgerald shall have first option or refusal on the purchase of the system. Said system shall not be sold at a price less than the price at which it was offered to the City of Fitzgerald. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-11) 
Sec. 12. - Indemnification of city; liability insurance. 
    The company shall indemnify, protect and save harmless the city from and against all losses and physical damage to property, and bodily injury or death to persons, including payments made under any workmen's compensation law, which may arise out of or be caused by the erection, maintenance, presence, use or removal of said attachments on poles within the city, or by any act of the company, its agents or employees. The company shall carry insurance to protect hereto from and against all claims, demands, actions, judgments, costs, expenses, and liabilities which may arise or result, directly or indirectly from or by reason of such losses, injury or damage. The amount of such insurance against liability due to physical damage to property shall not be less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) as to any one (1) accident and not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) aggregate in any single policy year; and against liability due to bodily injury or to death of persons not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) as to any one (1) accident. The company shall also carry such insurance as it deems necessary to protect it from all claims under workmen's compensation laws in effect that may be applicable to the company. All insurance required by this agreement shall be and remain in full force and effect for the entire life of this agreement. Certificates of insurance evidencing said policy or policies of insurance shall be approved by the city attorney and then deposited with and kept on file by the city clerk. Thirty (30) days' written advance notice of cancellation of any of said insurance policies shall be given by the company to the city clerk. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-12) 
Sec. 13. - Joint use of poles. 
    The company shall grant to the city, free of expense, joint use of any and all poles owned by it for any proper municipal purpose acceptable to the company, insofar as it may be done without interfering with the free use and enjoyment of the company's own wires and fixtures, and the city shall hold the company harmless from any and all actions, causes of actions, or damage caused by the placing of the city's wires or appurtenances upon the poles of the company. Proper regard shall be given to all existing safety rules governing construction and maintenance in effect at the time of construction. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-13) 
Sec. 14. - Business office. 
    The company shall maintain a business office within the franchise area for the purpose of investigating and resolving all complaints regarding the quality of service, equipment malfunction and similar matters concerning the operation of the cable television system. The resolution of these complaints shall be fair and equitable and are subject to review by the City of Fitzgerald. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-14) 
Sec. 15. - Grievance review committee; termination of service. 
(a)  The city hereby establishes a grievance review committee, the function of which shall be to review those complaints of subscribers which have not been resolved by the company to the satisfaction of said subscribers. The procedure to be followed in the processing of complaints by said committee shall be as follows: The subscribers shall file a written complaint with the mayor, stating with reasonable particularity the grounds therefor. The mayor shall thereupon determine whether there is substantial reason to believe that said subscriber is receiving substandard service. If so, he shall present said written complaint within twenty-four (24) hours to the cable company office. The cable company shall expeditiously make an investigation thereof and report back to the mayor or his representative within twenty-four (24) hours stating the cable company's findings and the corrective action taken. The mayor or his appointed representative shall then respond to the subscriber's complaint to verify to the city's satisfaction that the problem has been corrected. If the cable subscriber reports that his problem was not corrected, the mayor thereupon shall within twenty-four (24) hours present the said written complaint and the cable company's report to the grievance committee for their review and recommendation. If, after having afforded due notice and an opportunity for corrective action by the cable company, said committee determines that said subscriber is and has been receiving substandard service, the company shall refund to said subscriber any payments made by said subscriber to the company for service charges accruing from the date of the filing of the subscriber's original complaint with the company or mayor until the date the said substandard service condition is corrected. Any charges of the company [to] said subscriber which accrued during said period of time shall be forfeited by the company. 
(b)  In recognition of the substantial involvement between the City of Fitzgerald and the company in providing community area television cable service to the residents of the city, and in recognition of the statutory entitlement of every inhabitant of the city to subscribe to and, upon payment of the prescribed charges, to receive the benefits of this system, the following procedure in terminating service to a subscriber over the objections of said subscriber: It shall be the further function of the above-described grievance review committee to hear and to determine disputes between the company and a subscriber involving the termination of service to said subscriber. Except in the case of a subscriber failing to pay the company's charges as herein prescribed, the company shall file a written complaint with the mayor, stating with reasonable particularity its reasons for desiring to terminate service to said subscriber. The mayor shall thereupon determine whether there is substantial reason to believe that termination of services is justified. If so, he shall present said written complaint to said committee, which shall expeditiously make an investigation thereof. If after affording due notice and an opportunity for a hearing, said committee determines that said subscriber has been unjustly harassing the company or that there otherwise exists adequate reasons for the termination, said committee shall direct that the company may terminate service to said subscriber. 
(c)  Involuntary termination of subscriber service shall not be permitted other than by the above-described procedure, provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the company from disconnecting a subscriber for failure to pay the company's approved charges in accordance with the company's customary collection policies and procedures. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-15) 
Sec. 16. - Service to city offices. 
    In consideration of the granting of this franchise to the company, as aforesaid, the company will furnish without installation charge or monthly service fee, a single outlet to any of the city departmental offices within the service area of the company, if and when requested to do so; this service shall also be extended to all public schools and churches. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-16) 
Sec. 17. - Fee. 
(a)  In further consideration of the granting of this franchise to the company, the company will pay to the city an annual franchise fee equal to three (3) percent of the gross income of the company from subscribers within the city limits of the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. The term "gross income" for this purpose being defined as the recurring monthly service charges actually collected from its subscribers. The said franchise fee shall be payable annually on or before the first day of March of each year, computed on the said income for the calendar year ending on the preceding December thirty-first. The city clerk shall have the right, during regular business hours, to inspect all records and books of the company which may contain matter which pertains to the company's operations and activities within its Fitzgerald, Georgia, service area. 
(b)  Acceptance of the terms of this article and franchise by the duly authorized representative of the company shall constitute a knowledgeable and voluntary waiver by the company of any objection to said annual franchise fee upon the grounds that said franchise fee imposes an impermissible burden upon any activity of the company in interstate commerce, or that said franchise fee otherwise violates the due process rights of the company under the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Georgia. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-17) 
Sec. 18. - System to be maintained. 
    The company shall at all times during the term of this franchise maintain a modern up-to date TV cable system in the City of Fitzgerald, and keep said system in good working order at all times, and promptly service all complaints made by its subscribers. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-18) 
Sec. 19. - Compliance with federal regulations. 
    The company shall at all times be in full compliance with all federal communication regulations pertaining to cable television systems, as they now exist or as they may be amended. Any modifications of the provisions of section 76.31 of the rules of the Federal Communications Commission resulting from amendment by the commission shall be incorporated into this franchise within one (1) year of adoption of the modification, or at the time of franchise renewal, whichever occurs first. The company shall furthermore, at all times be in full compliance with all existing federal, state and local laws, ordinances and statutes as are applicable to the operation of a cable television system, provided, however, that no future such law, ordinance, or statute of the City of Fitzgerald shall materially alter the terms of this chapter without the written consent of the company. No part of this chapter other than section 17 hereof shall be construed as a waiver of any local, state or federal law, or as a limit of liability. Failure of the company, after ninety (90) days' written notice from the city, to comply with any of the provisions of this article or any of the above described federal, state and local laws, ordinances and statutes, shall authorize the city council to declare, after a public hearing and determine that said noncompliance has not been corrected, that this article and the rights and franchise granted hereunder are forfeited. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-19) 
Sec. 20. - Termination of prior rights. 
    The acceptance of this franchise shall terminate any rights which the company might have under the franchise agreement with the City of Fitzgerald under which the company has heretofore operated. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-20) 
Sec. 21. - Taxes. 
    Nothing in this article shall affect the liability of the company to pay ad valorem taxes to the city on property of the company located within the city. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-21) 
Sec. 22. - Severability. 
    If any section, clause, or provision of this article is declared invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the same shall not affect the validity of the article as a whole or any part thereof, other than the part so declared invalid. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-22) 
Sec. 23. - Effective date. 
    This article shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage by the city council. 
(Code 1966, § 61/2-23) 
DIVISION 2. - TCI CABLEVISION OF GEORGIA, INC.[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1107, adopted April 11, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, its inclusion as App. C, Art. I, Div. 2, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 30-1. - Grant of franchise. 
    Whereas, the legal, character, financial, technical and other qualifications of TCI Cablevision of Georgia, Inc., were examined and approved by the Mayor and Council of the City of Fitzgerald, State of Georgia, as part of a full public proceeding affording due process, and in consideration of the faithful performance and observation of the conditions and reservations hereinafter specified, the right is granted to TCI Cablevision of Georgia, Inc., a corporation organized under the laws of the State of Georgia, its successors, assigns, or designees (provided such successors, assigns, or designees are approved by the Mayor and Council of the City of Fitzgerald), hereinafter referred to as the "Company," to erect, maintain and operate television and other radio frequency signal transmission and distribution facilities, and additions thereto, in, under, over, along, across, and upon the streets, lanes, avenues, sidewalks, alleys, bridges and other public places in the City of Fitzgerald, and subsequent additions thereto, for the purpose of transmission and distribution of television and radio frequency impulses and television and radio frequency energy for a period from the effective date hereof until April 11, 1999, with the further right and option of the company to renew and extend this franchise with all of the rights and privileges and upon all of the terms and conditions set forth in the said Ordinance No. 1107, approved April 11, 1988, provided written notice of the election of the Company to renew and extend said franchise is given to and received by the said city in care of its Mayor, on or before the 31st day of December, 1998, and to connect and interconnect its said facilities to distribution facilities located outside the city limits of the City of Fitzgerald). In the event of a sale of more than fifty (50) per cent of the capital stock of TCI Cablevision of Georgia, Inc., by its present owners to other than an entity controlling, controlled by, or under common control with TCI Cablevision of Georgia, Inc., without the written consent of the Mayor and Council of the City of Fitzgerald, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, all rights of the Company under this franchise may be immediately terminated and this franchise may be thereby terminated. 
(Ord. No. 98-1243, § 1, 5-11-98) 
Sec. 30-2. - [Definition.] 
    Whenever used in this ordinance, the word "television" shall mean a system for the transmission by means of coaxial cable of radio frequency signals for the purpose of producing on subscribers' equipment, audio equipment, audio information or visual images by means of electrical impulses. 
Sec. 30-3. - [Distribution poles.] 
    The poles used for the company's distribution system shall be those erected and maintained by the General Telephone Company of the South and the Fitzgerald Water, Light & Bond Commission, when and where practicable, provided mutually satisfactory rental agreements can be entered into with said telephone company and said commission. Where the use of poles owned by the said commission is not practicable or mutually satisfactory rental agreements cannot be entered into with said telephone company and/or said commission following a good-faith effort on the part of TCI Cablevision of Georgia, Inc., to obtain such agreements, the company shall have the right to erect and maintain its own poles as may be necessary for the proper construction and maintenance of the television distribution system, with the approval of the city engineer or his representative of the location of the poles. 
Sec. 30-4. - [Location of equipment, etc.] 
(a)  The company's transmission and distribution system, poles, wires, and appurtenances shall be located, erected and maintained so as not to endanger or interfere with the lives of persons, or to interfere with new improvements this city may deem proper to make, or to unnecessarily hinder or obstruct the free use of the streets, alleys, bridges, or other public property; removal of poles to avoid such interference will be at the company's expense. Approval of all construction sites by the city engineer or his representatives shall be required prior to erection of any transmission or distribution facilities. Any change in the location of these facilities shall also be subject to prior approval by the city engineer or his representative. 
(b)  Construction and maintenance of the transmission and distribution system, including house connections, shall be in accordance with the provisions of the National Electric Safety Code, prepared by the National Bureau of Standards, as it now exists or as it may be amended, the National Electric Code of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, as it now exists or as it may be amended, and such applicable ordinances and regulations of the City of Fitzgerald affecting electrical installations which may be presently and in effect or changed by future ordinances. 
(c)  Installation and housedrop hardware shall be uniform throughout the city, except that the company shall be free to change its hardware and installation procedure as the art progresses. 
Sec. 30-5. - Maintenance operation. 
    In the maintenance and operation of its television transmission and distribution system in the streets, alleys, and other public places, and in the course of any new construction or addition to its facilities, the company shall proceed so as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the general public; any opening or obstruction in the streets or other public places made by the company in the course of its operations shall be made only after having obtained prior written permission from the City of Fitzgerald to do so, and shall be guarded and protected at all times by the placement of adequate barriers, fences, or boardings, the bounds of which, during periods of dusk and darkness shall be clearly designated by appropriate warning lights. All work in any way necessitated by the business of the Company which may involve the opening, breaking up, or tearing up of a portion of a street, sidewalk, or other part of any City-owned or City-controlled property, shall be done and repaired in a manner approved by the City of Fitzgerald, and may be done by the city at the reasonable expense of the cable operator, if mutually agreed upon by the City of Fitzgerald and the Company. The Company shall maintain said repairs in a condition approved by the City for a period of one year thereafter. 
Sec. 30-6. - [Installations.] 
    Installations shall be maintained so as not to interfere with TV reception already in existence. 
Sec. 30-7. - Reserved. 
    (Section deleted.) 
Sec. 30-8. - [Service to customers; interruption of service.] 
    The Company shall maintain at its place of business within the City of Fitzgerald an inventory of parts and equipment and a trained service staff which together will assure that every service call will be responded to within a twenty-four-hour period of time after such call is received by the company, and the company shall provide a published telephone number to which service calls may be placed at all times. Any subscriber who experiences a total interruption of cable services for a continuous period of forty-eight (48) hours or more, after reporting such interruption to the company, except in cases where the outage is caused by the acts of God, power company outages or other circumstances beyond the control of the company, shall receive upon request, a credit to the monthly subscription service charge of twenty-five (25) percent. Should the total interruption continue for a period of more than seventy-two (72) hours, the subscriber shall receive, upon request, fifty-percent credit to the monthly subscription service charge. Should the total service interruption continue for a period of more than ninety-one (91) hours, the subscriber shall receive, upon request, a one-hundred-percent credit to the monthly subscription charge for the month in which such interruption occurred. 
Sec. 30-9. - [Reception.] 
    Installation and maintenance of all cable and equipment shall be such that it is fully capable of receiving and delivering to any subscriber's set both color and black-and-white signals as they may be transmitted from the television station. 
Sec. 30-10. - [Abandonment, etc., of distribution system.] 
    The distribution system of the company as it currently exists or is hereafter improved shall not be abandoned, transferred or assigned either in whole or in part except to an entity controlling, controlled by, or under common control with the company, without consent of the city council of the City of Fitzgerald, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
Sec. 30-11. - [Sale of system.] 
    In the event the company does not seek a new franchise upon the termination of this franchise period, or in the event that the franchise is lawfully forfeited due to the failure of the company to fully comply with all material terms and conditions of this agreement, subject to state and federal laws, all assets of the company located in the City of Fitzgerald, shall be placed up for sale and the City of Fitzgerald shall have first option or refusal on the purchase of the system. 
Sec. 30-12. - [Indemnification of city; liability.] 
    The company shall indemnify, protect and save harmless the city from and against all losses and physical damage to property, and bodily injury or death to persons, including payments made under any workman's compensation law, which may arise out of or be caused by the grantee's erection, maintenance, presence, use or removal of said attachments on poles within the city, or by any act of the company, its agents or employees. The company shall carry insurance to protect the parties hereto from and against all claims, demands, actions, judgements, costs, expenses, and liabilities which may arise or result, directly or indirectly, from or by reason of such losses, injury or damage. The amounts of such insurance against liability due to physical damage to property shall not be less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) to any one (1) accident and not less than two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate in any single policy year; and against liability due to bodily injury or to death of persons not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) as to any one (1) accident. The company shall also carry such insurance as it deems necessary to protect it from all claims under any workmen's compensation laws in effect that may be applicable to the company. All insurance required by this agreement shall be and remain in full force and effect for the entire life of this agreement. Certificates of insurance evidencing said policy or policies of insurance shall be approved by the city attorney and then deposited with and kept on file by the city clerk. Thirty (30) days' written advance notice of cancellation of any of said insurance policies shall be given by the company to the city clerk. 
Sec. 30-13. - [Joint use of poles.] 
    The company shall grant to the city, free of expense, joint use of any and all poles owned by it for any proper municipal purpose acceptable to the company, insofar as it may be done without interfering with the use and enjoyment of the company's own wires and fixtures, and the city shall hold the Company harmless from any and all actions, causes of action, or damage caused by the placing of the city's wires or appurtenances upon the poles of the company. Proper regard shall be given to all existing safety rules governing construction and maintenance in effect at the time of construction. 
Sec. 30-14. - [Business office.] 
    The company shall maintain a business office within the franchise area for the purpose of investigating and resolving all complaints regarding the quality of service, equipment malfunction and similar matters concerning the operation of the cable television system. The resolution of these complaints shall be fair and equitable and are subject to review by the City of Fitzgerald. 
Sec. 30-15. - [Grievance review committee; termination of service.] 
(a)  The city hereby establishes a grievance review committee, the function of which shall be to review those complaints of subscribers which have not been resolved by the company to the satisfaction of said subscribers. The procedure to be followed in the processing of complaints by said committee shall be as follows: The subscriber shall file a written complaint with the mayor, stating with reasonable particularity the grounds therefor. The mayor shall thereupon determine whether there is substantial reason to believe that said subscriber is receiving substandard service. If so, he shall present said written complaint within twenty-four (24) hours to the cable company office. The cable company shall expeditiously make an investigation thereof and report back to the mayor or his representative within twenty-four (24) hours stating the cable company's findings and the corrective action to be taken. The mayor or his appointed representative shall then respond to the subscriber's complaint to verify to the city's satisfaction that the problem has been corrected. If the cable subscriber reports that his problem was not corrected, the mayor thereupon shall within twenty-four (24) hours present the said written complaint and cable company's report to the grievance committee for their review and recommendation. If, after having afforded due notice and an opportunity for corrective action by the cable company, said committee determines that said subscriber is and has been receiving substandard service, the company shall refund to said subscriber any payments made by said subscriber to the company for service charges accruing from the date of the filing of the subscriber's original complaint with the company or mayor until the date the said substandard service condition is corrected. Any charges of the company to said subscriber which accrued during said period of time shall be forfeited by the company. 
(b)  In recognition of the substantial involvement between the City of Fitzgerald and the company in providing community area television cable service to the residents of the City, and in recognition of the statutory entitlement of every inhabitant of the city to subscribe to and, upon payment of the prescribed charges, to receive the benefits of this system, the company shall be required to follow the following procedure in terminating service to a subscriber over the objections of said subscriber: It shall be the further function of the above-described grievance review committee to hear and to determine disputes between the company and a subscriber involving the termination of service to said subscriber. Except in the case of a subscriber failing to pay the company's charges as herein prescribed, the company shall file a written complaint with the mayor, stating with reasonable particularity its reasons for desiring to terminate service to said subscriber. The mayor shall thereupon determine whether there is substantial reason to believe that termination of services is justified. If so, he shall present said written complaint to said committee, which shall expeditiously make an investigation thereof. If, after affording due notice and an opportunity for a hearing, said committee determines that said subscriber has been unjustly harassing the company or that there otherwise exists adequate reasons for the termination of said service, said committee shall direct that the company may terminate service to said subscriber. 
(c)  Involuntary termination of subscriber service shall not be permitted other than by the above-described procedure, provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the company from disconnecting a subscriber for failure to pay the company's approved charges in accordance with the company's customary collection policies and procedures. 
Sec. 30-16. - Service to city offices. 
    In consideration of the granting of this franchise to the company, as aforesaid, the company will furnish without installation charge or monthly service fee, a single outlet to any of the city departmental offices within the service area of the company, if and when requested to do so; this service shall also be extended to all public schools passed by its cable. 
Sec. 30-17. - [Annual fee.] 
(a)  In further consideration of the granting of this franchise to the company, the company will pay to the city an annual franchise fee equal to five (5) percent of the gross income of the company from subscribers within the city limits of the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia, the term "gross income" for this purpose being defined as the recurring monthly service charges actually collected from its subscribers. The said franchise fee shall be payable annually on or before the first day of March of each year, computed on the said income for the calendar year ending on the preceding December thirty-first. The city clerk shall have the right, during regular business hours, to inspect all records and books of the company which are necessary to the enforcement of the franchise in Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
(b)  Acceptance of the terms of this ordinance and franchise by the duly authorized representative of the company shall constitute a knowledgeable and voluntary waiver by the company of any objection to said annual franchise fee upon the grounds that said franchise fee imposes an impermissible burden upon any activity of the company in interstate commerce, or that said franchise fee otherwise violates the due process rights of the company under the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Georgia. 
Sec. 30-18. - [Maintenance of system; extension of service.] 
(a)  The company shall at all times during the term of this franchise maintain a modern, up-to-date TV cable system in the City of Fitzgerald, so far as is technically and economically feasible, and keep said system in good working order at all times, and promptly service all complaints by its subscribers. The company shall install cable service to a subscriber located within the city already served by the cable system within ten (10) working days after such service is requested by a potential subscriber, whether such service is a new service or an upgrade of an existing service. 
(b)  The company is hereby authorized to extend the cable system as necessary, as desirable, or as required pursuant to the terms hereof within the service area. Whenever the company shall receive a request for service from at least fifteen (15) subscribers within one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) cable-bearing strand feet (one-quarter-mile) of its trunk or distribution cable, it shall extend its cable system to such subscribers at no cost to said subscribers for system extension, other than the usual connection fees for all subscribers, provided that such extension is technically feasible, and if it will not adversely affect the operation, financial condition or market development of the cable system. 
Sec. 30-19. - [Compliance with federal regulations.] 
    The company shall at all times be in full compliance with all Federal Communications Commission regulations pertaining to cable television systems, as they now exist or as they may be amended. Any modifications of the provisions of section 76-31 of the rules of the Federal Communications Commission resulting from amendment by the commission shall be incorporated into this franchise within one (1) year of adoption of the modification, or at the time of franchise renewal, whichever occurs first. The company shall, furthermore, at all times be in full compliance with all existing federal, state and local laws, ordinances and statutes as are applicable to the operation of a cable television system; provided, however, that no future such law, ordinance, or statute of the City of Fitzgerald shall materially alter the terms of this ordinance without the written consent of the company. No part of this ordinance shall be construed as a waiver of any local, state or federal law, or as a limit of liability. Failure of the company, after ninety (90) days' written notice from the city, to comply with any of the provisions of this ordinance or any of the above-described federal, state and local laws, ordinances and statutes, shall authorize the city council to declare, after a public hearing and determination that said noncompliance has not been corrected, that this ordinance and the rights and franchise granted hereunder are forfeited. 
Sec. 30-20. - [Termination of prior rights.] 
    The acceptance of this franchise shall terminate any rights which the company might have under the franchise agreement with the City of Fitzgerald under which the company has heretofore operated. 
Sec. 30-21. - [Taxes.] 
    Nothing in this ordinance shall affect the liability of the company to pay ad valorem taxes to the city on property of the company located within the city. 
Sec. 30-22. - [Separability.] 
    Should any section, clause, or provision of this ordinance be declared invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the same shall not affect the validity of the ordinance as a whole or any part thereof, other than the part so declared invalid. 
Sec. 30-23. - [Effective date.] 
    This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage by the city council. 
Sec. 30-24. - [City engineer.] 
    As used herein, the city engineer shall mean the city administrator. 
ARTICLE II. - TELEPHONE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL TELEPHONE COMPANY OF THE SOUTHEAST 
    WHEREAS, the General Telephone Company of the Southeast, hereinafter referred to as the "telephone company" or the "company" is now and has been engaged in the telephone and communications business in the State of Georgia, and in furtherance thereof, has erected and maintained certain items of its plant construction in the City of Fitzgerald, hereinafter referred to as the "City," for many years pursuant to such rights as have been granted it by and under the laws of the State of Georgia, and subject to the exercise of such reasonable rights of regulation under the police power as have been also lawfully granted by and under said laws to said city; and 
    WHEREAS, it is to the mutual advantage of both the city and the telephone company that an agreement should be entered into between the telephone company and the city establishing the conditions under which the telephone company shall operate in the city; 
    NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED, BY THE MAYOR AND COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF FITZGERALD, THAT: 

Sec. 1. - Construction and maintenance of telephone plant in service. 
    That the right, privilege and franchise be, and the same is hereby granted to General Telephone Company of the Southeast, hereinafter referred to as the "telephone company," or the "company," and its successors or assigns, subject to the terms and conditions hereinafter set forth, to construct, erect, build, equip, own, maintain and operate in, along, under, over and across the streets, avenues, alleys, bridges, viaducts and public grounds of the city, any and all such appliances, structures and fixtures necessary or convenient for rendering telephone and other communications service and for conducting a communications business including the rendition of local and long distance telephone service. The appliances, structures, and fixtures of the telephone company in said city shall remain as now constructed, subject to such changes, under the limitations and conditions herein prescribed, as may be considered necessary by the city in the exercise of its lawful powers and by the telephone company in the conduct of its business. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 1, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 2. - Location of poles and conduit. 
    The company shall have the right to determine the number and location of poles, wires, cables, conduits, markers and other property and appliances to be placed in, over, upon, under and across the streets, avenues, alleys and other public places of said city, so long as such poles, wires, cables, conduits, markers, property and appliances do not interfere with or obstruct the normal flow of traffic, or otherwise impede the common uses of the streets, avenues, alleys, and other public places of said city. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 2, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 3. - Streets to be restored to good condition. 
    The surface of any street, alley, highway, or public place disturbed by the telephone company in building, constructing, renewing or maintaining its plant and system shall be restored within a reasonable time after the completion of the work to as good a condition as before the commencement of the work and maintained to the satisfaction of the City of Fitzgerald, or of any city official to whom such duties have been or may be delegated, for one (1) year from the date the surface of said street, alley, highway or public place is broken for such construction or maintenance work, after which time responsibility for the maintenance shall become the duty of the city. No street, alley, highway or public place shall be encumbered for a longer period than shall be necessary to execute the work. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 3, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 4. - Operation and maintenance of telephone plant. 
    The telephone company shall maintain its system in reasonable operating condition at all normal times during the continuance of this agreement. An exception to this condition is automatically in effect when service furnished by the telephone company is interrupted, impaired, or prevented by fires, strikes, riots, or other occurrences beyond the control of the telephone company, or by storms, floods or other casualties, in any of which events the telephone company shall do all things, reasonable within its power to do, to restore normal service. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 4, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 5. - Temporary removal of wires. 
    The telephone company on the request of any person shall remove or raise or lower its wires temporarily to permit the moving of houses or other bulky structures. The expense of such temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the benefitted party or parties, and the telephone company may require such payment in advance. The telephone company shall be given not less than forty-eight (48) hours' advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 5, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 6. - Tree trimming. 
    The right, license, privilege and permission is hereby granted to the telephone company, its successors and assigns, to trim trees upon and overhanging the streets, alleys, sidewalks and public places of the city so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires or cables of the telephone company, and when so ordered by the city, said trimming shall be done under the supervision and direction of the City of Fitzgerald, or of any city official to whom said duties have been or may be delegated. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 6, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 7. - Annual cash consideration to be paid by the telephone company. 
    To indemnify the city for any and all possible damage to its streets, alleys, and public grounds which may result from the placing and maintenance therein or thereon of the telephone company's conduits, or other equipment or apparatus, and to compensate the city for its superintendence of this agreement, and as the cash consideration for the same, the telephone company agrees to pay to the city annually during the continuance of this agreement a sum of money equal to four and sixty-eight one-hundredths (4.68) percent of the annual gross receipts for the preceding year received by the telephone company from the rendition of local exchange telephone transmission service within the corporate limits of the city. The first payment hereunder shall be made within sixty (60) days of the date of this franchise and shall equal twenty-three thousand, two hundred-eighty nine dollars and seventy-three cents ($23,289.73), the amount of three (3) percent of the gross receipts received from January 1, 1973 to December 31, 1974; and thereafter payment as set out above shall be made annually on March 31st of each year. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 7, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 8. - Payments of cash consideration to be in lieu of any other payments except usual general or special ad valorem taxes and sales and use taxes. 
    The city agrees that the consideration set forth in section 7 shall be paid and received in lieu of any tax, license, charge, fee, streets or alley rental or any other character of charge for use and occupancy of the streets, alleys, and public places of the city: in lieu of any easement or franchise tax, whether levied as an ad valorem, special or other character of tax; and in lieu of any imposition other than the usual general or special ad valorem property taxes now or hereafter levied and other than any sales or use tax authorized or hereafter authorized under the laws of Georgia. Should the city not have the legal power to agree that the payment of the foregoing cash consideration shall be in lieu of the taxes, licenses, charges, fees, rentals, and easement or franchise taxes aforesaid, then the city agrees that it will apply so much of said payment as may be necessary to the satisfaction of the telephone company's obligations, licenses, charges, fees, rentals, and easement or franchise taxes. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 8, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 9. - Period of time of this ordinance; termination. 
    This agreement shall be in force and effect for a full term and period of fifteen (15) years from and after its effective date hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 9, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 10. - No exclusive privileges conferred by this ordinance. 
    Nothing herein contained shall be construed as giving to the telephone company any exclusive privilege. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 10, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 11. - Successors and assigns. 
    The rights, powers, limitations, duties and restrictions herein provided for shall inure to and be binding upon the parties hereto and upon their respective successors and assigns. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 11, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 12. - Partial invalidity and repeal provision. 
    If any section, sentence, clause, or phrase of this ordinance is for any reason held to be illegal, ultra vires or unconstitutional, such invalidity shall not effect the validity of the remaining portions of this ordinance. All ordinances and agreements and parts of ordinances and agreements in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 12, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 13. - Liability of city. 
    During the period this ordinance is in existence and enjoyed by the telephone company, the telephone company shall indemnify and hold harmless the city from any and all claims for losses, damages and injuries occasioned to or sustained by any persons, firms or corporations, or their property by reason of the existence, maintenance, operation or continuance of this ordinance and the exercise of all rights herein contracted for, except as herein otherwise provided. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 13, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 14. - Acceptance of agreement. 
    The telephone company shall have sixty (60) days from and after the passage and approval of this ordinance to file its written acceptance thereof with the city's secretary, and upon such acceptance being filed, this ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after the date of its passage and approval by the mayor, and shall effectuate and make binding the agreement provided by the terms hereof. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 14, 6-2-75) 
Sec. 15. - Use of utility poles of Fitzgerald Water, Light & Bond Commission. 
    The telephone company shall not use poles of the Fitzgerald Water, Light & Bond Commission unless a mutually satisfactory rental agreement is entered into with said Fitzgerald Water, Light & Bond Commission. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 15, 6-2-75) 
DIVISION 2. - GTE SOUTH INCORPORATED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1142, adopted July 8, 1991, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-15 as Art. II, Div. 2, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 1. - Construction and maintenance of telephone plant in service. 
    The right, privilege and franchise be, and the same is hereby granted to GTE South, Incorporated, hereinafter referred to as the "telephone company," its successors or assigns, subject to the terms and conditions hereinafter set forth, to construct, erect, build, equip, own, maintain and operate in, along, under, over and across the streets, avenues, alleys, bridges, viaducts and public grounds of the city, any and all such appliances, structures and fixtures necessary or convenient for rendering telephone and other communications service and for conducting a communications business including the rendition of local and long distance telephone service. The appliances, structures, and fixtures of the telephone company in said city shall remain as now constructed, subject to such changes, under the limitations and conditions herein prescribed, as may be considered necessary by the city in the exercise of its lawful powers and by the telephone company in the conduct of its business. 
Sec. 2. - Location of poles and conduit. 
    The company shall have the right to determine the number and location of poles, wires, cables, conduits, markers and other property and appliances to be placed in, over, upon, under and across the streets, avenues, alleys and other public places of said city, so long as such poles, wires, cables, conduits, markers, property and appliances do not interfere with or obstruct the normal flow of traffic, or otherwise impede the common uses of the streets, avenues, alleys, and other public places of said city. 
Sec. 3. - Streets to be restored to good condition. 
    The surface of any street, alley, highway, or public place disturbed by the telephone company in building, constructing, renewing or maintaining its plant and system shall be restored within a reasonable time after the completion of the work to as good a condition as before the commencement of the work and maintained to the satisfaction of the City of Fitzgerald, or of any city official to whom such duties have been or may be delegated, for one (1) year from the date the surface of said street, alley, highway or public place is broken for such construction or maintenance work, after which time responsibility for the maintenance shall become the duty of the city. No street, alley, highway or public place shall be encumbered for a longer period than shall be necessary to execute the work. 
Sec. 4. - Operation and maintenance of telephone plant. 
    The telephone company shall maintain its system in reasonable operating condition at all normal times during the continuance of this agreement. An exception to this condition is automatically in effect when service furnished by the telephone company is interrupted, impaired, or prevented by fires, strikes, riots, or other occurrences beyond the control of the telephone company, or by storms, floods or other casualties, in any of which events the telephone company shall do all things, reasonably within its power to do, to restore normal service. 
Sec. 5. - Temporary removal of wires. 
    The telephone company on the request of any person shall remove or raise or lower its wires temporarily to permit the moving of houses or other bulky structures. The expense of such temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the benefitted party or parties, and the telephone company may require such payment in advance. The telephone company shall be given not less than forty-eight (48) hours advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
Sec. 6. - Tree trimming. 
    The right, license, privilege and permission is hereby granted to the telephone company, its successors and assigns, to trim trees upon and overhanging the streets, alleys, sidewalks and public places of the city so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires or cables of the telephone company, and when so ordered by the city, said trimming shall be done under the supervision and direction of the City of Fitzgerald, or of any city official to whom said duties have been or may be delegated. 
Sec. 7. - Annual cash consideration to be paid by telephone company. 
    To indemnify the city for any and all possible damage to its streets, alleys, and public grounds which may result from the placing and maintenance therein or thereon of the telephone company's conduits, or other equipment or apparatus, and to compensate the city for its superintendence of this agreement, and as the cash consideration for the same, the telephone company agrees to pay to the city annually during the continuance of this agreement a sum of money equal to four and sixty-eight-one-hundredths (4.68) percent of the annual gross receipts for the preceding year received by the telephone company from the rendition of local exchange telephone transmission service within the corporate limits of the city. The first payment hereunder shall be made on or before March 31, 1991, for the period from January 1, 1990, through December 31, 1990, and thereafter payment as set out above shall be made annually on March 31 of each year. At the time of making the payment to the city above set forth or at some time prior thereto, a certified public accountant employed by the telephone company will certify that the amounts paid under this franchise agreement are true and correct. In the event the city wishes to audit any of the accounts of the telephone company pertaining to this franchise, the telephone company will pay the travel and other expenses for a city auditor to review the accounts. 
Sec. 8. - Payments of cash consideration to be in lieu of any other payments except usual general or special ad valorem taxes and sales and use taxes. 
    The city agrees that the consideration set forth in the preceding section hereof shall be paid and received in lieu of any tax, license, charge, fee, streets or alley rental or any other character of charge for use and occupancy of the streets, alleys, and public places of the city; in lieu of any easement or franchise tax, whether levied as an ad valorem, special or other character of tax; and in lieu of any imposition other than the usual general or special ad valorem property taxes now or hereafter levied and other than any sales or use tax authorized or hereafter authorized under the laws of Georgia. Should the city not have the legal power to agree that the payment of the foregoing cash consideration shall be in lieu of the taxes, licenses, charges, fees, rentals, and easement or franchise taxes aforesaid, then the city agrees that it will apply so much of said payment as may be necessary to the satisfaction of the telephone company's obligations, licenses, charges, fees, rentals, and easement or franchise taxes. 
Sec. 9. - Period of time of this ordinance; termination. 
    This agreement shall be in force and effect for a full term and period of ten (10) years from and after its effective date hereinafter provided. 
Sec. 10. - No exclusive privileges conferred by this ordinance. 
    Nothing herein contained shall be construed as giving to the telephone company any exclusive privilege. 
Sec. 11. - Successors and assigns. 
    The rights, powers, limitations, duties and restrictions herein provided for shall inure to and be binding upon the parties hereto and upon their respective successors and assigns. 
Sec. 12. - Partial invalidity and repeal provision. 
    If any section, sentence, clause, or phrase of this ordinance is for any reason held to be illegal, ultra vires or unconstitutional, such invalidity shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this ordinance. All ordinances and agreements and parts of ordinances and agreements in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
Sec. 13. - Liability of city. 
    During the period this ordinance is in existence and enjoyed by the telephone company, the telephone company shall indemnify and hold harmless the city from any and all claims for losses, damages and injuries occasioned to or sustained by any persons, firms or corporations, or their property by reason of the existence, maintenance, operation or continuance of this ordinance and the exercise of all right herein contracted for, except as herein otherwise provided. 
Sec. 14. - Acceptance of agreement. 
    The telephone company shall have sixty (60) days from and after the passage and approval of this ordinance to file its written acceptance thereof with the city's secretary, and upon such acceptance being filed, this ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after the date of its passage and approval by the mayor, and shall effectuate and make binding the agreement provided by the terms hereof. 
Sec. 15. - Use of utility poles of Fitzgerald Water, Light & Bond Commission. 
    The telephone company shall not use poles of the Fitzgerald Water, Light & Bond Commission unless a mutually satisfactory rental agreement is entered into with said Fitzgerald Water, Light & Bond Commission. 
DIVISION 3. - AT&T CORPORATION 
    THE CITY OF FITZGERALD HEREBY ORDAINS: 

Sec. 1. - [AT&T authorized licensee.] 
    That AT&T Corp., referred to as "Licensee", is hereby authorized to encroach upon the public right of way in certain streets and alleys in the city, for the purpose of overhead and underground fiber optic cable, shown as dashed lines (overhead) and solid lines (underground) on a plan prepared by AT&T Corp., designated as Drawing No. _______ dated _______, and entitled: "Proposed Overhead and Underground Fiber Optic Cable Encroachments by AT&T Corp., Priority Locations", a copy of which drawing is attached to this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 1, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 2. - [Encroachment.] 
    This article authorizes the licensee to encroach upon the public right-of-way as set forth on such drawing only to traverse the City, as requested by the Licensee. The Licensee shall give the city thirty (30) days advance written notice requesting any additional use of right-of-way and shall abide by any permitting requirements as specified by city ordinances. The City and Licensee have agreed that the Ordinance does not authorize the provision of any services in the City, and that the provision of services shall require separate authorization from the City. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 2, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 3. - [Rights non-transferable.] 
    The rights granted by this Ordinance to the Licensee are personal to the Licensee (as currently owned and controlled) and shall not be assigned or transferred, directly or indirectly, without the prior written consent of the City. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 3, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 4. - [Grant of authorization; conditions.] 
    The grant of authorization for the above-described encroachment shall also be subject to the following specific conditions: 
(1)  The Licensee, or any successor or assign, shall bear all costs incurred in connection with the installation, construction, maintenance, repair, operation and removal of the encroachments. 
(2)  The Licensee, on the Licensee's own behalf and on behalf of any successor or assign, shall acknowledge and assume all responsibility for the permitted use of the public right of way and the installation, construction, maintenance, repair, operation and removal of the encroachments, which shall be undertaken without risk or liability on the part of the city. 
(3)  The Licensee shall pay on an annual basis two dollars ($2.00) per linear foot for aerial facilities (_____ feet as of the effective date) and four dollars ($4.00) per linear foot for underground facilities in the public right-of-way as of January 1 of each year. The first payment under this article shall be prorated from _______, 2000 to the end of the year and shall be due within thirty (30) days from the effective date. Payments in advance for each subsequent year shall be remitted by January 30. This fee shall be adjusted annually based upon the average of the November monthly Consumer Price Index figures, relative to the United States as a whole, most recently issued by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor. For the purpose of this adjustment, the base figure shall be the average cost-of-living index figure issued in November 1999. 
(4)  The Licensee shall furnish the City evidence of a public liability insurance contract in an amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit, naming the city as an additional insured. 
(5)  The Licensee shall require any contractor or contractors to furnish the city evidence of a public liability and property damage insurance contract in an amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined coverage for bodily injuries and property damage resulting from the contractor's activities with regard to the authorized encroachment, naming the City as an additional insured. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 4, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 5. - [Responsibility for cost.] 
    The Licensee shall be responsible and must bear all cost for repair of any damage or movement of the encroachments and/or to the structure the encroachment is attached to due to repair, maintenance and/or failure/collapse of the existing gas, water and sewer lines under or approximately under said encroachment. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 5, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 6. - [Minimum ground clearance.] 
    The Licensee shall be responsible for assuring that all overhead cables meet the minimum ground clearance as required by all applicable codes and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 6, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 7. - [Placement of cables.] 
    The Licensee shall place cables underground where required to do so and in any other locations where required by the inspection department. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 7, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 8. - [Final location plan.] 
    Prior to construction, a final location plan shall be submitted for approval by the inspection department, and the inspection department shall be authorized to permit or to require an alternate location for the proposed conduit within the public right of way to avoid conflict with other permitted uses or to establish an appropriate width from curb for placement of conduit for the use proposed. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 8, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 9. - [As-built drawings.] 
    The Licensee shall provide as-built drawings detailing the location of fiber optic conduits and manholes installed pursuant to this authorization. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 9, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 10. - [Effectiveness.] 
    This Ordinance shall be in force upon adoption and shall become effective when the Licensee furnishes the required insurance and bond forms and files a written acceptance of the Ordinance with the City Clerk in the form attached as Appendix A. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1267, § 10, 4-10-00) 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1108, adopted May 2, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ I-IV as App. C, Art. III, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. I. - Grant of franchise. 
    Be it ordained by the governing authority of the City of Fitzgerald (hereafter referred to as the "city"), that the authority, right, permission and consent are hereby granted to Georgia Power Company, its successors, lessees and assigns (hereafter referred to as the "company"), for a period of thirty-five (35) years, to occupy and use the streets, alleys and public places of the city within the present and future limits of the said city as from time to time the company may deem proper or necessary for the overhead or underground construction, maintenance, operation and extension of poles, towers, lines, wires, cables, conduits, insulators, transformers, appliances, equipment, connections and other apparatus for the business and purpose of transmitting, conveying, conducting, using, supplying and distributing electricity for light, heat, power and other purposes for which electric current may be or become useful or practicable for public or private use, and to re-enter upon such streets, alleys and public places from time to time as it may deem proper or necessary to perform these functions, and to cut and trim trees and shrubbery when and where necessary, in the judgement of the company, to insure safe and efficient service. 
Sec. II. - Conditions of franchise. 
    Be it further ordained that the rights, permission and consents herein contained are made for the following considerations and upon the following terms and conditions, to-wit: 
(1)  The company shall pay into the treasury of the city (a) on or before the first day of March in each year following the granting of this franchise a sum of money equal to four (4) percent of the gross sales of electric energy to customers served under residential and commercial rate schedules (as prescribed by the Georgia Public Service Commission) within the corporate limits of the city during the preceding calendar year and four (4) percent of the gross sales of electric energy to customers served under industrial rate schedules (as so prescribed) within the corporate limits of the city during the period beginning on the first day of the month following granting of this franchise and ending on December 31 thereafter, and (b) on or before the first day of March of each year thereafter during the term of this franchise a sum of money equal to four (4) percent of the gross sales of electric energy to customers served under residential, commercial and industrial rate schedules (as so prescribed) within the corporate limits of the city during the preceding calendar year, on condition that, in the event that the city shall grant to any other entity the right to use and occupy its streets for like purposes, such use and occupancy shall be upon the same terms and conditions as those herein contained, including the payment provisions hereof. 
(2)  The amount, if any, of any tax, fee, charge or imposition of any kind required, demanded or exacted by the city on any account, other than ad valorem taxes on property and license taxes on the sale of home appliances, shall operate to reduce to that extent the amount due from the percentage of gross sales above provided for. 
(3)  The company shall fully protect, indemnify and save harmless the city from all damages to person or property caused by the construction, maintenance, operation or extension of poles, wires or other apparatus, or conditions of streets, alleys or public places resulting therefrom, for which the said city would otherwise be liable. 
(4)  The company shall, in constructing, maintaining, operating and extending its poles, wires and other apparatus, submit and be subject to all reasonable exercises of the police power by this city. Nothing contained herein, however, shall require the company to surrender or limit its property rights created hereby without due process of law, including adequate compensation, for any other purpose at the instance of the city or for any purpose at the instance of any other entity, private or governmental. 
Sec. III. - Filing of written acceptance; contract. 
    Be it further ordained that the company shall, within ninety (90) days from the approval of this ordinance, file its written acceptance of the same with the clerk of said city, so as to form a contract between the parties. 
Sec. IV. - Conflict. 
    Be it further ordained that upon such acceptance all laws and ordinances, and all agreements between the parties, in conflict herewith be and the same shall thereupon stand repealed and terminated, respectively. 
ARTICLE IV. - CABLE SERVICES AND OTHER TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES FRANCHISING 
DIVISION 1. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 1.1. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this ordinance, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings set forth in this section, unless the context clearly indicates that another meaning is intended. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the plural number include the singular number and words used in the singular number include the plural number. 
    1.1.01 "Cable services" means "cable services" as defined in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 and the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, and as may be further amended from time to time (the "Cable Act"). In the event that "cable services" is no longer defined in the Cable Act or the definition in the Cable Act otherwise becomes inapplicable, "cable services" shall mean "cable services" as defined in the Cable Act immediately prior to such term no longer being defined in the Cable Act or such definition otherwise becoming inapplicable. 
    1.1.02 "Cable System" means any "cable system" as defined in the Cable Act. 
    1.1.03 "City" means the City of Fitzgerald, Georgia. 
    1.1.04 "City council" means the city council of the city and its designee or any successor thereto. 
    1.1.05 "Franchise" means an initial authorization, or renewal thereof, issued by the city, whether such authorization is designated as a franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, agreement or otherwise, which authorizes the occupation and use of the streets to provide telecommunications services. 
    1.1[.]06 "Grantee" means the legal entity to which is granted the right, authority and responsibility to construct, install, operate and maintain a system of equipment as necessary to furnish, supply and distribute cable or telecommunications services, or both, to inhabitants within the franchise area. 
    1.1.07 "May" is permissive. 
    1.1.08 "Ordinance" means this ordinance [ No. 1214] and all modifications and amendments thereto. 
    1.1.09 "Person" means any individual or any association, firm, partnership, joint venture, corporation or other legally recognized entity, whether for profit or not for profit, but shall not mean the city. 
    1.1.10 "Shall" is mandatory, not merely directive. 
    1.1.11 "Streets" means the surface of, as well as the spaces above and below, any and all streets, alleyways, avenues, highways, boulevards, driveways, bridges, tunnels, parks, parkways, public grounds or waters, and other public rights-of-way within or belonging to the city. 
    1.1.12 "Telecommunications services" means the receipt and/or distribution, through any means, including, without limitation, coaxial cable, optical fiber, or satellite or microwave transmission, of one or more audio, voice or data signals. Telecommunications services includes both cable services and noncable telecommunications services. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § I, 3-11-96) 
DIVISION 2. - GRANTING AUTHORITY AND FRANCHISING PROCEDURE 

Sec. 2.1. - Granting authority. 
    2.1.01 No person shall provide cable services or operate a cable system without a franchise granted in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance and no person shall use or occupy the streets to provide any telecommunications service other than cable services without a franchise granted in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance. 
    2.1.02 The city council may grant one or more franchises in accordance with this ordinance, provided that the city council reserves the right to modify any provision of this ordinance by amendment hereof. 
    2.1.03 The grant of any franchise shall be made by adoption of a separate ordinance by the city council and shall be on such terms and conditions as may be specified in said separate ordinance and/or a franchise agreement between the city and the franchisee. 
    2.1.04 Any franchise granted shall be nonexclusive. The city specifically reserves the right to grant, at any time, such additional franchises as it deems appropriate and or itself engage in the provision of telecommunications services. 
    2.1.05 A franchise may be granted for all or any defined portion of the city and for all or less than all telecommunications services, and for telecommunications services for all or less than all purposes. 
    2.1.06 The grant of franchises by the city shall be subject to the provisions of applicable law, such as the provisions in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, governing cable television franchises and renewals thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § I, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 2.2. - Franchise applications. 
    2.2.01 Applications for franchises shall be submitted in such form and be issued on such terms and conditions as the city council may determine, subject to applicable law. 
    2.2.02 Any application for a franchise shall contain and/or require the following information with respect to the proposed franchise and such other information as the city council shall deem necessary or appropriate: 
(i)  Applicant's name, address, telephone number, and federal employer identification number or social security number; copy of applicant's corporate charter or partnership agreement as applicable; and any trade names (and registrations) used by applicant; 
(ii)  A detailed statement of the corporation or business entity organization of the applicant, including, but not limited to, the following, and to whatever extent required by the city: 
(a)  The names and the residence and business addresses of all officers and directors of the applicant; 
(b)  The names, residence, and business addresses of all persons and entities having any share of the ownership of the applicant and the respective ownership share of each person or entity; 
(c)  The names and address of any parent or subsidiary of the applicant, namely, any other business entity owning or controlling applicant in whole or in part or owned or controlled in whole or in part by the applicant, and a statement describing the nature of any such parent or subsidiary business entity, including, but not limited to, telecommunications or cable systems owned or controlled by the applicant, its parent, and subsidiary, and the areas served thereby; 
(d)  A detailed and complete financial statement of the applicant, certified by an independent certified public accountant, for the fiscal year immediately preceding the date of the application hereunder, or a letter or other acceptable evidence in writing from a recognized lending institution or funding source, addressed to both the applicant and the council, setting forth the basis for a study performed by such lending institution or funding source, and a clear statement of its intent as a lending institution or funding source to provide whatever capital shall be required by the applicant to construct and operate the proposed telecommunications or cable system in the city, or a statement from an independent certified public accountant certifying that the applicant has available sufficient free, net, and uncommitted cash resources to construct and operate the proposed cable or telecommunications system in the city; 
(e)  A detailed financial plan (pro forma) describing for each year of the franchise, projected number of subscribers, rates, all revenues, operating expenses, capital expenditures, depreciation schedules, income statements, and a sources and uses of funds statement; and 
(f)  A statement identifying, by place and date, any other cable system or telecommunication franchise(s) awarded to the applicant, its parent or subsidiary; the status of said franchise(s) with respect to completion thereof; the total cost of completion of such franchised cable or telecommunication system(s); and the amount of applicant's and its parent's or subsidiary's resources committed to the completion thereof; 
(iii)  A detailed description of the proposed plan of operation of the applicant which shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(a)  A description of the cable services and any other telecommunications services proposed to be provided; 
(b)  A detailed map indicating all areas proposed to be served, and a proposed time schedule for the installation of all equipment necessary to become operational throughout the entire area to be serviced;
